INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the Senate acquainting the House of the following resolution agreed to by the Senate:

PARA.TAB: That the proposed resolution for the establishment of an Audit Committee be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry and report by 23 August 1994, and that the committee, in conducting its inquiry, give particular attention to the appropriateness of establishing a separate committee rather than conferring the functions of the proposed committee on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

INTERJECT.PARA: Given the length of the proposed resolution, I do not intend to read the terms of it, which will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: The proposed resolution read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: (1)That a joint standing committee, to be known as the Audit Committee of Parliament, be appointed to:

PARA.TAB: (a)advise the Auditor-General of the committee's audit priorities in respect of Commonwealth bodies;

(b)advise the responsible Minister in relation to a government business enterprise (GBE) that the committee attaches a priority to a performance audit being undertaken of certain activities of that GBE, for the purpose of requesting that Minister, where appropriate, to seek the Auditor-General's agreement to undertake the performance audit;

(c)consider the resources of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) for the purposes of assessing the effectiveness of the ANAO in undertaking its charter and the adequacy of resource levels, including charge-out rates, to undertake an appropriate program of audit coverage; and as appropriate, make recommendations to the Auditor-General and/or the Executive Government; and

(d)report to both Houses on any matters arising out of the committee's consideration of ANAO resources, reports of the Independent Auditor on the operations of the ANAO, or other matters relating to the performance of the Auditor-General's functions which the committee considers should be drawn to the attention of the Parliament.
(a)the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate each alternating as chairman and deputy chairman for periods determined by the committee;
(b)the chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts;
(c)two Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, three Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips; and

(d)one Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, one Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and one Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: (3)That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4)That the members of the committee hold office as a joint standing committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.

(5)That the deputy chairman shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and that at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to examine.

(7)That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at the time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of a subcommittee, the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.

(8)That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to adjourn from time to time, and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(9)That five members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee, and a majority of members of a subcommittee constitute a quorum of that subcommittee.

(10)That in matters of procedure the chairman or deputy chairman presiding at the meeting have a deliberative vote and, in the event of an equality of voting, have a casting vote, and that, in other matters, the chairman or deputy chairman have a deliberative vote only.

(11)That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(12)That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(13)That a message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 29 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill provides for an increase in the funds appropriated under the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1988 to support tertiary education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students. The funds concerned are to be transferred from the Higher Education Funding Act 1988.

PARA.TAB: The funds concerned will be made available under the Commonwealth's Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program. This program was introduced in 1990 and underpins the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, AEP. Funding for this program is presently appropriated on a triennial basis with the second triennium covering the years 1993 to 1995. The Commonwealth remains committed to the AEP, which addresses the inequality of educational opportunities and outcomes between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and non-Aboriginal people.

During 1993 the Commonwealth government, with the agreement of all state and territory governments, commenced a national review of education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The national review has been asked to examine whether or not the strategies developed over the first three years of the AEP have been effective and to suggest some new strategic directions where these might be required.

A national reference group to oversee the review was appointed in October 1993. The 10 members of the reference group, chaired by Mandawuy Yunupingu, issued a discussion paper in February 1994. The second stage of the review, which will take account of the views put forward in submissions and in the responses to the discussion paper, will culminate in a final report and recommendations to be presented in September 1994.

In addition to this national review, the April 1994 meeting of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs considered a discussion paper presented by the Commonwealth in relation to developing a national strategy for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The council agreed to establish a group to provide advice to ministers within three months on the terms of reference, membership, term and financial arrangements for the development of a national strategy. Following acceptance of the terms of reference by ministers, a national strategy working party, chaired by the Commonwealth, will be established. The working party will provide a progress report for consideration by the ministerial council at its October-November 1994 meeting.

The Commonwealth looks forward to responding positively to both the recommendations of the national review and the report of the national strategy working party. The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1994 provides for a small increase in Commonwealth funding of the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program for 1995 and 1996 to support tertiary education provision in remote areas.

This bill provides for the appropriation of $84.131 million in 1995 and $256,000 in 1996. The 1995 funding level represents an increase of $212,000 on the amount currently specified in the principal act. The amount appropriated for 1996 reflects the amount of funds to be transferred from the Higher Education Funding Act. Legislation will be introduced at a later stage to increase that amount to reflect the appropriate base level of funding which should apply in 1996 and later years. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1994. From the outset can I say that the coalition fully supports this bill and fully supports the funding of education for Aboriginal Australians. Nevertheless, as the opposition, we want to raise some issues about this area of government administration. To a significant extent any debate about education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is also a debate about much broader issues. The coalition believes that education is fundamental to relieving social disadvantage for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the areas of housing, health and employment opportunities, as well as improving social justice and bringing about reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: Many of us in this place are aware that governments essentially have two levers that they can use: one is financial help to Australians and the distribution of resources in that way; and the other is education. The coalition is fully supportive of funding Aboriginal education as proposed in this bill. However, the current social indicators in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are clear testimony to the fact that Labor policies of the last decade—with their focus on land rights, a treaty and funding communities rather than individuals and families—have not worked. We have to remember that the social disadvantage which still exists in this country in the area of Aboriginal affairs is after 11 years of a federal Labor government.

As the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody identified, education has the power to bring about political, social and economic change for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Whether the problem is sanitation, community or domestic violence, primary health needs, alcoholism, family breakdown, law and order or petrol sniffing, education is the most important process available to governments to bring about a medium to long-term change. I think all Australians are deeply desirous that that change be brought about. I hope this sort of funding may help some way towards achieving that goal.

The royal commission also recognised the debilitating effect the lack of training and education had on employment opportunities. The consequence is that many Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders find it extremely difficult to have any economic power. Huge levels of funding have been put into this area—about $10 billion over the last 20 years. Over the past few years a substantial amount of money has also been put into Aboriginal education.

However, I am concerned that the educational outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have not improved in proportion to the money being spent. Many people on both sides of the House, not just on our side, would be concerned about that. There has been some improvement—I acknowledge and welcome it—but, given the millions of dollars spent over the last decade, we should be seeing a far more dramatic improvement in the educational outcomes and social indicators within our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

Approximately $160 million has been allocated for the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program from 1 January 1993 to 30 June 1995. This bill will appropriate another $85.387 million to AESIP largely for the period 1 January 1995 to 30 June 1996. While the base level of funding from January 1996 to June 1997 has not yet been appropriated, we will be looking at an expenditure of $330 million or so on just this program from 1993 to 1997.

When this amount of money is being expended in this area, there is a great need to have very clear quantitative performance indicators. I stress how important it is to ensure that the money which is allocated actually achieves the outcomes that all of us would desire. With this amount of money being spent on Aboriginal education, as well as around $350 million per year in special allocations for Aboriginal education to higher education institutions and $150.5 million funding directly to students and their families through Abstudy, tutorial assistance and vocational and educational guidance, one could expect some dramatic improvements in the participation rates, retention rates and educational achievement of Aboriginal students. Sadly, this is not the case. Once again, it seems that the federal Labor Party is throwing substantial amounts of money at Aboriginal education, but it is not getting to the right people or to the right areas so as to make a significant difference to the proportion that is needed in the field of education.
In 1988, the Aboriginal Education Policy Taskforce, which examined a wide range of issues concerning the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines remain the most educationally disadvantaged people in Australia. Now, six years later, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders remain the most educationally disadvantaged group.

The Hughes report focused on four key areas which the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy also endorsed: to increase the involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in educational decision making; to strive to achieve equality of access to educational services; to strive to achieve equality of educational participation; and to strive for equitable and appropriate educational outcomes. I will certainly be making further reference to that last point a little later.

PARA.TAB: No-one would question that these are vital areas in the improvement of Aboriginal education. However, it is now four years since AEP came into effect. This was determined by the government to be a suitable time to also allow a review of the effects of AESIP funding and to determine what progress has been made and what further efforts must be made.

Unfortunately, the statistics from the 1994 national review of education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are an indictment of the government in the way that money has been thrown at the problem but to little avail. The 1994 national review has provided considerable evidence that, despite some improvements—we welcome those improvements; I also acknowledge that it is a difficult area—in the educational participation and retention rates of Aboriginal Australians over the last four years, there is still reason for considerable concern that greater progress has not been made. There is a lot of distance to cover before equity will be attained.

Most Australian children attend preschool as four-year-olds. The 1994 review shows that the gap in the preschool participation rate between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and other Australian four-year-olds almost halved between 1986 and 1991. However, the level still remains at 9.5 per cent lower than the 58 per cent for other Australians who attend preschool.

In the rural areas the situation is worse than in the cities and towns, with participation rates for preschool Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders being considerably less than for their urban counterparts. Less than 80 per cent of five-year-old Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children living in small communities of 200 people or less are apparently enrolled in a school or preschool. It is alarming that 13.2 per cent of five-year-old Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children are apparently not participating in any form of education, compared with 5.9 per cent of other Australian five-year-olds. They are therefore later to start school generally than other Australian children.

Primary school participation rates for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children still remain lower than for other Australians, but the vast majority—95 per cent of them—will begin and complete primary school. I hope that, as time goes on in this great country of ours, that will bring benefits to the country and hopefully those children will stay on through high school. However, again there is a reason for deep concern with regard to achievement. Whereas 16 per cent of other Australian children have significantly lower levels of achievement in literacy and numeracy than the average, a huge 45 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children have significantly lower levels of achievement in these areas. What we have to recognise as Australians is that these are fundamental skills for participating in the world today.

The huge pool of money is simply not providing the resources for or meeting the needs of these children. Of this $84 million that the government is now appropriating for the January 1995 to June 1996 period, what guarantee can the government give that the money will actually reach and benefit the young people of Australia? This is where we have to ensure that it is the outcomes from the use of this money that are important to us. What these children with learning problems need is more teachers on the ground—a better teacher-student ratio—so that time and effort can be spent in order to address the learning difficulties of these children. Are they going to get it? That is really the test for when we spend money in this place.

In the secondary school area the statistics are even more staggering. Grades eight and nine are compulsory years of high school, yet a significant number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students are not completing years eight and nine. An estimated 25 per cent plus of those who start secondary school leave before the end of year 10. The educational disadvantage of these students, which is the prime focus of the AESIP funding, is not being alleviated.

Since 1986 a consistent average of about 10 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students have dropped out of school before July in their year 9. This is in complete contrast, and therefore is of tremendous concern, to other Australian children, where the great majority finish year nine and the year 10 retention rate is 98 per cent.

In 1992-93, 16 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students who were still in school in year nine had left before July in year 10. In 1988-89, 30 per cent of 16- and 17-year-old Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander young people were participating in education or formal training, compared with the national equivalent of 75 per cent—over double for the rest of Australia. In 1993 little had changed, with only an estimated 33 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students who began secondary school still attending in year 12 compared with 76 per cent of other Australian students—that is, five years later there was only a three per cent change in this area of education and formal training.

Furthermore, it is one thing to try to improve retention rates, as we should, but it is another to monitor the course skills to determine what level of work is actually being done. Many Aboriginal students are in high school doing work at the basic primary level. I have talked to some primary teachers and principals in some areas which have a large population of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students. Their concern, as one person said to me, was `Yes, we do have our students here. They are 15- and 16-year-olds, but the real problem for Australia is that they are still doing grade three work.' We have to try to move them up to the standard of most other Australians.

He said that was the real problem. Our statistics often show that we are doing well but really, at the grassroots level, the change is not taking place. What proportion of this appropriation is to be used to create a national standards program for education? What performance indicators are there going to be? Or are we going to look back in, say, five years and still see very little progress?

I thought I would refer to a speech the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) gave in the same area a year ago. He said that there were three national priorities, the first being to respond to relevant recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. How much progress have we really made in this area a year or so later? Has there been some incremental change or not? Does the parliament know? I do not think we do and I think it is time to account for how we are progressing in achieving our goals, which I would understand both sides of the House would be desirous of.

Another important national priority, the minister said, was implementing a national Aboriginal languages and literacy strategy, which began in January 1993. This was about providing special languages other than English in Aboriginal schools. I ask the government and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), who is at the table: how many schools is this program being taught in? How many children are benefiting from this program? What are the languages which are being taught? If we say, `This is the purpose of the money,' then 18 months later we should be able to say, `So many young people are being taught so many different languages.'

Then there was the bilingual and bicultural program. What is the nature of these programs that are actually operating in the schools? Where are they being taught? Are they being taught in all our schools throughout Australia, or are there only little pockets where the money has reached and is having an effective change at the grassroots level? How many students are involved in these bicultural programs? If we are about reconciliation in this country, we have to get people involved. Is the money getting there and influencing people's minds? Are they successful programs? What criteria is used to measure the success if they are successful? It is these types of things I think the parliament needs to have some answers on.

The next point was measuring the development of Aboriginal languages and curriculum materials. What measures have been undertaken in the last 18 months? Do we have booklets? Do we have programs? What was the nature of the materials? How many schools have those materials? It may be very well for us to develop these materials, but do they get into the classrooms and are they used in the classrooms?

Another point was language teaching and paraprofessional staffing resources. What resources have been developed 18 months later? How many children are benefiting from the increased resources to our teachers and paraprofessionals in this area?

The third point was about national reconciliation and schooling strategy and that there was a role there. Minister Beazley said last year that it was vital to enable advancement in harmonious relationships, so the funding of the money was there to encourage an advancement in our educational institutions. I fully support that and so does the coalition. He went on to say that it would be for all levels of education. Again, what is the nature of the material that is being developed? Can the minister guarantee that all levels of education are benefiting? Is it in all our schools? Is it in all our tertiary institutions? Is it in our TAFE colleges?

After all, are Aboriginal studies undertaken only in our TAFE colleges and universities? Or are we yet to have these studies, for example, in our science or economics courses? The government claimed that these studies would be available to be undertaken at all levels of education. The minister referred to a whole list of areas seeking to bring about reconciliation within education to help future generations of Australians understand each other.

The minister said, firstly, that elements of the reconciliation and schooling strategy for which specific funds would be appropriated were an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies curriculum project which contributes to the national collaborative curriculum exercise and to preparing a publication for use in Australian schools. Has that been achieved? Do we have it 18 months later or do we not?

Secondly, the minister said that a review would be undertaken and that there would be a survey of best practice for schooling. What is the outcome of that? Which are the best practice schools? Where are the best practice teachers? Do we know that? Is the money really achieving the goals set by the government last year or not? Thirdly, the minister referred to the teacher in-service module education system designed to increase the quality of in-service training. What has been the in-service training over the last 18 months?

Fourthly, the minister referred to a comparable exercise for teacher pre-service training and the sister school scheme which was launched in 1992 and which aims to encourage contact between students of predominantly non-Aboriginal schools and students in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander schools. I would be interested to know how many of those exchange schools actually exist under the sister school scheme. Is it working well? Is it effective? How is it going? We did not hear from the government today on how these things were working, even though these issues were outlined in the minister's speech last year.

Further, the minister said that steps had been taken to research and develop a national strategy to improve education. In his speech today we did hear something of that national strategy, which I am pleased to see is being put together. Also, the government wanted to develop a national strategy of training for Aboriginal prisoners and ex-offenders. I am not sure whether we have made any progress in achieving that in the last year or whether that will come up under the ministerial council in September.

So one can go through a whole range of goals set by the government last year. I would like to find out whether any of these goals have been achieved or whether there is an incremental step progress towards achieving them. Unless we start focusing our minds on the outcomes of the money going to this area I do not believe we are dealing with education and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people fairly and openly.

The government needs to adopt benchmarks so that at high school level students, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, will be expected to attain proficiency in reading, writing and mathematics, and no doubt we could add to that list. But we do need benchmarks to determine whether the money that is being allocated and appropriated by our parliament is actually bringing about results.

At the tertiary level the picture is slightly more optimistic. This is encouraging because five or six years ago very few Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were reaching tertiary education; but this is most encouraging. In fact, participation rates for the age group 16 to 24 are higher than those for other Australians. Also, although Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders have lower university participation rates than other Australians, the numbers involved doubled in the period from 1988 to 1993. I say to the minister: I really do welcome that, having been a former shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, and for Australia that can be seen as exciting.

The number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander graduates is steadily increasing and let us hope it continues to increase. Despite these modest improvements the general picture for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students is still bleak. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy—AEP—sought to achieve equity in educational participation. These statistics indicate that we are still a long way from that goal. The AEP also sought to achieve equality of access to educational services but the 1994 review shows that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in rural areas and especially in the remote areas of Australia are severely disadvantaged in regard to access to education, and the gaps are getting wider between urban and rural participation in post-compulsory education. The government has also ignored many other Australians in rural and remote areas of Australia in regard to educational access over the last decade.

Through my speech I have highlighted just a few of the educational statistics. The social indicators also show that the health, housing and unemployment situation of Aboriginals has not changed significantly throughout the government's 11-year effort in this area. Currently, the transition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to the labour market is abysmal. These people continue to experience lower rates of employment—in fact, 38 per cent of 20- to 24-year-old Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are outside the labour market. Is this funding going to bring about the change we so desperately need? It is clear that the government must be more accurate in targeting the specific areas of need and the most effective ways of spending taxpayers' dollars in order to alleviate the educational disadvantage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

In conclusion, it will be a challenge for the present government to ensure that this funding is directed to where it will be most effective. We support the funding but, under this government's administration, is the money really achieving the outcomes that all of us desire? I do not believe it is. It is very important that we achieve these educational outcomes where it will make a difference. Ultimately, we must bring about change to overcome the social disadvantage which we now notice amongst our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander friends. Education is fundamental to that. The coalition fully supports this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to contribute to the debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill, which is providing an increase of $212,000 to the total of $84.131 million in 1995 under the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program. The total funding under this program is provided to assist and support tertiary education provisions for Aboriginal students in remote areas. The last year of the current triennium under this program, which is the second triennium of the program, will be 1995. There is also in this legislation provision for a one-off appropriation of $256,000 for 1996—which really foreshadows the next triennium—to the Notre Dame University in Western Australia to provide some particular programs for Aboriginal people in the Kimberleys.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear the contribution made by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), leading for the opposition on this bill. He raised a lot of issues and made a lot of observations with which we would agree. There are also some with which we would not agree, and that is quite obvious from the different positions adopted by the government and the opposition in relation to Aboriginal issues generally.

I will not be able to respond to all the questions that the honourable member raised, although I may well be able to respond to some. Initially, I have only one observation to make about the opposition's general proposition in connection with Aboriginal issues at the present—and this was repeated by the honourable member—and that is that those opposite continue to claim that Aboriginal land rights are almost a separate factor in the whole question of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander rights and development in Australia.

Those opposite make the assertion that the government is preoccupied with land rights to the exclusion of an appropriate level of concern for all of those other major deficiencies in the standards of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia, be it in the area of health, housing, education or social conditions generally. That is not the case. The government has chosen to give such importance to the question of land rights because the government quite correctly sees land rights as central and in many ways fundamental to the whole question of Aboriginal advancement, Aboriginal development, Aboriginal self-development, Aboriginal pride and Aboriginal dignity.

The whole future of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia to a very large extent is premised on whether or not they will have appropriate access and rights to land. The Mabo High Court decision, which was a momentous decision on this question, put to bed forever one of the most serious and gross offences that could ever be claimed against Aboriginal people, and that was the suggestion that they were not here in Australia before 1788—the concept of terra nullius, an unoccupied land.Any simple observation of a map of Australia showing tribal areas indicates that the whole of the continent was occupied. The High Court has given recognition to that.

There are Aboriginal people who, despite Mabo, are the least benefited by it because they have been the most dispossessed. The whole question of Mabo depended upon Aboriginal people being able to prove a continuing association with the land over which they have some claim which has not been otherwise alienated as a result of government action. Those Aboriginal people who were the most dispossessed, who were the most displaced, who have been the most disadvantaged, who have been the most alienated from their initial land are the people who can provide no such proof. The people who are not able to make any effective claim are the most disadvantaged in terms of land claims. That is a fundamental premise to the whole approach that the government has made in connection with the Aboriginal land fund, which has been so offhandedly dismissed by the opposition as part of the shambles that it has displayed in connection with Aboriginal policy generally.

I compliment the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) and I congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) for the way in which they have cooperated in the development of Aboriginal policy in the educational area and the extent to which they have been able to win significant gains in funding. I also congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for his record period in that office. I think he has done an outstanding job. The whole Australian Aboriginal community relates well to him because it understands and knows the nature of his commitment and his dedication to their interests.

The program that I referred to earlier under which these funds were made available was introduced in 1990. That program is basic to the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy generally, which has become known by the abbreviated term the `AEP'. The AEP is an agreement between the nine governments of Australia to cooperate to overcome clear educational disadvantages for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by the end of this century. That is a tall order. I hope their commitment matches their rhetoric. In 200 years we have not done that.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, it is not such a long time ago that the first Aboriginal person—I think it was Charlie Perkins—graduated from one of our universities. We now have thousands of Aboriginals in tertiary institutions. We have a long way to go. I would be delighted if the nine governments of Australia—the six state governments, the two territory governments and the federal government—were to achieve their objective to overcome those educational disadvantages by the end of this decade, by the end of this century.

A review of the AEP is currently under way. A discussion paper issued in February this year highlighted a number of the issues of concern and the direction that the review was taking. We expect the final report and the recommendations to be presented later this year in September. The Australian Education Ministers Council is presently in the process of developing a national education strategy for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Later this year a progress report will be available from the working party which the council has established.

The environment in Australia at present is particularly propitious for major changes to be introduced, for major initiatives to be taken, for innovations. I think those changes first came about at the time of the extremely important 1967 referendum. For the first time, Aboriginal people were to be treated in the same way as other Australians in relation to the census and in relation to the capacity of national governments to legislate on their behalf. Since Federation, since the Commonwealth came into existence, most referendums have been defeated. The 1967 referendum was overwhelmingly supported. That reflects very well on the Australian community at that time, the people who gave their commitment to that decision.

We later had the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, ATSIC. To a very large extent, it was designed to provide Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia with the opportunity to participate in their own government, their own programming, their own funding, the allocation of funds for different purposes. That has more recently been followed by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, of which Elliott Johnston QC was the commissioner. The report of the commission came down in 1991.

We are now undertaking a reconciliation process between white and black Australians. The dialogue is in place; the objectives are being pursued. All of that is taking place within the context of consideration being given to constitutional reform, to recognition of Aboriginal Australians, as the original owners of this continent, to how their circumstances and their aspirations might be accommodated within the constitution. There was also the historic Mabo decision. All of those elements are building a momentum which helps to create an environment which is conducive to change. I think all Australians applaud the development of these circumstances.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, for example, undertakes periodic examinations of the circumstances of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. A committee report on access and equity, which was tabled, I think, here in the House in November last year, was designed to examine the extent to which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people had equitable access to Commonwealth programs and services. That access and equity strategy has been in place, as far as the government is concerned, since 1985 and it was extended to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in 1989.

Part of the executive summary in connection with that inquiry said that the strategy `had still to achieve any significant outcomes for Australia's most disadvantaged and dispossessed groups of people'. Those barriers, of course, which help to impede the removal of disadvantage include racism, language, culture, inappropriately designed and delivered services, and a lack of services in many areas.

Fundamental to this question as well was the Elliott Johnston Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Commissioner Johnston's report made 339 recommendations, which were not simply designed to look after Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people when in gaol but were to prevent their incarceration in the first place. He quite correctly, and I thought admirably, canvassed the whole area of Aboriginal rights, circumstances and conditions. And 338 of those recommendations were endorsed by Australian governments; only one out of the 339 recommendations was not. Those recommendations which specifically related to education were from 289 to 299. I make mention of the observation made by Commissioner Johnston in relation to preschool. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it should be recognised that to a considerable extent the success of the whole National Aboriginal Education Policy—
the NAEP—
will turn on the success of the preschooling initiatives . . .

If I have time, I will be saying something about the participation rate for Aboriginal children in preschools. That is of fundamental importance. What we finish up with in tertiary education institutions on the part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, or any other group of people in Australia, starts fundamentally in the home and also fundamentally in their opportunity for access to preschool experience.

PARA.TAB: Of particular relevance and importance in Commissioner Johnston's recommendations was part of his recommendation 299 where he said that it is to be recognised that the aims of that national Aboriginal education policy:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . are not only to achieve equity in education for Aboriginal people but also to achieve a strengthening of Aboriginal identity, decision making and self-determination . . .

They are fundamental issues. It is not just a matter of providing greater opportunities for Aboriginal people to go into the schools and, hopefully, to remain in schools but a recognition of the particular characteristics and features of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders which contribute to their Aboriginality and which provide them with a basis for self-pride and self-realisation to develop and express their dignity. All of that is fundamental to our whole approach to these issues.

PARA.TAB: Let me give some background information about this situation generally. Towards the end of the 1980s, less than half of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children had any preschool experience compared with a national rate in excess of 90 per cent—an area of serious disadvantage in relation to the point I have just made about the importance of preschool access. Only about 85 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children of compulsory school age were actually in school compared with a national rate so close to 100 per cent that it does not matter. Only 10 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people over 15 held any post-school qualifications compared with a national rate of over 30 per cent.

It is a national tragedy that indigenous Australians continue to be the most chronically disadvantaged group on every social indicator—health, housing, employment and education. In many respects they are more disadvantaged than many of the people of the Third World. Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are Australian citizens—just as truly, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you and I are. They are not to be marginalised and sidelined. The deficiencies have to be made up and compensations have to be built into the system.

The commissioner, Elliott Johnston, made it clear that the major factor leading to the overrepresentation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody is their disadvantaged and unequal position in Australian society. He investigated 99 cases of Aboriginal deaths in custody. Of those 99 cases, 40 represented people who had not proceeded beyond primary school—and only two had completed secondary schooling. Since the completion of the royal commission, another 55 Aboriginal people have died in custody—the number may now exceed 55.

There are some bright spots. Let me deal with some of them. In 1982 there were 854 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in higher education institutions; in 1992, there were 4,807. In 1989 the participation rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in the 17 to 64 year age group in tertiary education institutions was 20 in every thousand. In 1991 the rate increased to 35 in every thousand. In 1988 there were 2,565 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders enrolled in universities. In 1993, there were 5,578. That is an increase of 117 per cent. The number of all Australians participating in university education between 1988 and 1993 increased by 32 per cent, so there was a dramatically larger increase for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students.

Even in 1993, ATSI students made up only one per cent of the student population when, as a proportion of the total population, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders made up about two per cent. I think that it was 1991 when the intake of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students into the universities finally reached the same level as their numbers as a proportion of the population. I say in response to the former shadow minister, who spoke in opening for the opposition, that we are making progress. That progress is being made by this government and by these ministers because of the level of the commitment which they are demonstrating. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address this bill, I will take up some of the points mentioned by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who spoke with such absolute passion and spoke such absolute nonsense.
—Were you advising the leader up in the NT?

—Earlier, the honourable member for Charlton—who is now yelling across the floor—said that the coalition did not recognise land rights. May I ask him who he thinks is responsible for the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which gave—at present—over a third of the Northern Territory to Aboriginal people. Was that not the Fraser government? Let us consider the Tonkin government in South Australia. Some 20 per cent of South Australia was given to the Pitjantjatjara and Maralinga people. The honourable member for Charlton does not know what he is talking about.

PARA.TAB: Let us take that a bit further. The honourable member for Charlton was talking about the Native Title Act and how marvellous a benefit this had been to Aboriginal people. Recently I had a chance to talk with some of those Aboriginal people about that act. An Aboriginal lawman said that, originally, white men took Aboriginal land; now Aboriginal people were taking Aboriginal land from other Aboriginal people. He ended the submission that he gave to me by saying that, on the basis of this native title legislation, there will be bloodshed amongst Aboriginal people. Is that something to be proud of?

I suggest to the honourable member for Charlton that, if he wishes to go on with this great rhetoric, he should go out and find out exactly what is going on. The Aboriginal lawman also said that the most disadvantaged Australians, those Aboriginal people who do not benefit from Mabo, are `the fundamental premise for the land fund'. The land fund is to cover those people who cannot make a claim. I ask the honourable member for Charlton why the land fund bill currently before this parliament does not specify that the fund is for those people who cannot make a claim under Mabo. There is no mention at all in the land fund legislation of what has been called `the fundamental premise in the legislation'. I suggest that the honourable member should read his own government's legislation before grandstanding in here on subjects that he knows absolutely nothing about.

I now turn to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1994. The amendments to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 are, firstly, to increase the appropriation for funding from 1 January 1995 to 30 June 1996 from $83,919,000 to $84,131,000 and, secondly, to appropriate $256,000 for the next 18-month consecutive period from 1 January 1996 to 30 June 1997.

As both the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) have pointed out, these funds are to assist in overcoming the disadvantage that Aboriginal people suffer in education. A 1988 task force concluded that Aboriginal people were disadvantaged in educational opportunities. To the honourable member for Charlton, who has lauded the achievements of this government while at the same time referring to the incredibly appalling situation that Aboriginal people in this country live in, certainly in relation to their educational standards, I ask: why, after 11 years in government, is that the case if it is not through a failure of this government?

Following the report of the task force, the Aboriginal education program was developed by the Commonwealth in conjunction with the states and territories. Arising out of the Aboriginal education program was the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, which funds Aboriginal education programs. It provides funds to organisations and institutions to supplement the costs of delivering educational services to Aboriginal people. The program supports preschools, primary and secondary schools, and technical and further education. The funding is provided by the Commonwealth as a supplement to the normal provisions of funds for education in the states and territories and is committed on a forward triennial basis.

We are in the second triennium of the Aboriginal education program, which runs from 1993 to 1995. A total of $244 million was committed for the triennium, and originally $83.9 million was committed for the 18-month period from January 1995 to June 1996. This bill increases that amount by $212,000. I believe the proposed increase of $212,000 for 1995-96 and $256,000 for 1996-97 are additional amounts to cover student places at Notre Dame University in Western Australia and for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in the Kimberley region.

There are three national priorities for the second triennium. The first priority is responding to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, particularly with regard to preschool services and increased employment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander educationalists. The second priority is implementing the national Aboriginal languages and literacy strategy, which provides for intensification of efforts to improve English literacy amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander school children and adults and which promotes the teaching of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages in schools. The third priority is implementing the national reconciliation and schooling strategy, which provides for specific schooling strategies that promote the reconciliation process between Australia's indigenous and non-indigenous people.

That said, I will now move forward from the points made by the honourable member for Braddon, who I think covered very adequately the situation regarding the education of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal children in Australia, and discuss some of the very pertinent issues that have been raised with me. I shall discuss the issues in sequence. They all concern education. The first issue arose in Queensland when I visited the Wjal Wjal Aboriginal community. The women in that community approached me with an issue they wished to take up with me. That issue was a key issue—the education of their children.

The problem the women raised with me was that because the community was so small the children had to move to a larger centre for schooling and they had to board; but the bus that took them to school went on Tuesdays, not on Sundays. As a result, the children missed the first two days of the school week, which was hardly conducive to helping them with their school work.

These are some of the problems that Aboriginal children face in getting an adequate education. The Aboriginal communities are isolated and often the whole infrastructure has not been put in place to allow them access to education. This is something that the states and the Commonwealth have to address as a very high priority.

The second community was one that I met at the Central Land Council. Women from adjoining communities came to me. They wanted to talk about education for their children because they wanted their children to be able to go into Alice Springs when they grew up and compete with everybody else for jobs. Because of the way the children were being taught currently they would not be able to do this.

I would not like to see this as a precedent for all communities but, quite interestingly, these women mentioned that the teacher in the Aboriginal community was teaching the children in their own language. The women said to me, `We don't want our children taught in our own language. They speak our language at home. They know the language. We want our children to be taught perfect English to improve their chance of getting a job when they finish school.'

I mention that as an individual instance. In other communities where there may be two or three language groups I believe it is important to keep that language in the school because the children do not have as much access to their own language in the general community. It was an interesting variation on the trend in various communities to teach the children in their own language. The women were saying, `No, that is not what we want. What we want is for the children to learn really good English.' That is something that we have to take on, and the opposition will be doing that in our policy.

The third matter is a much more exciting development. I had an opportunity to go to Yuendumu in the Northern Territory. The question of Aboriginal education had been worrying me because of the problem of the remoteness of Aboriginal communities and the small number of people in those communities. How do we overcome the tyranny of size and distance to address these problems of Aboriginal education?

I need not have worried. The Aboriginal people themselves have come up with a solution, and that solution is the Tanami network. The honourable member for Charlton, who seems to be interested in these matters, may not have heard of this network. The Tanami network currently links several urban and regional centres. On the link-up are Darwin, Lajamanu, Yuendumu, Willowra, Kintore and Alice Springs. The Tanami network is probably the most exciting thing that I have seen in a long time. It is an interactive television network whereby children can sit in front of a television set and be taught by a teacher who is possibly 15,000 miles away. My immediate thought was this: wouldn't David Suzuki not like the opportunity to appear before a class of Aboriginal children and teach them? With the Tanami network he could.

The children in the class can control the camera at the other end—obviously not all of them at once. One, two or three children can sit in front of the controls and move the camera around so that the teacher can be brought into close focus. The camera can be moved to highlight the blackboard or anything else that the teacher wishes to show the class. In his or her turn the teacher is viewing that class on a television monitor and has the opportunity to move the monitor around to see the children in the class, so that when one child raises his or her hand the teacher can see the hand and ask, `What is your question?'

This is just how a normal classroom operates. To have the teacher educating these children from any distance is a fantastic opportunity and is one of the most exciting things I have seen. I believe that this is going to be the future for Aboriginal communities who suffer from the tyranny of distance and the size of the country. It is something that I will be looking at in coalition policy to see how we can assist those Aboriginal communities who have found their own solution to a very important problem.

More often than not, if we listen properly to Aboriginal communities we will find that they have the solutions to their problems. What they need from us are the resources to implement those solutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill is timely as it is the first opportunity for the parliament to consider a social policy area of Aboriginal affairs since the announcement of the opposition's policy review. This followed the notorious visit to the Northern Territory by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus)—surely the least successful visit to central Australia by any duo since Burke and Wills.

PARA.TAB: I am glad to see the review is being conducted within the Liberal Party by one of its few remaining small `l' liberals—the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. These days in the Liberal Party it must be very difficult to undertake that small `l' liberal agenda on issues as diverse as Aboriginal land and social policy, human rights breaches in Tasmania and even the republic. On this side of the parliament we can at least console ourselves that, for all the problems the Liberal Party has in this policy area, the shadow minister is one of the few remaining people with a genuine small `l' liberal agenda.

The Leader of the Opposition described himself as born of the Liberal Party. In my assessment in this policy area, it is much more likely that he has been born of paternalism. It is important to point out that paternalism in Aboriginal affairs is every bit as damaging and dangerous as bigotry, because paternalism relies on a pessimistic judgment about the nature of Aboriginal people—that they cannot be relied upon to make effective decisions about their needs and welfare or land, employment or social conditions, and that only affluent European stock can make these judgments. In many respects, this is the mission reborn into social policy. It has certainly been a feature of the way in which the Liberal Party in recent times has addressed the issue of native title. A true liberal party would regard any denial of decision making as a fundamental breach of human rights.

Paternalism is equally as dangerous in the area of education, but I am glad to see that this bill maintains the government's commitment of financial assistance grants to the states and territories, non-government school systems and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education institutions for the purpose of advancing Aboriginal education. The bill provides particular support in tertiary education with funds transferred from the Higher Education Funding Act.

The government's Aboriginal education policy is currently under review as part of the social justice package, which came out of the Mabo settlement and the government's native title legislation. So in that, at least, both sides of the parliament have something in common—a review of social policy conditions for Aboriginal people. That is important and it gives hope for a more bipartisan attitude to Aboriginal affairs than we have seen in recent months.

The review being undertaken by the government is very important because education for Aboriginal people has immense power and opportunity to bring about social, political and economic change. The key question raised in the review is: can public education resources be applied differently to ensure that indigenous people have the opportunity to achieve equitable outcomes and satisfy a right to have education delivered in more culturally appropriate ways? Looking at the progress so far, there is an opportunity to build on the achievements of this government but to do so in a more culturally appropriate fashion, to produce the reform and improvements for Aboriginal people in education and other areas of social policy that I am sure each member of the parliament would wish.

Since 1986, while the gaps in participation between Aboriginals and other Australians in the age group of three to five years have narrowed, they still remain significant—9.5 per cent—with a higher proportion of five-year-old Aboriginal children, 13.2 per cent, not participating in any form of education; they are mainly located in remote areas of the country. Participation rates are increasing for the compulsory years of schooling. Like other Australians, the vast majority of Aboriginal children will begin and complete primary school. However, an estimated 25 per cent of those who start secondary school education leave before the end of year 10. In 1993, one-third of Aboriginal students who began tertiary school were still attending in year 12, compared with 76 per cent of other Australians. The retention rate is less than half of the non-Aboriginal Australian population.

I am pleased to note the government's greatest progress has been made in the area of TAFE—one of the great reforms of the Keating government in technical education for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal parts of Australian society. Aboriginal participation in technical education is increasing with participation rates now higher than those for other Australians. That is a very significant figure. It is the first time in the history of this country that participation rates for Aboriginal people in a sector of the education system have been higher than those for non-Aboriginal Australians.

University participation rates are still lower than the national average, however—although the number of Aboriginal university students more than doubled between 1988 and 1993. Education, of course, translates into labour market opportunities. Lower rates of employment and a larger proportion of Aboriginal unemployed are great problems in this field. Thirty-eight per cent of 20- to 24-year-old Aboriginals are outside the labour market. In this age group, Aboriginal incomes are about 80 per cent of those of other Australians.

In many respects, this government can point to a record in Aboriginal education that has seen greater improvements than any other government since federation. The statistic on TAFE is outstanding. We need to do more in other areas of participation. I point out that there is a problem with indicators such as these in that they inevitably place pressure on Aboriginal people to make a cultural shift towards the mainstream values that these measures reflect. I think that is an area in which government and policy makers can learn. There have been improvements, but perhaps through more culturally appropriate forms of education and other service delivery even greater improvements can be made.

It is dangerous to assume that Aboriginal people can selectively adopt mainstream material benefits while holding on to their own culture. I notice that there is too little mention in the literature on the review of the Aboriginal education policy of Aboriginal culture and values. Rather, the measures of success are linked more closely to Anglo-Saxon culture than to Aboriginal cultural standards. We need only to look at the history of Aboriginal housing policy in Australia to understand how decisions pushed upon Aboriginal people by federal and state bureaucrats, isolated in their centres of decision making, have had adverse effects.

There needs to be greater suitability and understanding of the needs of Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal communities. For instance, the housing types provided for many decades do not necessarily take account of the Aboriginal extended family structure. Sometimes people point to the problem of overcrowding, but if the housing was built around the needs of Aboriginal families with an extended family structure then overcrowding would not be such a problem. Within Aboriginal families, children have a right to freedom of behaviour in the house far wider—I suppose, by our standards, it is much more lenient—than that which would apply in non-Aboriginal Australia. Also, houses are left empty in Aboriginal communities when a death is associated with them.

All these sensitivities need to be worked out in the standards. We cannot be applying in any area of social policy—education, housing, health—the standards of Anglo-Saxons when Aboriginal people should be empowered to apply their own cultural standards and values and develop some of their own solutions.

When looking at the history of Aboriginal policy in this nation, we see that often the people with the best intentions came away with the worst results. The do-gooders often tried their hardest but did not achieve the sorts of results that Aboriginal people could have achieved if they had access to their own decision making process and had established their own priorities.

For instance, the missions that were established around Australia were a great tragedy. The idea of the missionaries taking Aboriginal people away from their land and establishing them in isolated communities and some of the squats that can be seen in Central Australia and North Queensland has been a tragedy, but it was well motivated. They thought that giving people a Bible and what they regarded as a proper education would lead to progress. It did not because it rode over the top of the sorts of values and culture that should be respected by non-Aboriginal Australians. Equally, the equal pay decision in Australia in the late 1960s was well intentioned and generally a good reform, but it had the unintended consequence of pastoralists no longer employing Aboriginal people on pastoral stations because they did not want to pay the equal pay.

These things need to be thought through by the standards and culture of Aboriginal people, instead of white Anglo-Saxon decision makers and bureaucrats trying to impose their own standards. I wish that in the literature about the review of the Aboriginal education policy and in the social justice package there was greater recognition of that fact. It would lead to better outcomes and better solutions for Aboriginal people throughout the country.

Another area is child care. The values of non-Aboriginal Australia are that institutionalised child care is a good thing, but it can have negative effects in Aboriginal families because the role of child care is integral to the family structure and the culture. There is rebellion against and resentment of institutionalised child care, which is unsuitable. These things need to be worked through.

I was impressed by an article by a school principal in the Northern Territory, Ralph Folds, published in the Australian Aboriginal Studies Journal of 1993. I quote from his experience as a school principal:

SPEECH.PARA: Real social justice demands a more sophisticated perspective of Aboriginal and mainstream societies which displays notions of inequality based solely on cultural arrogance. That would require that the majority of society more readily accepts the differences between the two societies, not solely as inequality but as aspects of very different cultures. Some of these differences are unpalatable and often politically difficult, but wallpapering over them will not make them go away. Such a model of social justice would be highly unpopular with many in both societies. The current model makes it possible at least in the short-term for the national government—
and, I suppose, state governments—

to claim to be delivering equity even if much of what is provided is inappropriate in Aboriginal communities. No doubt it is also expedient for the majority of society to believe that with enough resourcing and manipulation of community institutions comparative disadvantage as now defined by both races can be overcome. It may be of comfort to members of the majority of society who believe in two ways that, for example, schools can produce Aboriginal culture as well as deliver academic outcomes.

A very interesting point is made by this former principal of a school in the Northern Territory about getting the right mix for what we would regard as achievement and the proper sensitivities to and regard for Aboriginal culture and values. It must form the basis of the next step forward in the development of social policies for Aboriginal people. This government, with its historic native title legislation, has established the basis for land rights and access to traditional land in Australia, something that is of immense importance to Aboriginal people, providing not only cultural independence but also an economic base by which security and financial prosperity can be achieved.

PARA.TAB: Having established that foundation stone of Aboriginal policy in native title, the government can build on its achievements in areas such as Aboriginal education. It can become more aware and adaptable in administering these policies to the needs of Aboriginal culture. I am also interested in some of the models being promoted for greater local self-government within Aboriginal communities. The issue of empowerment and decision making by Aboriginal people is very important. We can have a model of native title with its cultural and economic independence benefits, with self-government in social policy; that is, taking Aboriginal people out of some of the mainstream administration that has not produced the results the parliament and the government would have hoped for, and giving Aboriginal people a better sense of their own identity and their own capacity to make decisions in their own interest.

We have some models in Australia outside our traditional three tiers of government. For instance, Aboriginal self-government could be based at the local level on the models that have been developed on Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. They have forms of self-government which go beyond traditional local government responsibilities. If adopted with cooperation between the state and federal administrations, it could achieve greater Aboriginal input into education, health and housing policy. In Queensland we have DOGIT, deed of grant in trust. At Yarrabah near Cairns, the venue for a visit by the native title committee, of which I am a member, the committee members were exposed to some of the benefits of Aboriginal people taking greater control of responsibilities.

They do it there at the municipal level, but surely there is the opportunity in cooperation with the states to give Aboriginal people greater power and authority in decision making in relation to housing, education and health. Many Aboriginal people have clearly stated that they want to control the matters that are important to them and to receive adequate funding to provide an improved range and quality of services. This should not be seen as a threat to other non-Aboriginal interests, least of all economic interests. Many other countries have made the practical decision that it is better for indigenous people to run their own affairs and to solve their own problems. Non-Aboriginal people and governments have not been particularly good at solving the problems that indigenous people experience, even with the most careful planning and good intentions.

There is a historic opportunity for the parliament and the government—I hope joined by the opposition after its policy review—to build on the great success of the native title legislation and to adopt a system of government for Aboriginal communities that empowers them and provides the opportunity to make better decisions in these social policy areas. It is important for the shadow minister and her Liberal and National Party colleagues to understand the model that this government is developing. With native title in place as the foundation stone of cultural and economic independence for Aboriginal people, a huge amount can be achieved.

The attitude of the Liberal Party towards land—which has been expressed by its leader and which may be contradicted by the shadow minister—has been appalling. The Liberal Party says it wants to do something about social policy and wants to do good things for Aboriginal people in relation to housing, health and education but it believes that that will not be done through native title and the parliament accepting the responsibilities given to it by the 1967 referendum.

The Liberal Party will hand over the land issues to the states. The policy of the Western Australian government is to extinguish native title. It is unacceptable for the Liberal Party to say that it wants to help Aboriginal people and it wants to have an impact on social policy but that native title is the responsibility of the states.

This policy was announced at the Western Australian Liberal Party convention. The policy in that state is to extinguish native title. The Liberal Party needs to break the gordian knot, that contradiction it has got itself into, of saying that it wants to do things that will help Aboriginal people when it will also leave the extinguishment of native title to state governments such as Western Australia.

It is hardly surprising that Australia's largest state, Western Australia, has the most crown land, pastoral leases, mining activity and Aborigines. Even the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, has conceded the benefits of a national approach to native title. In 1967, 80 per cent of non-Aboriginal Western Australians—Aboriginals did not have the vote—voted to provide the national parliament with constitutional powers to make special laws for Aboriginal people. The Western Australian government's challenge in the High Court effectively seeks to overturn that mandate.

That mandate should not be disregarded by any of the parties in this parliament. It should be accepted by the Liberal Party in its policy review. We have the power to make special laws for Aboriginal people. I was appalled on a recent visit of the Joint Committee on Native Title to hear Richard Court's evidence about native title. From my assessment, he was appealing to the worst features of Australian society. He was playing on the old fear about uncertainty arising from the tyranny of distance in this nation. I would have thought that, as technology, transport and communication improvements provide Australia with the chance to come closer together, it is a low point in public debate and public life in this country to have a state Premier trying to drag Australians apart by playing on the parochial point of Aboriginal policy in his state.

This legislation, which continues the efforts of the government, provides an important opportunity for the parliament to debate these questions. The issue of Aboriginal policy was put on the agenda, although I am sure not to his liking, by the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory. It is a chance for this government to say that its native title legislation is working, providing the economic and cultural security for the Aboriginal people that was denied Aboriginal communities for more than 200 years in this nation. It also gives members of the government a chance to explore, within the framework of policy review and the social justice package, the opportunity for better policies framed more around the needs of Aboriginal culture and the standards of Aboriginal culture in this country.

This is the opportunity for an historic shift from welfare dependency to greater self-sufficiency for Aboriginal people. I hope this is one of the lasting outcomes of the review of Aboriginal education policy and the social justice package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of remarks about some of the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I wish to say initially that, on this particular occasion, I will decline the invitation of the honourable member for Werriwa to comment on the issue of the republic or gay rights in Tasmania. There will be other opportunities for me to do so.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I want to say a few words about land and Aboriginal people. It is important that, quite unequivocally, many of us on this side of the House accept without reservation the significance of land in Aboriginal culture and to Aboriginal people. It is also important that, quite clearly, the coalition in its totality accepted the Mabo High Court ruling. It was the particular detail of the native title legislation with which we had a problem. It is quite erroneous and divisive to the community—and it does the indigenous people of this country no good—for those opposite to try to perpetuate the myth that we do not accept those fundamental points.

Secondly, I want to call the honourable member's bluff in relation to his remarks about bipartisanship. Even though I have already described in this place what happened during the formulation of the native title legislation, I will do so again. The media, which is so noticeably absent at this time, apart from one lady from the AAP who is in the gallery, has failed to report these things. But I think it is important that it be understood.

At the time of the formulation of the native title legislation, I was the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. Before the 33 principles of the government were issued in June of last year, I went to the minister, with the permission of my leader, and specifically asked whether we could deal with this on a bipartisan basis, whether we could talk privately and whether we could try to sort something out in the same way that the previous Prime Minister had done with the then leader, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), in terms of the reconciliation council. There was no specific response.

Before the legislation was introduced into this place, I went to the minister, again with the authority of the then leader, the honourable member for Wentworth, and asked whether we could sit down and take a bipartisan approach. In language that is not repeatable in this place, I was told that the then Prime Minister would not have a bar of it. The tripe that is so often peddled from the other side of the House about bipartisanship is just not true. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) does not want to take a bipartisan approach. Government members should not try to pin that label on this side of the House.

Thirdly, I say to the honourable member for Werriwa—I also feel strongly about these issues—that this consistent theme we hear from the other side of the House tries to drive a wedge, in political terms, between our spokesmen and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer). The government has tried it again today. It has tried to portray the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), as having different positions from that of the Leader of the Opposition. The government has tried to give her different labels. If the shadow minister were able to speak again in this debate, I am confident that she would say that that is not the case. Government members regularly stand up and try to drive wedges between different people on this side of the House. It is purely a political tactic and it will not wash.

I turn to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill which we are debating today. It seems to me that the speakers on the other side have strayed mightily from the main issue into other general areas. As usual, they have been playing politics with a very sensitive issue, and I do not think that does their reputation much good at all.

The first point I wish to make is that Aboriginal education is improving. There is no question about that.
