But, my God, it is coming off such a low base that, even though the increase in percentages has been phenomenal, the standard of Aboriginal education is still appalling compared with that of the broader community. Not enough has been achieved over a lengthy period. This government has to understand and accept that it has had more than a decade to deal with some of these problems and that it has not done so satisfactorily enough.

I welcome some of the comments made earlier in this debate by the minister in terms of the review and the strategy that is upcoming. I think those are worth while, but I also agree with much of what the shadow minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), said about the need to look at measurable objectives. I think all too often we spend money on a problem, with good intentions—and this applies to both sides of the House and governments of all persuasions both federal and state—but we do not actually achieve a great deal on the ground.

The cycle of Aboriginal disadvantage is well known. If you have poor housing, you tend to have poor health. If you have poor health, you tend not to do well at school. If you do not do well at school then, of course, you do not complete school—which means you do not get a job and so cannot afford to get good housing. Added to that, of course, are the side issues which go with all those conditions—having too much time on your hands, getting into substance and alcohol abuse, domestic violence and overrepresentation in the legal system. We have that cycle of disadvantage. It is a cycle of disadvantage which applies to any economically deprived group anywhere in the world. It applies in this country more to indigenous people than to others, and it has overlays for indigenous people by way of cultural impacts as well.

It seems to me that we have to take a holistic approach to deal with these issues, of which education is a fundamental plank, though not the only plank by any stretch of the imagination. Also important, of course, are self-esteem and the subject of land.

I am concerned about retention rates in schools. We are told that the figures are improving, but in respect of many of the places that I have visited in the four years I have been in this place—as a shadow minister, as a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and as a member of the House of Representatives committee—I do not believe that the statistics are accurate. Many of the schools and communities that I have been to tell me that the figures are often fudged for all sorts of reasons. They might be fudged to make the teachers look as though they are doing a better job than they are. They might be fudged because some payments of government funds are based on the number of kids that go to a particular school. So there is some percentage in artificially inflating those figures. The statistics for attendance, retention rates and achievements are often very doubtful. I would like to see this government do a more meaningful evaluation of what is actually being achieved because I do not believe we are hearing the full story.

I think there are some very difficult dichotomies with traditional learning. In remote communities everybody seems to take the view that the importance of traditional learning has to be accepted. One of the problems with traditional learning is that it does not necessarily do a lot of good when the students want to get a job. I am not saying we should not have traditional learning; I am saying that there is often a conflict and communities have to make a fundamental choice—do they want to get into the economy or do they want traditional learning.

I am reminded of a school at Yirrkala, up in Gove, which has been held up for some years as a good example of Aboriginal control of a school. I remember going there with the House of Representatives Aboriginal affairs committee three or four years ago. People were saying, `Isn't this good? Doesn't it work well? Isn't everybody in the community pleased?' A couple of years later when I was up in that neck of the woods I talked to the senior management of Nabalco, which is the major local industry and employer. I asked them why they did not have more Aboriginal people on their payroll. One of the reasons they quoted was that the children coming out of that school, those you would expect to comprise a fair proportion of those applying for jobs at Nabalco, frankly did not have what we in our terms would regard as a basic education. They had an education and had gone quite a long way through the school system—year 9, year 10, year 11 or whatever—but they really did not have the command of English, the literacy skill, that was needed for a worthwhile job within Nabalco.

I am not judging the rights and wrongs of the school and I am not judging the rights and wrongs of Nabalco; I am saying that often there is a fundamental difference of philosophy and approach between those two sets of objectives. I think we have to be very clear as to our objectives in some of these programs. So traditional learning is a problem and a concern. Equally, the environment in which Aboriginal children are expected to get an education is a concern. This is one of the reasons why I say that the holistic approach to education is fundamental. It is not just a question of putting money into schooling, or teachers, or whatever; it is also a question of making sure that we provide houses.

I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa, that often an Aboriginal household with a lot of people in it—an extended family—is a part of a particular tribe's way of living and culture. Culturally, it is appropriate that, if a family's relatives arrive, often the family cannot tell them to move on—as you or I might do, Mr Deputy Speaker—even if the family wishes them to. Therefore, these people might want to have larger housing which has communal sleeping and eating areas, as well as outside areas.

Often when we go to Aboriginal communities we find in place the so-called traditional three-bedroom brick veneer house with one shower and one toilet—and there are 20, 25 or 30 people in it. I visited the Maningrida community in the Northern Territory, where I found 38 people in one house. And we wonder why, after six months of living in a house like that, in a hot climate, with that number of people, things start to break down! Frankly, I suspect that if 38 members of this chamber were in the same house for six months then there would be a pretty serious breakdown as well.

In terms of education, let us say that we give children the best schooling in the world, with a teacher who is culturally aware and with the right language. Then we give them some homework to do, as you or I might give to our kids, Mr Deputy Speaker—or, in my case, grandchildren. When they go home, how are they going to do homework in that environment?

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't look that old, Peter.

—I started young. Some schools overcome it by having homework sessions in the school classroom after the normal school day. But when the children go home, if they are not getting the right nourishment or if the environment is not right—in terms of domestic violence or stoushes—those sorts of things have to be fixed as well. I am not condemning the indigenous people in that sense; I am saying that the associated problems have to be fixed as well as the purely educational problems.

PARA.TAB: I think it is also important to remember that many of our Aboriginal people live in urban environments. When people move into the cities, we tend to take the view that their aspirations and requirements are the same as those of other people living in urban areas. That is not necessarily the case, in my experience. We have to recognise that quite often the traditional culture and values are just as important to urban dwelling Aboriginal people as they are to those in the more remote communities.

Many of the young non-Aboriginal constituents in my electorate, in outer-eastern Melbourne, a lot of whom are unemployed, say to me, `You tell us to go on with our education, or do some TAFE training, or go to university, or whatever. What for? Unemployment is so bad that we're not gonna get a damn job anyway.' With the unemployment levels of Aboriginal people, that response and that attitude are even more emphatic.

We have to do things about the employment situation for indigenous people concurrently with classroom education. Otherwise they will say, `What on earth is it for', and we will get a very highly educated but very dissatisfied group in our community. Then in Australia we will start to see some of the civil unrest that we have seen with some of the coloured population in America—from which, mercifully, we have been spared. I think it is something we need to be conscious of and to treat with a great degree of sensitivity.

There is a need to do something for any group that has the sort of economic disadvantage of our indigenous people, but you have to question whether our approaches are working effectively enough. I certainly support the comments of the honourable member for Braddon in terms of the need for achieving more measurement in the outcomes of many of these programs.

I also want to briefly refer to the tertiary sector. It seems to me that more Aboriginal people are going to university. But I really wonder how effective some of that education is and whether the courses are appropriate. I also sometimes wonder whether we are able to harness the people who have been through university to go back to communities and help their own people. Quite often, when they do go back to their own communities there is a gulf and they seem to have lost a lot of that contact.

I remember talking to some of the doctors in the Torres Strait Islands. One of them said, `I went away and got qualifications and some medical experience and then went back to the Torres Strait.' I said, `Isn't it great that you have that rapport?' That person said, `No. It has been broken because I went away. I am no longer, to the same extent, a part of the community.' Those sorts of problems have to be overcome.

Many tertiary qualified indigenous people join the Public Service. There are probably more tertiary qualified Aboriginal people in Canberra than in the rest of the nation. Why should they not join the Public Service? They are individuals, they are Australians, and they are entitled to apply for a job wherever they want. But the reality is that it is not actually achieving an improvement that we seek in the overall standards of the indigenous community.

I would personally like to see us do what has been done in other countries and walks of life. Some scholarships could be tied whereby those who achieve an education return to their community and provide a few years service there. I do not see that as being racially discriminatory. It could apply to doctors, teachers or any other profession in many ways regardless of race. If people are going to be given free education, why can they not be expected to give something back to the community in return?

We then turn to the very vexed subject of whether we should have separate schools for indigenous people. Why not? We have separate schools for religious groups, such as Catholics. There really should be no discrimination in that sense. But there is often a problem with regard to the economic viability of separate schools where there are not large numbers of indigenous people in a particular area. It certainly seems to me that, in many cases, it is an appropriate way to go. I have noticed that quite often where there are essentially Aboriginal schools they very seldom have any objection to taking on the odd non-Aboriginal person who happens to live in the area. But that does not always seem to occur in reverse.

A fundamental point in terms of education, as in so many other areas of indigenous endeavour, is that there has to be much more local and indigenous control over decision making. It seems to me that only with drive and initiative coming out of communities will there start to be some ownership of the problems, issues and solutions. The communities will then start to become much more effective. All too often, the present approach is from the top down rather than from the bottom up, and that is not the best approach that we can take in education, health and so many other areas.

The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) said something about the AEP requiring a commitment by all governments—the federal government and state governments. I certainly support that view.

Before I run out of time, I want to make one other comment. It is perhaps instructive to look at our situation in indigenous affairs with what goes on overseas. In the last few weeks, I have had the benefit of making some overseas visits. In particular, I went to both California and Washington in the United States and to British Columbia and Ottawa in Canada to talk to indigenous people there. I also spoke to both the state governments and, in the Canadian situation, the provincial governments and the national governments in those two countries about a range of indigenous matters, not exclusively the education issue.

I read with interest a couple of days ago an article in a newspaper by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) about the Navaho Indians. I will address that article on a separate occasion, because I do not quite agree with many of the conclusions that he has drawn. But it seems to me that, although the approaches to indigenous affairs in America and Canada are slightly different from ours, there is nevertheless a great degree of commonality of approach in the sorts of ideas that we advocate. One can argue whether they are doing better than us. But I have to say that the outcomes in terms of actual statistics are not much different and that they are as dissatisfied as us.

I say in conclusion that history has served the Aboriginal people poorly in education and in most other areas. We need special measures. I support this legislation as an important step in that direction. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the minister's second reading speech on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1994, to follow my colleagues, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), in this debate and to respond to some of the issues raised by my colleagues on the other side of the House. In relation to some of the opening comments of the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the former shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, one could say that me thinketh that the ex-shadow minister protesteth too much.
—Rubbish! We just don't like to be misrepresented.

—And now we have the shadow parliamentary secretary getting all hairy chested. It is good to see him there for some particular reason. On the issue of the bipartisan approach, while I certainly was not privy to his consultations with the minister, the history of the native title debate in this parliament is that on many occasions the government pleaded with the opposition to participate and get on board.
—And when we tried the Prime Minister said no.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! The honourable member for Aston spoke without interruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one thing to talk about not liking the Native Title Bill, but at the end of the day, right up to the death knock in the Senate, the opposition sat there not able to cope with the internal party divisions. That is the issue. His rousing defence of his successor in the portfolio, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), about how we are trying to drive a wedge between the new shadow minister and her leader is nonsense. I saw on television—and I do not think the camera lied in this instance—the shadow minister throwing her hands up in horror as her leader exited the press conference.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 81 refers to the digression from the subject matter of the debate by the speaker. I understand that we are debating a bill to do with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education in Australia, not the Native Title Bill nor the comments made by the shadow minister on any television debate about the Native Title Bill. I ask you to bring the speaker back to order.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—It is traditional in the second reading speech for there to be a general debate on the issues concerned. I have only just taken my place in the chair. There may have been some remarks earlier. But what I have heard to date seems to be in order and I invite the honourable member to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for a most fair and eloquent ruling. In fact, as the shadow parliamentary secretary will notice, I was simply responding to the opening gambit of the member for Aston.
—You don't have to respond.

—I think the Deputy Speaker is running the House today. I cannot avoid bringing this up because the plummet in the opinion polls goes back to the appalling experience of the new Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory. I quote from an article written by P.P. McGuinness:

SPEECH.PARA: Poor little Alexander Downer, the Leader of the Opposition, has been getting a pretty thorough going over from the officious and politically correct schoolmarms of the media since he made a fool of himself in the Northern Territory on his own party's policy on Aboriginal land rights.
The characterisation that I think will stick is the one of the Leader of the Opposition as `Winnie the Pooh—the bear of very little brain'. The article continues:
For Alexander really is looking and sounding more and more like Winnie-the-Pooh, desperately in need of "a Sustaining Book, such as would help and comfort a Wedged Bear in Great Tightness".

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Capricornia does seem to be straying somewhat from the topic of the bill.
—Do you think I am drawing a long bow, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—I think you are straying somewhat at the present time and I ask you to return to the substance of the bill.

—I raise the analogy because the wood that opposition members are in is indeed the wood of A.A. Milne. The characterisation of the rest of the executive of the opposition—Piglet, Kanga and so on—is so apt that I think they are going to be laughed out at the next election.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) made the point that, if the Liberal opposition fails to deal with the reality of Aboriginal affairs, including the Native Title Bill, and the importance of land rights, which will only be the issue that will empower Aboriginal people, Australians will never vote for the Liberal Party. As the minister said on 27 May:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an anathema to Aboriginal people and to any fair-minded Australians that 27 years after passing of the 1967 Referendum the Coalition continues to be on the public record as being committed to support the repeal of the most important legislation ever enacted under the Aboriginal affairs power, namely the Native Title Act 1993.
The minister continues:

So long as the would-be alternative Liberal Prime Minister of Australia refuses to categorically rule out the repeal of the historic Native Title Act there are hundreds of thousands of Australians who will never vote for them for this reason alone.

That is the issue that members of the Liberal Party are going to have to deal with. Until they deal with the internal dissension in their own party room, they will not be able to deal with more than whining criticism of government policy. There is no doubt, as other speakers have made clear, that this bill and the allocation of moneys will not address the incredible deficit that Aboriginal education faces.

PARA.TAB: In spite of enormous difficulties, the government has been moving to address these significant issues. We should not run away from the enormous problems that we face in responding to the social inequities and injustice for Aboriginal people in this country. It is not an issue of history, as the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) mentioned; it is an issue of government policy 200 years after the invasion.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander unemployment rates at the time of the 1991 census were 2.6 times higher than for other Australians. However, this had improved from 1986 when their unemployment rates were 3.8 times higher. Although they are painfully slow, improvements are being made. Income for indigenous Australians is still about two-thirds of the national average and the unmet demands for housing infrastructure in this country have been estimated to be presently $1.7 billion. Across the country in remote and isolated communities, in regional and coastal communities and in the heart of major metropolitan areas, issues that the honourable member for Aston and his colleagues noted are clear and unambiguous.

Aboriginal people suffer disproportionately from many diseases, including diabetes, circulatory and respiratory disorders and diseases of the eye and the ear. I am glad to see my colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) in the House because he is a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and is very concerned about otitis media—glue ear—which is causing a major health problem for Aboriginal babies and preschoolers and which we believe directly causes educational disadvantage. I call on the government to provide effective funding for research into this very difficult area. At the present time, we do not know what causes this problem, but it is a major health issue which contributes to poor educational outcomes for Aboriginal students.

The death rates for Aboriginals are well known. Aboriginal males can expect to live 18 years less than their white counterparts and Aboriginal females can expect to live 20 years less than their white counterparts. But the area of education is where we see disadvantage in its most obvious form. There remains a wide gap in participation rates in education between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

For example, between 1985 and 1992, the retention rate to year 12 of indigenous people rose from 14 per cent to 25 per cent. At the same time, the retention rate of non-Aboriginal people rose from 58 per cent to 78 per cent. In the 1991 census, one in two Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged between 15 and 19 had left school at 16 years of age or younger, compared with one in four non-indigenous people in this age group.

As has been mentioned by previous speakers, the picture in terms of TAFE enrolments is improving. In higher education, indigenous students made up just over one per cent of the total enrolments in 1993, but made up 1.5 per cent of new enrolments. That is very promising when we note that indigenous Australians make up 1.6 per cent of the overall population. However, it should be noted that the birth rate of Aboriginal people is higher than the birth rate of non-Aboriginal people. We need to respond to an increasing educational demand for this particularly disadvantaged group. As has been said, the proportion of 20- to 24-year-old Aboriginals participating in tertiary education has improved remarkably.

I was delighted at a recent graduation ceremony at the Central Queensland University to see with pride that there were 16 graduates on that day. All of the graduates participated at the Capricornia Aboriginal and Islander Tertiary Education Centre, a specific support centre for the indigenous students at the Central Queensland University. The graduates at the ceremony proudly wore a special item with their academic gowns to nominate that they were CAITEC students. CAITEC currently provides support and assistance for 200 students who are undergoing tertiary education at the Central Queensland University.

I was pleased to have the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), visit my electorate on 28 July. I took him to Lakes Creek Primary School where he met a number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students and resource teacher, Maryanne Sullivan. Her position is funded under the national Aboriginal education policy, regrettably only for five hours per week. She is currently finishing her teaching degree at Central Queensland University. The school also receives $100 per year per child from the ASSPA funding to provide resources and to assist Aboriginal students. This is a very small amount of money and really highlights the myths about the buckets of money which go to Aboriginal students and the apparently unequal access of Aboriginal students to the educational system. It is vitally important that we educate the wider community to understand that the sort of assistance we are giving to Aboriginal students, being meagre at best, is vitally important to address their educational disadvantage. I would call on the government to provide more funding to provide educational opportunities.

The principal at the Lakes Creek school, Yvette Dawson, is encouraging the involvement of Aboriginal parents. She pointed out that that is not an easy thing to achieve. Many of the parents have had very negative educational experiences or very limited educational opportunities and need to be encouraged. This school is participating in providing educational options for mainstream students, non-indigenous students, to have a more effective understanding of Aboriginal culture. We obviously have to do much more of this.

There is no doubt that we have a problem in this area. Teaching graduates are picked up in the wider system of employment opportunities. This often means that trained teachers are lost to the education system. It is vital that we have Aboriginal teachers in positions of responsibility teaching both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal children in our schools so that both Aboriginal students and their non-Aboriginal counterparts learn to respect each other's culture. We have to increase the base from which we are achieving our graduates. We have to make sure that all teaching graduates are encouraged into the teaching system, particularly in remote locations.

On two occasions during the break I was delighted to attend the Dreamtime Cultural Centre in Rockhampton. One was when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) visited Capricornia on 19 July and the other was the official opening of the theatre complex by Lois O'Donoghue, the chairperson of ATSIC. I was delighted to have my family, who had just arrived from overseas, attend that opening. I am delighted to have them sitting in the gallery this afternoon.

The opening of the Dreamtime Cultural Centre was attended by many ATSIC regional councillors and commissioners from all over Australia. Subsequent to the opening they had a full week of meetings. The centre is an example of what can be achieved by effective government funding and by trained young people who are enthusiastic and skilled. Very sophisticated tourism based services are now on the map and international tourists are wanting to come and see the cultural displays and the history of Aboriginal people.

Some weeks earlier, when I had the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Faulkner) in my electorate—I have had so many ministers in my electorate that I wonder why the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has not visited, although I am sure he will as soon as he has time—we happened to pop into the Dreamtime Cultural Centre. While we were there, we met some young Aboriginal students from Woorabinda who were visiting with their school. It was wonderful to see their pride and pleasure in seeing their own history and culture shown to them by young Aboriginal people. This is what empowerment will be about.

In relation to Aboriginal education initiatives, I visited Moranbah High School in a coalmining community in my electorate. I happened to be there during school assembly. During that school assembly, a very small Aboriginal group of students presented a mural to the rest of the school. They had painted that mural as part of an after homework program initiative, another funding initiative of this government. It was great to see how proud they were to be presenting to a mining town which is fairly well monocultural examples of their cultural heritage. These sorts of initiatives which this government has been funding and dealing with, which are once again part of the bill before us today, will make a difference. No-one is underestimating the size and complexity of the problem. I believe we have to put more funding, not less, into this whole area.

I return to the theme of my contribution. While we continue to think that the way to solve injustice and inequality for Aboriginal people is to fix up the problems according to our view of the world—that is, a white Anglo-Celtic view—we will continue to fail. Until we are prepared to acknowledge the importance of Aboriginal people, that real empowerment will come only from real reconciliation based on the reality of the invasion, the dispossession and the subsequent genocide and the need to right those wrongs and the need for a truly bipartisan approach, we will continue to make the sorts of mistakes that have ended up in the sorts of concerns expressed from both sides of the House.

I think this issue is very important, and I call on the opposition to get its own side in order on Aboriginal policy. Opposition members will have to take their policy back to the drawing board because the dissension inside the Liberal Party is quite clear and obvious. It is still pandering to vested interest groups, such as Mr Court in Western Australia. Until the true liberals have the numbers to deal with this issue, I am afraid that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) will continue to plummet in the opinion polls and `Winnie the Pooh' will be the mantle that he will achieve. I do not see Piglet as being much of a successor. I think it is very important for the Liberal Party to get its side in order on Aboriginal education and Aboriginal affairs altogether.

I do not know who will emerge out of this fracas in the opposition, but I certainly hope it is someone with a true commitment to Aboriginal education, because this side of the House is prepared to grapple with this issue. Before I finish, I want to congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on his record of office as the longest serving Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and recognise his excellent contribution following Clyde Holding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell)! She should spend more effort on what she and I are concerned about with Aboriginal people instead of throwing in this red herring about dissent within the Liberal Party. Let us forget about that. If there is such a thing, it is irrelevant to what we are talking about today—the future of Aboriginal Australians.

PARA.TAB: While we can learn from the past, we do not have to live in the past. As I stand here right now, I personally and totally reject the assumption that was made, because I did not invade this country. I did not dispossess anybody. I have never participated in genocide and, quite frankly, I reject that mantle of guilt which the honourable member for Capricornia and her colleagues sometimes try to thrust upon us. I want to go forward into the future in a positive fashion, and I am not going to carry a load of guilt on my shoulders for something that I did not do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The holocaust didn't happen.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! The honourable member will not interject away from his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept, of course, the total history of what happened in the settlement of this country by European settlers—note that I said the settlement of this country; I do not accept the term `invasion' whatsoever. Bad things happened. There is no doubt about that. We have to go forward to the future and make sure that those Aboriginal Australians who are here now and who will be here in the future have every possible advantage that they need and deserve to reach their fulfilment as both Aboriginals and Australians. I accept totally the concept that Aboriginal people have a special spiritual or mystical relationship with the land. I have no difficulty with that whatsoever. I can understand that totally. I feel the same way about this land of ours.
—Your colleagues have a similar type of sentiment.

—I know they do. I think most Australians would probably realise, when they stop and think about it—we are not, as a people, given to getting terribly involved in this—that they feel the same thing about Australia and the land. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and I have travelled around with the same committee visiting many parts of Australia. We cannot escape that feeling of bonding between ourselves as living creatures and the land itself. I understand, as much as a white person can, what the Aboriginal people are saying about their relationship with the land.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Charlton suggested that all Australian governments have agreed that we should work towards overcoming Aboriginal educational disadvantages by the end of this century. That is certainly an admirable ambition. All I can say is, `Don't hold your breath, baby, because we have a long way to go.' I acknowledge what other speakers have said about the improvements that have been made, but we have been starting from a mighty small base.

I come before this House to speak on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill with the proposition that the education provided by all state and territory governments of whatever political persuasion has totally failed the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people because, if we look at the degree of literacy and numeracy problems, we see that they are totally widespread. The honourable member for Charlton pointed out that Charlie Perkins was the first university graduate, and another speaker has said that we now have thousands—I think that was the figure—of Aboriginal people involved in universities. That is great, but it is not enough. I make it plain that education in Australia has failed the Aboriginal people. We can point to the little success stories here and there, but the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, as it went around Australia for many weeks since this parliament started, did not hear many.

In Western Australia, South Australia, the Northern Territory, Tasmania, Queensland—you name it—everywhere we go, we say, `How many Aboriginal kids in year 12?' We ask that question almost religiously. Everywhere we go we are told, `None', or `One', or `Two'. That is not satisfactory. It is good that retention rates are improving, but the overall situation regarding education is not satisfactory. I suppose I can be accused of being dramatic when I say that all our education systems have failed Aboriginal people. I accept the accusation. We need to dramatise the problem that Aboriginal literacy and numeracy skills are very low.

We all know about the numbers of Aboriginal people in gaol and how they are far out of proportion to the numbers of Aboriginals in the general community. In the Northern Territory, Aboriginal people make up 26 or 27 per cent of the total population but they make up 85 per cent of the gaol population. While I do not know the accurate answer, I am willing to bet right now that at least 95 per cent of those 85 per cent of the gaol population are illiterate. Somebody also speaking in this debate, I think on my side of the House, referred to the cycle of Aboriginal society. You have poor housing, and therefore you have poor health, and therefore you have poor education, and therefore you do not get a job and, because you do not get a job, you cannot afford decent housing. That is a pretty good description.

I am convinced that the four things that are of outstanding importance for the development of Aboriginal people are: health, education, housing and employment—not necessarily in that order. As my colleagues on the committee know, as far as I am concerned education is the key. I am not talking purely about the education of children. We have children from several schools in the galleries today. All three of the galleries at the top of the chamber and some of the public galleries have children in them. I am not talking about maths and science alone but about total education to equip people to be effective in society. That cycle we have described is in full acceleration. Unless we do something to put a spike in the wheels, to stop it turning, it will continue.

So far, in spite of the success stories we can point to—and there are some—that acceleration is continuing. The honourable member for Capricornia very rightly said that we need to dispel the myths associated with Aboriginal education. Those myths are there. The difficulty is how you separate the fact from the myth. There is a need for that education to extend beyond the Aboriginal community. Even today, prior to speaking in this debate, I talked to high school teachers and heard that in many of our high schools there is animosity from the European kids, the white kids, regarding the amount of money that Aboriginal kids have to spend in the tuckshop. They have more than the white kids. True or false? I do not know. It is not for me to make a definitive statement, but it is a question that should be asked. Aboriginal kids do appear, according to the myths, to be getting special treatment over and above the other kids in the schools.

I was told of one high school in my electorate where the Aboriginal kids were given a fully expenses paid excursion to Fraser Island. None of the white kids got that. I do not deny that it is a good thing for excursions to Fraser Island, but I do not want to see division within our schools on the basis of race. Surely to heaven we have to walk right away from this. Whether it is myth or fact, we have to get away from the situation where there can be divisiveness on the basis of race. We have to work at this very strongly.

Reference has been made to another one of my hobbyhorses—otitis media, otherwise known as glue ear. This is something that I talk about all the time. I think the member for Capricornia said that the cause of it is not known. This may be true, but the information I have is that two major contributing factors of otitis media in young children are nutrition and hygiene and the incidence of smoking and alcohol in their mothers. We have to look at these factors when considering my definition of education, which goes beyond maths, science, English and so on.

In Australia there is a high incidence of otitis media. A classic example is in my own electorate in the Macleay Valley where something like 94 per cent of the kids between the ages of three and six suffer from this disease. This is absolutely appalling. However, the good thing is that the Durri Aboriginal Medical Service has an audiometrist and a specialised hearing facility that can test and find out whether the children are deaf. Until we find out whether the kids are deaf or not, there is not much we can do about it. This is a significant indicator.

Due to their hearing impairment, the language development and socialisation of these kids is about three years behind other kids who do not suffer from the disease. They start school and are three years behind in language development. We have to take into account—not necessarily in Macleay but other parts of Australia—that English is the second language for Aboriginal children. Assuming that English is their first language and they start school, if they have not developed to the same stage as other kids and they cannot hear, they are not going to be able to learn.

Children thrust into the situation of attending school with a hearing impairment cannot learn and are therefore seen as pretty dumb. They are not dumb. The Aboriginal children that we as a committee have seen in schools around Australia are bright and intelligent and have the potential to do as well as any other Australian. We have to look at the environment in which they are growing up. When we go to places like the Pitjantjatjara lands, Yalata in South Australia and many others, it is heartbreaking.

I know former Senator Graham Richardson had a revelation on the road to Damascus or Darwin. I can understand why that happened. I am certainly not here to attack the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), Graham Richardson or anybody else. I think it is a pity that the member for Capricornia had to divert and start playing politics. I think the cause of Aboriginal education should go way beyond politics. That is absolutely vital. If I were to become political, I could say to my friends on the other side of the house—but I would not do that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on.

—I could say that all these wonderful things are happening, but I could say that they have been in government for 11 years, they have spent an absolute fortune doing it and they have got nowhere. But that is not going to profit us.
—You are not going to say it.

—I am not going to say that; that would not profit the debate at all. That would not be helpful to our fellow Australians of Aboriginal descent. I want to say with all the passion that I can command that the future of Australia depends on Australians working together for the cause of Australia. We do not want to be divided. We do not want apartheid in this country. That has been and gone.

PARA.TAB: I was very interested to hear over the weekend that somebody who is regarded as a professional ethnic in the multicultural industry has finally said what I have been saying for some years: what we should be pursuing, praising and lauding in Australia is our cultural diversity. I approve of that totally. I believe very strongly that Australia should not be divided.

I know that this is not the time to get into a multicultural debate, but ever since I have been in this place I have attacked the concept of multiculturalism as such. We need cultural diversity within Australian society—not segregation, ghettos or different groups all over the place. We will become an even greater country if we can work together. That is one of the things that we must do.

The honourable member for Capricornia said that the government was moving to address the issues of social inequity and injustice for Aboriginal Australians. It is true that there is social inequity and injustice. We need a thoroughly bipartisan approach in order to solve those particular problems.

I reiterate the point that health, education, housing and employment are the vital issues. I will not get involved in the land acquisition fund or Mabo. Let us accept that and take that for granted. Quite apart from the relationship with the land, the vital issues are health, education, housing and employment.

As has been said, there is great difficulty in trying to inculcate Aboriginal cultural standards or values in mainstream education. However, if Aboriginal people are to succeed within and become a part of the Australian society, as I think the vast majority want to be, while still retaining their separate cultural identity—and so they should, just as other groups that have come to Australia have every right to maintain their cultural identity within the overall social mainstream of Australia—it will depend on education. This education has to be beyond the curriculum of the primary schools and the high schools. It has to be education in the community.

First and foremost, we have to inform the parents or the adults of the value of education. The great bulk of the Aboriginal people living in Australia today have been part of that cycle. In very many cases, they do not appreciate the value of education. Therefore, we need to provide educational facilities to the Aboriginal communities and the widespread community of Australia.

We have spoken briefly about myths. An enormous amount of money has been spent on Aboriginal affairs. Everywhere the standing committee has gone, we have been asked by Aboriginal workers, individuals and organisations where the money has gone. There are justified complaints that the money is not getting down to the grassroots.

Education in Australia has failed the Aboriginal people of Australia. The money has not got through. Therefore, as a society, a nation and a culture, we should not just provide money; we should point it in the right direction so that it gets there and so that Aboriginal people can really fulfil their destiny as Australians. Other Australians can take pride in what Aboriginal Australians are doing, secure in the knowledge that the money is being well spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join this debate on Aboriginal education by first of all dealing with the point on which my colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) finished—that the money does not get through. It is inevitable when we are dealing with Aboriginal issues that the criticism immediately flows from the opposition that we have been here for 11 years, have spent all this money and have got nowhere.

PARA.TAB: Let me say this to the honourable gentleman: one of the problems we have is that the gentlemen opposite are firm believers on every occasion of the concept of states rights. The Commonwealth provides the funding, but the administration of the program is left to the states. If you want to know why there is a disparity within states and between states in the quality of education and housing—in some areas of Australia the quality of housing is good and in other areas it is totally inadequate for Aboriginal people—it is because the administration of those programs on the ground is left to the states.

Are we really advancing Aboriginal housing? If we give funds to the states, they send in a building contractor to build one or two houses which for the most part are plonked into the community without any input from or discussion with that community. In many cases this housing is totally inadequate or totally inappropriate for that community. When the contractor goes away there are no skills left in that community to repair electrical faults or other faults that may arise. So, if we are going to share blame, it should be shared equally.

One of the great tragedies facing Australian people when we talk about reconciliation is that unfortunately Her Majesty's opposition has yet to get its exercise, its principles and its policies clear. The greatest disadvantage that Aboriginal people face on the issue of reconciliation is the total confusion and abnegation of political and social responsibility from members of the opposition. They cannot have it both ways. I can only wish the shadow minister well.

I do not have to remind members of the opposition, members of this parliament or, indeed, the Australian public that the Leader of the Opposition's sojourn, his first basic exposure to the problems of Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal society, was a totally disastrous failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order under standing order 81. The bill we are debating is the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill and I do not believe that the trips of the Leader of the Opposition are in any way relevant to the debate. I ask you to call the member to order.

—The honourable member for Melbourne Ports is debating the bill before the House. Earlier today when I was sitting in on the debate, the course of that debate ranged fairly wide. But I remind the honourable member that the bill relates to Aboriginal education.

—One of the presumptions made within this House is that education and the philosophy of education in many cases involves our treating Aboriginal people on the basis that if they would only be like us—abandon their culture, abandon their tradition—then all would be well. Honourable gentlemen should walk through the bush with a group of Aboriginal children under 12 and ask themselves who is educated. It is a very important experience.

PARA.TAB: If there are these problems that bedevil education it is because basically in many states of Australia the view is that, if only Aboriginal people would be like us and accept our values and our concepts, there would be no problem. You cannot separate educational policies from the philosophy, the tradition and the culture of a people that has been subject to a holocaust for over 200 years. That is the social and economic reality. In the course of this government not one single item of legislation brought forward to benefit Aboriginal people has not been opposed by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—Mr Speaker, I table the question time roster for this week.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. I remind the Treasurer that before the last federal budget the Governor of the Reserve Bank and many other economic commentators urged the government to accelerate the reduction of the budget deficit. Since the government did not take that advice, does the Treasurer now acknowledge that the cost of the government's irresponsible budget is now being paid for by small businesses and home borrowers in the form of higher interest rates? If you do not accept this, why did the Reserve Bank urge you to lower the budget deficit?

—After the budget the Governor of the Reserve Bank expressed his satisfaction with the budget, so there is nothing about the budget policy which is contrary to the views of the Reserve Bank about appropriate fiscal policy at this time. So to that extent the question is wrongly based.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that monetary policy has a role to play in keeping inflation down, along with fiscal policy. We have a fiscal policy which involves a reduction in the budget deficit of a considerable order over the next few years. It is a deficit reduction program which stands up pretty well compared with those of other countries which have announced deficit reduction targets—none of them having a target of less than one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. We expect to be below that point and, therefore, to have a thoroughly credible fiscal policy and one which is appropriate to our economic circumstances.

That said, it is also important that monetary policy is not kept in some frozen state. In the course of an economic cycle, one does not want to have more interest rate increases than are required but that does not mean that we therefore try to keep them in some frozen state for as long as possible. Pursuing that course would most likely mean that at some stage or other we would be forced into quite substantial increases and most likely have larger increases in official interest rates than would be the case if moving in an appropriate way.

Clearly, in terms of the market response, there being an increase in official rates at this time, in order to ensure that we do not have an outbreak of inflation and we keep our inflation in that range of two to three per cent, which the Reserve Bank has said is appropriate and with which we agree, we have seen that the official rate increase of 0.75 per cent has not led to an increase in long-term rates. Indeed, long-term rates have fallen. The 10-year bond rate today is about 20 points less than it was at the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Basis points.

—It is 20 basis points less than it was on the day before we increased official interest rates. So we see that bond rates have come down. The same is true for shorter bonds. That is quite important for investment. Investment costs will be largely determined by bond rates, not by bank lending rates—although obviously they are not irrelevant; they are important for businesses with overdrafts. To that extent, as business overdraft rates go up, they would be affected. In terms of raising funds for investment through long-term loans, the bond rates obviously are very important. Those bond rates have come down. So there can be no assumption that there is some sort of adverse effect on business investment overall as a result of this action.

PARA.TAB: It is just simply untrue to argue, as the Leader of the Opposition does, that if we had a lower budget deficit at this time we would have been able to avoid some increase in interest rates. New Zealand perhaps bears up the point. In New Zealand, there has been a move to a budget surplus with considerably higher taxes as a percentage of GDP than we have. That has given it a budget surplus at this stage. With that budget surplus, however, its official interest rates have gone up, not 0.75 per cent but 2.75 per cent. It is simply a non sequitur to argue that if we had a tighter budget deficit there would therefore be no need to adjust interest rates. In New Zealand, with a budget surplus, there has been a much sharper movement in interest rates than here.

Clearly, monetary policy has to be utilised. The opposition wants to argue that we should never use monetary policy. It would indeed make for a unique position on the part of a potential government in this country for it to say, `If we get into government, we will never increase interest rates and monetary policy would never be used.' It would be simply laughed out of court by the markets and anyone who knows anything about economics as a totally unreal position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. At the recent COAG meeting, did the states demand a fixed percentage of Commonwealth revenues? What was the Commonwealth's response? Why?
—It is the case that at the recent COAG meeting in Darwin last Friday—
—It was a waste of a day.
—No, it was not a waste of a day.
—The premiers said that it was.

—The Premier of South Australia thought that it was a waste of a day. His attendance was a waste, but the day was not a waste. This meeting was a follow-on to the meeting in February in Hobart, where the states and the federal government looked at the desirability of implementing the Hilmer report. It very much affects the states in terms of the need to open up their government enterprises to competition, to allow federal law to apply in respect of unincorporated enterprises which are not covered by the Trade Practices Act and to allow the Trade Practices Act to apply to state trading enterprises. The states are very much involved in this. What we were doing in Darwin was taking it to the next step.

PARA.TAB: Before we could get on to that agenda in Darwin, we were hit with a demand by the Liberal premiers, who sought to use this occasion to put maximum leverage on the Commonwealth to extract some new funding arrangement. It was led by the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett. It was put that all future revenue growth for the Commonwealth should be split fifty-fifty with the states. If that were to happen, they would be prepared to go on and discuss the benefits of implementing the Hilmer report and perhaps be involved in it.

The federal government's attitude to that has been that we flatly oppose that concept. It was not on the agenda. It was never a part of the process that there should be some discussion of revenue sharing in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in 1990-91.

—It was not in 1991. It was never agreed at that time. A 50 per cent share of revenue, even if one were predisposed to have a share, is just an outrageous demand. At the present time, financial assistance grants to the states cover 15 per cent of our tax revenue. Yet they wanted a 50 per cent share of all future growth in our revenues. They have amazing cheek. It is an outrageous demand.

PARA.TAB: In any case, the issue of a fixed formula has many problems. Any fixed revenue sharing formula would probably only apply, as far as the states are concerned, to the good times. What they see, looking out in the years ahead—these figures are contained in the national fiscal outlook—is a very strong projection of government revenues feeding off continued high economic growth. They think, `Fair enough. We would like a big share of that.'

But they ignore that in the recent past we had a period, with the recession and low growth, where Commonwealth revenues actually fell. Would they want a share of that? Did they ask for a share of our reduced revenues? Of course not. Would they in the future if such an occasion arose again? Of course not. They would want to maintain their real payments, which was what they were given in the last recession and its aftermath. They were protected through that period. They did not have to share in the fall of the Commonwealth revenues, so they were thoroughly protected.

If they had had a fixed share through that period they would have received $2.3 billion less than they in fact received, because they were protected by this same real level of financial assistance grant arrangement. We did that even though the states had a faster growth of revenue through that recession period than we did. The states' revenues were not affected in the way ours were. The states in fact had real growth through 1989-90 to 1993-94 in their tax revenue of 17.5 per cent, and the federal tax revenue fell in real terms by 3.7 per cent. So there was a total disjunction between what happened to the states in the recession and what happened to us but, despite the fact our revenue fell in real terms, we maintained the real value of their grants even though their revenue continued to grow quite rapidly.

Current arrangements are clearly quite reasonable; they protect the states in the bad times. With the change that we made at the last Premiers Conference, which was to give them not just the same real but the same real per capita, we gave them a 1 1/4 per cent real growth factor built in. We did that partly on the expectation that they would be cooperative in relation to the Hilmer reforms. They have now a guaranteed share of growth in the future as well as protection in the bad times, and the current arrangements are therefore highly appropriate.

Nevertheless, the government did offer instead to enhance current arrangements by sharing revenues from the Hilmer reforms to which the states have contributed. This means that if the federal government gets additional growth over what it otherwise would have had as a result of the Hilmer reforms being implemented, and one would expect that to be the case, it is prepared to look at sharing any disproportionate revenue growth it gets because the states will get some improvement in their revenue from higher growth anyway. Of course, we have to get around to implementing the reforms first.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is 12 minutes into the first question time of this robust spring session and we have had just two questions and answers. I put it to you that on 9 May this year you gave an admonition to ministers with regard to the length of their answers. I invite you to extend that admonition on this occasion.

—Order! I think the Leader of the National Party has in fact raised a valid issue. I would counsel those on my right on the front bench in responding to questions from both sides. The Treasurer in conclusion.

—I will be finished in a moment, Mr Speaker. This is a very important issue. This means that we are prepared to be reasonable to the states and share any disproportionate increase in the revenue. We will get the Industry Commission to analyse that issue, and will report on it at the next conference in Adelaide in February.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand that the states have to come on board before there can be any additional revenue to share. It is a matter of the states trying to put the cart before the horse—particularly the Liberal states, which ganged up on a federal government on a political basis on this occasion to do that. The Leader of the Opposition undoubtedly supported their doing that. He says that he supports giving them a fixed share. For all the reasons that I have given, that would be an absurd thing to do but if he wants to pursue absurd policies I guess that would not be unusual because he has a lot of other absurd policies as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer stand by the statement in the Senate this afternoon of Senator Evans, the putative member for Lalor, who said that the government does not foresee the rise in official rates flowing through to home lending? If you do, and your policy is to dampen home lending, does that mean you will be looking at further rises in official rates that will flow through to home lending to enable your policy to be accomplished?
—What has been said by me and, although I did not hear what Senator Evans said, I assume by Senator Evans—
—So the Treasurer can answer the question, I seek to table a transcript of what Senator Evans said.
—Leave is not granted.
—Leave is not granted by the Leader of the House.
—What has been said by me, the Prime Minister and I assume by Senator Evans is that—
—You have had an hour to get the transcript.
—Order! The Treasurer has the call.
—Has Senator Evans asked you any questions?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition.
—Does he want your seat?
—No, not mine.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer might resume his seat for a moment. When the House comes to order, the Treasurer will have the call.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition is not setting a very good example.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither is the Leader of the House.

—The Prime Minister and I have said on several occasions since the announcement on interest rates last Wednesday that we think it quite possible and indeed likely that the full amount of the official interest rate increase of three-quarters of one per cent will not flow through to bank mortgage rates.

PARA.TAB: I assume that that is what Senator Evans was getting at and I thoroughly support it. There are various pressures on the banks. The area of housing loans has been highly competitive and we would expect that in those circumstances the banks would be rather cautious about moving quickly to pass on the full amount of the increase. Various factors will be operating on banks and making them decide what to do about that, including what happens to their deposit rates. Banks have to make their own decisions about increases in their deposit rates. Of course, some of the funding costs that they incur are set in the marketplace anyway, and some of those costs have increased. The degree to which they have increased will vary from bank to bank. There is no clarity about the cost pressures that each bank will have to wear in terms of passing on those additional costs to bank mortgage rates.

The likely outcome is that banks will not pass on the full amount. Of course, in so far as they seek to pass on any percentage increase, it is then not at all clear what that will actually mean for mortgage holders because, as interest rates have come down, many people with mortgages have chosen to maintain their payments at the rate that they were before, so they are paying well in excess of the minimum rate required by their bank. Even with an increase in interest rates, it is quite possible that they will continue to be able to pay the same amount and still be paying well above the minimum rate that they would be required to pay by the bank on the particular loan. That very important factor is operating.

There is also the capacity for banks to extend loans rather than to increase the payments, so there are all sorts of possible outcomes. The most likely outcome is that less than the full three-quarters of one per cent will be passed on. It is even more difficult to ascertain the actual impact on the monthly repayments by mortgage holders, but it will not mean any increase at all for many of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the minister inform the House of the implications of employment growth for job seekers and, in particular, the long-term unemployed?

—I thank the honourable member for Port Adelaide for his question. Despite the good news that came through in the last fortnight on employment growth, the fact still is that unemployment remains unacceptably high and, accordingly, the most important social and economic issue still confronting this government is getting it down. However, the recent figures confirm that we are making substantial inroads into this task. The 90,000 growth in employment in the last month has seen the total number of jobs created since this government was re-elected to office 15 months ago grow by 376,000. When we went to the election we said that we would create 500,000 jobs, so we are 75 per cent on the way to the target in 40 per cent of the time.

PARA.TAB: The recent job growth has brought the unemployment rate down to 9 1/2 per cent, despite the fact that the participation rate went up. The unemployment rate is down from the peak of 11.2 per cent. The employment growth itself has been broad based. All states are experiencing it; it is applying more to full-time jobs than it is to part-time jobs; and males and females are equal beneficiaries of the growth.

Concerning the long-term unemployed that the honourable member asked about, I would remind the House of the commitment that the Prime Minister made upon re-election. That was that, with this economic recovery that we were going to preside over, we were not going to let the long-term unemployed be left behind. As a stark reminder, the House should be aware that from 1983 to 1989 when this government presided over that economic recovery, having been left in the mess by those that sit on the opposition benches, we created 1.6 million jobs, but only 109,000 of them went to the long-term unemployed.

I am pleased to be able to say that the new ABS figures to be published later this month in Labour Force Australia will show that the number of long-term unemployed for this month has declined again. They will show that the number of long-term unemployed has dropped to 290,200. That is a 14,000 drop over the previous month and takes the figure to a total drop of 76,000 in the 15 months since we were re-elected. Compare those figures with the figures for the period 1983-89 when only 109,000 long-term unemployed were picked up. Of the 376,000 jobs created in the past 15 months, 76,000 have gone to the long-term unemployed.

This government has learnt the lesson of the 1980s: job growth alone will not solve the problem for the long-term unemployed. There need to be targeted measures to address their particular needs. The white paper builds on the initiatives that were introduced by my predecessor in targeting jobstart subsidies to the long-term unemployed. That is the reason why we are getting the drop this time, whereas we could not effect it so significantly in the period 1983-89. In addition to those targeted measures that have been built upon in the white paper, we are not only increasing the subsidies but also developing a job compact that guarantees a job to all those who have been unemployed for 18 months or longer, as well as case management to ensure that we can deal with their specific problems. We have also recognised that the thrust of the white paper has to be about ensuring that we secure sustainable economic growth in a low inflation environment. That is why the initiatives that go to skill formation and encouragement in the area of training will help the economic agenda.

This is a package of measures that gets the policy right, both on the social front and on the economic front, and I would hope that those on the other side of the House would get behind applauding the good news on employment rather than try to run it down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his statement on the Sunday program describing changed capital adequacy ratios for home lending as more likely to affect first home buyers `struggling to get a deposit'. Why is it government policy to introduce regressive changes to hit the poor hardest and to especially penalise first home buyers?

—Housing has hardly ever been as affordable as it is at present. The Commonwealth Bank index of housing affordability was at record levels at the beginning of this year. It has moved down just slightly since then, and an increase in interest rates will obviously change that a little further, but it will still be very high by historical standards. So let us start off from the point that we have very affordable housing at present. That is a function of various factors, including rising real household disposable incomes; low interest rates; and housing prices, which have been contained in recent times.

PARA.TAB: The decision by the Reserve Bank to change the risk weighting for housing where there was a high loan to valuation ratio of over 80 per cent was taken because of the concern the bank had that there were very high rates of housing lending, increasing by over 20 per cent per annum over the last couple of years. There seemed to be a substantial number of loans being given at the very high end of those ratios, around the 90 to 95 per cent mark. Obviously, that is at the more risky end of business. The higher the loan as a proportion of the valuation of the home, the more chance there is that the person will find it difficult to service that loan with variations in their income or variations in interest rates. In those circumstances, it was thought appropriate by the Reserve Bank to change the prudential requirements.

At present the prudential requirements give very substantial concessions to housing. Instead of having to have $1 of capital behind $1 of loan in terms of the capital adequacy ratio—which is currently eight per cent minimum—when calculating that eight per cent minimum capital adequacy ratio, they are able to discount housing loans by 50 per cent. That is a very concessional approach. The bank believes that, in the circumstances where there is this recourse to risky lending, it is appropriate to change the risk weighting ratios at that level. This is not unknown for other countries. Various European countries have done this, including Germany.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!

—It is not a stupid argument; it is seen as quite commonsense in other countries. It is not likely to have any marked impact on housing lending overall because a relatively small proportion of loans are in that over-80 per cent mark. At present the capital adequacy ratio of the banks is around 12 per cent, whereas the minimum requirement is eight, so they have a lot of latitude. If they wish, they can make loans at that higher level over 80 per cent. There is no prohibition on their continuing to make loans at higher loan to valuation ratios than 80 per cent. However, if they do that, in terms of calculating their capital adequacy ratio for the purposes of meeting the eight per cent minimum, there will be no 50 per cent discount on such loans from 5 September.

PARA.TAB: Given that the capital adequacy ratio is now 12 per cent as against the requirement of eight per cent, there is a lot of fat to be used up. It is up to the banks to decide whether they want to proceed with loans of that sort or not. Their response to it is that `we will have to wait and see'. Its effect is obviously going to be quite minimal on the overall growth of housing, which has been growing very, very strongly indeed.

Until recently we have had a growth in the number of new housing units financed per month of around 50,000, whereas the peak in the 1980s was around 35,000. So we have had a very strong growth of housing. We expect still to have a strong growth in housing, but it will taper down from this exceptionally high level reached in recent times. That will not cause devastation to the housing market or to the ambitions of potential home buyers. It simply will mean that there will be some slight reduction in housing effort as a result of both the prudential change and the increase in interest rates. But we are still looking at very high levels of housing activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has the minister seen evidence of recent successes flowing from the government's policy of support for Australian arts and film? Can he advise of those successes and of alternative proposals for influencing Australia's cultural development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Feature films that have been produced recently in Australia are certainly doing very well. Their commercial performance has been as positive as some of the critical assessments of the values of those particular films. They are finding a very favourable reception with audiences both at home and abroad. The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert recently opened in the United States. It is a film which I am sure is very popular with a few members of the opposition. It opened in the US on 10 August and is drawing full houses. Its American distributor, Gramercy, rates the film as a hit. Priscilla is already playing in seven cinemas throughout the United States, in San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Seattle. As its success improves, I am sure that it will get a wider release across the US. I am sure that the opposition will be very pleased when it is released in Perth.

PARA.TAB: In the five days since its opening in the US, Priscilla has grossed more than $300,000. That is a cinema average of $42,000, which the distributor, I am sure, thinks is excellent. When we compare that with the No. 1 top grossing film in the US at the moment, A Clear and Present Danger, we find that it is currently grossing only about $2,500 for each cinema screening. So Priscilla, the Australian film, is grossing $42,000 per screen and the No. 1 film in the US at the moment is only grossing $2,500. That is certainly a very good sign.

A few members of the opposition were interjecting about Sirens. In the United Kingdom on 29 July Sirens premiered with outstanding results and as of 7 August it has grossed over #1.3 million. It was the No. 1 film in the first weekend in August in Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen it yet.
—The Leader of the Opposition may not have seen it, but we were overwhelmed with Liberal and National Party members keen to attend the advance screening at Parliament House.
—I have seen it.

—I have known for a long time that the member for Gippsland has been a keen appreciator of Australian films and we were keen to see him at the Sirens premiere in the front row. The Sum of Us is another Australian film which is doing well starring two of Australia's best actors Jack Thompson and Russell Crowe. It is proving very popular with Australian local audiences, which is something even the honourable member for Ballarat would welcome, I would hope.

PARA.TAB: A few people opposite might not think that film is a genuine industry, but it is certainly one that generates a lot of jobs here at home. It is generating a lot of export earnings, and it is important for Australian culture that we can hear Australian voices and see Australian actors up on screen. Tonight we will see an advance screening of Muriel's Wedding, a film that has received 11 AFI nominations. I would encourage all members to see it over the next two nights when it is being shown.

All of these films have been backed by the Film Finance Corporation. The fact that they are doing so well internationally and at home demonstrates the strength of the government's support for our film agencies. It is interesting to contrast that with the views of the Leader of the Opposition, who in the past has argued for the scrapping of the Australian Film Commission and the Film Finance Corporation. If he had been successful, these films would not have received the assistance that they are now receiving.

The opposition tells us that it is going to give us some new initiatives and we are waiting to hear what they might say about the arts. At the moment the only indication we have is that the Leader of the Opposition thinks it would be a good thing for Australian school children to be taught popular Italian operas. I am sure that will be a central feature of the opposition's arts policy. It is interesting just to contrast some of the views expressed by different members over time. In a recent newspaper column on 3 July, the Leader of the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is clearly an abuse of question time. You have already cautioned ministers today. This minister should be told to sit down.

—Order! I again draw all ministers' attention to the assistance that they will give the House and its smooth operation by limiting the time of their responses. The minister, however, I am sure is coming to the end of his response. I invite him to do so.
—The last point I would make is that we should look at what the Leader of the Opposition said on 3 July in a column—
—He is going straight on with it.
—Order!
—This is the Leader of the Opposition setting out his view on the great principle of arms-length funding. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a role for government in art funding, including at the federal level, the Australia Council, but that funding should be at arms length.
That was the view of the Leader of the Opposition on 3 July this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —So?
—The Leader of the Opposition says, `So?'

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a simple point of order. Mr Speaker, you have a discretion. You have exercised the discretion. You have invited the minister to wind up and he is now flagrantly abusing your invitation to wind up his answer.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is winding up, and I would invite him not to respond to interjections which seem to lengthen the answer.
—I thank you for your protection. I contrast that recent statement of the Leader of the Opposition regarding in-principle support for arm's length funding with what he said in the past:

ANSWER.PARA: Labor has hidden behind the false and intellectually dishonest facade of arm's length funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —When? When was this?

—So what is your view? Do you support the principle, or is it an intellectually dishonest facade? The Leader of the Opposition has been caught out on his views on Aboriginal land rights funding, on citizen initiated referenda and now it is arm's length funding. He cannot go around advocating contradictory views and not get caught out.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that over the past 10 years this Labor government has poured $160 million of taxpayers' money into Australian National Line?
