Is it also a fact that over the past two years ANL has actually lost $290 million in value and that for years the government has known about these problems and done nothing to address them? Is the minister further aware that the Labor ministers and Labor premiers responsible for similar financial debacles, such as the State Bank of South Australia, WA Inc. and the Victorian State Bank, all lost their jobs? Who will accept responsibility for the ANL disaster—the minister or his predecessor?

—Let me at the outset confirm that $160.5 million was injected into ANL either in debt forgiveness or in grants, but let me also confirm when it was injected. It was injected in two applications, in 1983 and 1985. And why? I will tell you why. Because ANL, when the Hawke government was elected, was utterly bankrupt. That is why $160.5 million was injected into ANL.
—Order! The minister might resume his seat. The House will come to order. I remind those on my left of the provisions of standing order 55.

—The fact is that every penny of that injection was to repair the damage that Liberal and National Party governments had done to ANL. Having said that, it is not as if the world has stood still since. This government has been responsible for pursuing the shipping industry reform process, a reform process that you neglected absolutely in your time. So let me say to the Leader of the Opposition that the answer to the first part of his question is yes, the sum was $160.5 million, but it was money injected to help ANL over its problems. The second part of the question was: can we confirm the order of losses of $290 million over the last two years? That is absolutely false. There is no validity in that at all. Let me confirm the figures.
—Why are your hands shaking?
—Oh, wake up to yourself, will you. Are you still here?
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong.

—Talk about Casper! Wake up to yourself. Let me confirm that in 1992 Potter Warburg and Price Waterhouse indicated a very wide range of values for the company of between $127.4 million negative through to $170.9 million positive. That was the span of values that that report indicated might be placed on ANL.

PARA.TAB: I also report to the House that, in the due diligence study I released yesterday, the range of values given by Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers is between $74.8 million negative and $117.8 million negative. Let me, in the interests of accuracy, state that those figures, from the two independent valuations that are available, do not in any way prove the assertion made by the Leader of the Opposition in the second part of his question that there has been a deterioration of $290 million in the value of ANL over the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are the figures that—
—Order! This is not a debating point. I call the minister.

—The state of ANL is one that should properly concern everyone in this House. The opposition's repeated parroting of its proposition that it should be 100 per cent privatised—and that is the only thing you have contributed to this debate in the last 12 months—is equally stupid, along with everything else that has been said.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is—

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just quieten down for a while.
—Order! I have already cautioned the Leader of the Opposition.
—The Leader of the Opposition invited me to come into this chamber this afternoon—
—And accept responsibility.
—Excuse me, just listen to the answer, will you—and blame someone for this result. He wants me to blame either the board or my predecessor. He wants me to blame anyone at all.

PARA.TAB: Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Moore.

—Let me make it very clear. As I said yesterday, I am not into blame; I am into responsibility. It has been responsibility that has motivated the government in everything it has done to bring this position to the point yesterday where we unveiled the rescue plan. In terms of responsibility, rather than waiting for a sale process and then a due diligence study to be carried out, it was this government that decided, on my recommendation, jointly made with the Minister for Finance on 21 February this year, that due diligence—

PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Sturt.

—should be carried out and those results should be made available. We received that report in its final form last Saturday. Already it has been made public. Already action has been taken to save ANL; already action has been taken to repair those elements of the business that can be made commercially viable; and action has been taken to protect the taxpayers' interest. That is not blame; that is responsibility. It will be responsibility that you will see in our continued approach to the restructure of ANL. This idea that you could race out, as the opposition would have us believe, and sell it at a time when it has got a net negative worth—
—What annual budget have you got?
—Listen.
—Order! The minister might resume his seat for a moment.
—Put him in a lifeboat.
—If the minister continues to respond to interjections which are disorderly, he prolongs his answer. I invite him to now bring his answer to a conclusion.
—In view of the continued interjections, I am quite happy to continue this debate in the matter of public importance that has been listed on this very subject.
—Could the Minister for Resources advise the House what the prospects are for the sale of Australian coal in overseas markets and, in particular, in the Asian markets?

—At the outset, I wish to offer my condolences and I am sure the condolences of all members of this House to the friends and family of the mineworkers who were killed working underground in the BHP mine at Moura.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my sad duty to represent the government at the memorial service, and the opposition was represented by the honourable member for Gippsland. It always reminds us of how difficult and dangerous this occupation is, despite the debate over its future.

PARA.TAB: In the recess, I had the opportunity to talk to some of Australia's major clients in the Australian coal industry. I am particularly pleased with the prospects for this industry. When I was in Japan, I talked to a number of major Japanese utilities and all the Japanese steel mills.

Whilst the future prospects for coking coal are quite slack, there is an opportunity for further sales in markets such as China. Of course, the opposite is the case for steaming coal. Japanese utilities expect to double the demand for steaming coal towards the end of this decade. That will provide an excellent opportunity for the Australian coal industry to take a large share of that market. We will need to maintain our competitiveness and our international reputation as a reliable supplier of coal for thermal power generation.

I hope that I was able to give some important messages to the Japanese utilities. At the moment, there is a surplus of coal in world markets. That will not last long, particularly as growth in the Asian region takes off. At the moment, not only in Australia but in other parts of the coalmining supply industry, such as South Africa, Canada and the United States, there is a lack of investment in coal infrastructure.

The message that I tried to get across to the Japanese utilities was that, whilst there is an opportunity for them to reap a substantial bonus by cheaper coal prices because of the market oversupply, there is an opportunity to take a strategic view of this industry. It is my strong belief that this industry has the potential to double in the next 10 years. It is already Australia's largest export industry, at $7 1/2 billion, and I think the industry has the potential to double. But it will mean that Australia has to maintain its international competitiveness.

I note with some interest that a campaign which is currently being run has engaged a number of leading Australian rugby league players as champions of the coal industry. I welcome that participation. If Mal Meninga can do for the coal industry what he did for rugby league, I think we have a winner on our hands.

I stress very strongly that there is an important message for all of us about the way we treat this particular industry. Unless we—that is, government, the Australian coal unions and the Australian coal suppliers—work as a united industry, I do not think this industry will reach its full potential. I am very confident that the report into the Australian coal industry to be brought down in October or early November by Rae Taylor will give us an extremely good outlook for the industry and that it will point the way forward. I am hoping that particular report will be a circuit breaker. I hope it will break down the attitude of us and them, which I think still exists in that industry. I hope that we can all work together to make this Australia's truly great industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In 1992, ANL was valued at about $290 million. Last year, the chairman of ANL reported a profit of $9 million before tax and minority interests, which after the sale of assets was a turnaround from a $19 million loss the previous year. Yesterday the minister said that `he could not give ANL away'. When did the minister become aware of the gravity of the financial situation of ANL and what action did he take? Will the minister accept the responsibility for this massive loss of taxpayers' money?

—I wish to add to the points made by the Minister for Transport in previous answers. We put in place the due diligence process to find out exactly what the situation was with respect to the finances of ANL. It was a perfectly sensible thing to do.
—Order! That is not a signal for further interjections.

—As the minister said, we found out what its financial situation was when it was reported last weekend. That was when we received advice from the financial advisers associated with it as to what ANL's position was. At that point in time, there were discussions amongst ministers and officials. We put in place the process that was announced yesterday by the Minister for Transport.

PARA.TAB: I might say, in explaining the situation of ANL, that when we found it in the situation that it was in when we came to office, which was a situation of bankruptcy, we put a capital injection into it. The board then went through the process of substantially restructuring the company. In the process of that restructuring, it went down from about 33 ships, most of which were unsuitable for its trade, to about 14 or a dozen. It also acquired additional ships which it hoped—and it was receiving private advice as well as just simply operating off its own bat—would return it to a regular stream of profitability.

Almost immediately after that it was hit by the recession and the optimistic projections of the board were, of course, not realised. In addition very substantial changes took place in most of the areas in which its trading activities were conducted and substantial competitors emerged. All the best projections of the board came, in effect, to naught. We sought to find out exactly what the position was before we went through any process of privatisation associated with it. We went through a sensible process of due diligence. It provided us with accurate information and we acted upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can he advise the House whether the competition policy reforms recommended by Professor Hilmer will still be introduced quickly? How does the government respond to the claims in today's Australian Financial Review that the Commonwealth has been selfish in its relationship with the states—that while the states have given a great deal to the Commonwealth in Commonwealth-state areas the Commonwealth has given them little in return?

—I thank the honourable member for Melbourne for his question. I can assure the House that the Federal government remains committed to the introduction of a national competition policy on 1 July 1995—in fact, the COAG communique from Darwin reaffirms that date—because we are not prepared to deprive Australians of the enormous benefits that competition will bring in terms of lower prices and sustainable jobs. Any attempts to delay the introduction of the national competition policy or to water down the main recommendations can only be at the expense of ordinary Australians and can only serve vested interests.

PARA.TAB: The detail of the policy will be settled in February of next year, but prior to that date—in fact in a few weeks time—I will be releasing for public comment draft legislation and intergovernmental agreements. The draft legislation will deal with extending the Trade Practices Act across all areas of the economy, mainly to do with state government businesses and the professions. The intergovernmental agreements will deal with areas where the Trade Practices Act does not reach, such as access and pricing regimes. The states remain committed to the general principles of Hilmer and we are determined to address their concerns over the next six months.

In response to the second part of the question, I have seen the claims in today's Australian Financial Review that the Commonwealth has derailed the process by continuing to give nothing to the states while they have given up everything. All I can say is that that is absolute rubbish. I notice at the bottom of the article that Mr Sturgess, the author of the article, is described as an adviser to state governments. If that is the sort of advice he is giving to state governments, I hope he has nothing to do with the Hilmer report. Let me give a few examples where he is wrong.

Firstly, the Commonwealth government untied $700 million in road funds as the states asked. In return, the states promised to pass legislation to establish a national regime for regulating and registering road transport. That was three years ago; it still has not happened. We also agreed to take over the interstate rail freight system, which was costing the states around $350 million a year. Not only did we relieve them of that debt but we have also put around $1 billion into the system and are currently spending around $1 million a day on roads. In addition, as the Treasurer has indicated, we agreed with the states and gave them certainty in their financial planning by maintaining financial assistance grants at their same real per capita level until 1996-97.

In addition to that we have given the states more than a billion dollars to establish the Australian National Training Authority—a whole new area of funding and one which will skill up Australians. That is not a bad record arising out of the COAG process. So we have given significant concessions to the states over the past six months in addition to all of those proposed to Hilmer. In fact, we have gone a fair way to addressing the states' concerns arising out of the Hilmer report. That has been recognised by the officials of the states, who understand the benefits that will flow not only to their states but to Australia once the Hilmer reforms are implemented.

We now have six months to make sure that the premiers, who are fairly long on the rhetoric of supporting Hilmer but were very short on the detail up in Darwin, get across the detail of the policy. We will be instituting a national competition policy next July. The states themselves have six months to get across the details of the policy and sign up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. What shipping industry expertise is held by the new chairman of the Australian National Line, your old mate Neville Wran? Will the minister guarantee the House that neither Neville Wran nor his sidekick on the board, Malcolm Turnbull, will be permitted any role in a future sale of ANL, given the potential conflict of interests connected with their banking activities? Will the minister accept full responsibility for these new and farcical arrangements?
—I think we are quite fortunate to have a person of the calibre of Neville Wran to serve in this capacity.
—Do you really?
—Yes, I do—absolutely; and so should you.

PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—I believe that he and his colleagues on the newly reconstructed board—Malcolm Turnbull, Paul Merner, and John Spark of Ferrier Hodgson—will bring all the requisite skills necessary to give this company its best chance of reconstruction. I believe that they are very well placed to employ the best expertise to assist them in that task. It is a very big challenge indeed.

PARA.TAB: Let me indicate to the House the terms of their appointment. They have been appointed to serve for a period of six months to get this company into some sort of shape; to report to the government on all of the steps that are necessary to give it its best chance; to make recommendations to make viable anything that can be made viable; and, as Neville Wran said, to deal with those parts that are chronic losers. At this stage I do not expect that Mr Wran and Mr Turnbull are likely to be involved after that initial period of six months. If they are, the honourable member and the House can rest assured that I will be more than willing to let them know the state of play as it develops.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can he advise the House of the tax arrangements the government has set down for the anticipated NRMA share float? What are the advantages to NRMA members of that tax treatment?

—The NRMA share float is quite a unique occasion. It involves the demutualisation of an organisation with 1.8 million members and the distribution to them of shares or cash in a manner determined by the board of NRMA to be commensurate with each member's interest in the organisation. It means that all members will be offered a free allocation of about $500 worth of shares, another $500 if they also hold an NRMA insurance policy, and an extra amount if they are long-term members.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important development in the economy. The demutualisation of such a large organisation means a major change in share ownership. An issue that arose in those circumstances was the tax treatment which would apply to the issue of the shares or cash, if the members preferred to have cash. The issue that needed to be decided was the way in which capital gains tax would apply to the allocation of shares and cash.

The circumstance that existed was that under current tax law the tax office was likely to set the capital gains tax cost base, from which any accruals in value would occur as the taxable element, at zero or at $36, which was the joining fee for members of the NRMA. Therefore, a very large proportion of the allocation to members would have been subject to capital gains tax—not at the point of receipt of the shares but when the shares were sold or the cash was received.

The government decided that this was something that should be encouraged, that the process of demutualisation is a good thing. It applies not only in cases like the NRMA's; it will also be important in other areas, such as various insurance companies. We wanted to establish something which would be an encouragement to demutualisation. We certainly did not want the tax system providing a barrier to the demutualisation, which may well have been the case had there been no attempt by the government to change what would otherwise have been the application of the tax law.

Therefore, the government, in discussions with the NRMA, decided on an appropriate arrangement, which involved the cost base for the shares being set by reference to the net tangible assets of the NRMA group. The same cost base, for capital gains tax purposes, will be applied to those members who choose to take cash instead of the shares. The net tangible assets cost base will not be calculated until the date of demutualisation, which is in a couple of months. But the NRMA has estimated that it will represent a tax free transfer of capital to members of about $1.5 billion.

Consistent with the tax treatment provided to previous demutualisation proposals, all franking account balances as at the date of the NRMA's demutualisation would have been cancelled. The NRMA had various franking credits through various dividends from investments. They were not utilisable as a mutual body because it did not pay dividends. But, once it became a company with dividend payments, it wished to use the franking credits to pay franked dividends.

We believed that, consistent with a previous policy for demutualisation proposals, which did not go ahead, there should be a cancelling of those credits. But, given the NRMA's expressed strong desire to retain sufficient franking credits so that it would have a capacity to pay some franked dividends, we provided it with the scope to do that in a way which is revenue neutral to the Commonwealth. That involves an amount of franking credits which the NRMA wishes to retain. It has been left to it to determine the amount.

But the capital gains tax cost base of the net tangible assets will be reduced by $1.50 for every $1 of franking account balances retained. According to the Taxation Office, that will give us, as best as can be assessed, a revenue neutral outcome, in terms of the original proposition—the capital gains tax base net—being tangible assets and there being a complete cancellation of franking credits.

I believe that the arrived-at determination which allows this capacity for franking credits to be utilised in a revenue neutral way does give the NRMA a very good basis upon which to go ahead with the demutualisation. It is a major step forward for the Australian economy. It means not only that a lot of people in New South Wales will become shareholders—I hope that those who get the shares will in large part retain them and not just cash them in; we certainly expect to see a substantial boost to share ownership in New South Wales as a result of this development—but also that it has set a precedent for future demutualisations in other areas, which we will also do our best to encourage in a similar way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister for Transport. The new chairman of ANL, Nifty Wran, said on the ABC's AM program this morning that he is not interested in determining what went wrong with ANL in the past—a past that has seen Australian taxpayers lose $290 million in ANL's value over the past two years. Will the minister initiate an investigation into this cover-up to determine just why Australian taxpayers are left with a failed government business enterprise with a net value of minus $117 million? When will the government accept responsibility for this fiasco?

—I have indicated to the House that I accept full responsibility and I intend to fix up the situation. I am pleased to have joining me in that task the Hon. Neville Wran and his colleagues who have been appointed to the board. I have already dealt with this furphy of a suggested loss of $290 million over the last two years.
—How have you?

—Quite frankly, the performance this year was no different from the performance last year, the year before or the year before that in terms of average losses. Indeed, the steps that the government has taken are aimed at protecting the taxpayers' interest in making sure that this business is restructured and trades its way out of difficulties so there is no loss to the taxpayer. It is for that purpose, with that in mind, that the government has embarked upon what I think is a very ambitious and constructive approach of making ANL work and guarantee its profitability in the future.

PARA.TAB: We are not about blaming anyone for the past. It is the easiest thing in the world to come in here and bag the board, the auditors or someone else. I am mindful of the fact that ANL deserves to be given a big chance, and we are committed to giving it that chance and will be constructive in our approach.

I think this chamber is well aware of the circumstances of the international shipping business these past three years. I think this House is aware that there has been no more cutthroat area of competition in any area of trade anywhere in the world than shipping. I think this House is aware of the fact that Australia with ANL is a tiny niche player in this great international competitive market. I think this House is aware that international shipping has been subjected to chronic depression as a result of the world recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the level of crewing?

—I think this House should also be aware of the fact that ANL, seeing as someone on the opposition benches mentioned crewing, has been in the forefront of reducing crewing sizes—I might say, with the support of the Maritime Union of Australia—down to the position where its crew sizes are the same as those of its OECD competitors.

PARA.TAB: Equally it is true that the House is aware of the fact that the Chinese government and the Russian government are using their shipping lines, which are several times the size of ANL, as foreign currency earners. All of this—the recession, the depression of the shipping market, the enormous competition through displaced large ships on the European route coming down and putting our ships out of business—has led to a situation where ANL has continued to lose money.

But that is the past. We own up to it and say, `Let's go forward from here.' The reconstruction proposal that I put to cabinet yesterday, which was agreed to and endorsed by the party room, is the way forward for Australian shipping. There is a viable opportunity there. It is going to be a very different ANL but we are intent on making the reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Will he advise the House of the benefits flowing to consumers from Australia Post's improved financial performance and of what response there has been to these achievements both at home and overseas?

—On behalf of the government I would like to congratulate Australia Post for its decision to freeze the cost of sending a standard letter at 45c until 1997. This will bring to five years the period for which the cost of posting a standard letter will have been set at 45c, and that is an outstanding performance by the staff and management of Australia Post. It means that since Australia Post was corporatised in 1990 there has been a 12 per cent real decline in the cost of sending a standard letter.

PARA.TAB: It is not just in price that Australia Post has been performing well. If you look at service standards, productivity, and many of the different ways you can measure Australia Post's performance, the management and staff of Australia Post have done very well by working as a team.

It has introduced modern letter sorting technology. In 1992-93 alone it raised labour productivity by five per cent. In the three months to June this year, Australia Post was delivering 94 per cent of letters on time or early, and that is a great achievement by any measure.

When Australia Post announced that it was freezing the cost of a standard letter at 45c for a total period of five years, which provides benefits to all users of the postal service, what response did we get from the shadow minister for communications and the arts? Silence. Even though he hands out press releases like confetti, he had nothing to say about the fact that Australia Post has been able to keep down its price for a standard letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is it?

—It is Senator Alston. But he was not able to bring himself to put out a press release on this, even though it provides great benefits to the users of the postal service. Since the opposition always seems to look to the mother country for guidance, it is interesting to compare this performance with what is happening in Britain. The conservative government in that country is looking at options that will break up British Post and privatise the royal mail, yet it is at this very time that British Post is looking for some guidance and advice from Australia Post on how it has been able to get management and staff to work together to implement these reforms and to improve the performance of an organisation without the massive industrial turmoil that members on the other side are trying to engender.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Earlier this year the House established the Main Committee of this House of Representatives and, subsequently, the room formerly known as committee room 2R3 became the second chamber of this House. While I totally support every avenue being made available for the education of children about parliamentary democracy, is it intended that the second chamber of this House be used as a schoolroom for students, as happened during question time this day?

—The Parliamentary Education Office has become so popular, and I think would have the support of all members of this place, that we have taken a decision that, because of the demand on present resources, alternative sources in which to talk to school children coming to Parliament House be explored. In that respect, given that the Main Committee—the second chamber—is in use for only a period of the parliamentary sitting time, and given that it has a configuration as a chamber, it was considered that it would be a perfect opportunity to use as a resource. As a result, permission has been given to the Parliamentary Education Office to use it for that purpose. It will not, of course, be used at a time which would inconvenience its main purpose. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The incompetence of the Government's handling of ANL which has resulted in the taxpayers of Australia losing $290m in the value of ANL in the last two years.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing that we are reminded of by yesterday's statement by the Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). We are reminded of the old saying—we on this side of the House know it only too well—that you cannot trust Labor with other people's money. If there were ever a need to remind the people of Australia of that, there is a need to do so now. If people ever doubt the veracity of that old saying, they should not only look at what the Minister for Transport announced yesterday, they should also remind themselves of the failing of Labor in government right around Australia over the last few years—failures such as the State Bank of South Australia, WA Inc., the State Bank of Victoria, to name just a few major economic disasters that Labor in government has sat in charge of over the last few years.

PARA.TAB: In this building at 4.30 p.m. yesterday afternoon the Minister for Transport announced yet another one of those disasters, another one of Labor's economic black holes through which it has poured a great deal of taxpayers' money and through which it is going to have to pour a great deal more taxpayers' money in order to correct the problem—if indeed the problem can be corrected. I heard the minister during question time today doubt the credibility of the claim as to the extent of the loss that has been incurred by taxpayers as a result of the failings of this government's management of ANL over the last few years.

The minister knows only too well, if we compare the two valuations of ANL—Potter Warburg's valuation was around $200 million, and yesterday's valuation by Salomon Bros and Price Waterhouse was minus $117 million dollars—we can quickly see that the Australian taxpayers have borne a very serious loss. The reason for that is that ANL today carries a debt of $180 million. It has been carrying operating losses each and every year, averaging around $30 million over the last two years. That is a very severe loss—one which should cause this government a great deal of pain, just as other Labor governments around Australia have been caused a great deal of pain by being confronted with major government business enterprise disasters.

It is interesting to ask the question: who is to blame for this problem? The Minister for Transport, who is at the table, said earlier today in the House, `We are not in the business of placing blame.' I will tell honourable members the reason why he is not in the business of placing blame. If he pointed the finger of blame at somebody, it would end up being pointed here—at the Minister for Transport and at the government of Australia.

If honourable members do not want to take my word for that, take the word of people who are traditional Labor Party supporters, those who are united with this government in the cause of keeping Labor in government—the trade union movement. I was interested to hear the deputy national secretary of the Maritime Union of Australia, Mr Paddy Crumlin, speaking in a debate last night on ABC radio. I can quote Paddy Crumlin from today's Daily Commercial News. For anybody who is not a real buff on the subject of transport, the Daily Commercial News is the industry's daily newspaper. Paddy Crumlin said that ANL has been put in a weak commercial position due to the government's handling of its future.

SPEECH.PARA: Where do we start to point the finger of blame? At the government, as he pointed out. The DCN of 19 August states:

PARA.TAB: MUA joint deputy national secretary Paddy Crumlin said yesterday the government's mishandling of the privatisation process had caused serious commercial damage to ANL.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members do not take Paddy Crumlin's word or my word about who is to blame for all of this, let us look at a letter from the ANL board to Minister Brereton earlier this year. The letter was reported in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 30 May 1994. It states:

PARA.TAB: The letter from ANL to Mr Brereton claims the value of the company's trade shares (or goodwill) has diminished significantly because of the way its partial privatisation is being handled.

SPEECH.PARA: Handled by whom? The government. It further states:
Overall, the letter to Mr Brereton gives details of nine broad areas where the board of ANL perceives the actions of the task force—
that is, the government's task force—
and the sale process in general have led to operational difficulties and value erosion.

If honourable members do not take my word or Paddy Crumlin's word, they can take the word of the board of the ANL in that private letter leaked to the Financial Review earlier this year. The reason the government is not in the business of laying blame, as the minister pointed out earlier today, is that the blame lies with the government.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members might ask themselves why Neville Wran is the chairman of this new ANL board? There are four people on the board: Neville Wran, old mate Nifty; Malcolm Turnbull, who is not exactly divorced from the interests of Neville Wran and some of his friends; a public servant from Canberra; and a person involved in restructuring companies. Why? It is a good question. If we start to think about it, we get the answer. The government can trust Neville Wran. Why can it trust Neville Wran, and why does it need to trust him? The minister and this government know that, if they cannot have a board that they can trust and control, they will be blamed for the fiasco of ANL and for all of the money lost by ANL's operations over the last few years.

That is the reason why Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull are part of that board. They are certainly not there because they have any expertise in transport or in shipping. I doubt very much whether Neville Wran knows anything about shipping. I doubt whether he would know much about anything regarding transport. Certainly, the only contribution that I can think of that Malcolm Turnbull will make to the management and restructuring of ANL will be to try to change its name to Australian Republican Line rather than Australian National Line. These are interesting questions to ask. Why do these people, with no previous track record of involvement in the transport industry, get to be on the board of ANL? The simple reason is that the government can trust them. They are the government's mates. Members of the government know that they will not do the dirty on them because, if somebody that they cannot control is running that board, the fickle finger of blame will be pointed at the government.

Why was that dramatic announcement made yesterday? We only have to go through the newspapers over the last few weeks to find the answer. This minister knew that his attempt to privatise ANL was becoming a major political embarrassment to the government. That is the reason. He knew that in September, when the ALP conference is to be held, he would cop a hiding on the floor of the conference. He did not have the numbers at the ALP conference to get the privatisation process through. The minister will say, `The reason I did what I did yesterday was that all of a sudden I became aware of the problems of ANL, and I had to act quickly. It had nothing to do with the political furore around the privatisation process and the ALP's national conference.'

I can assure the minister, as many people on this side of the House are aware, that the problems of ANL did not suddenly arise in the last few months. Anybody who goes through its financial targets over the last few years will discover that it has been a long way off the mark. For example, ANL missed its financial targets by $61 million in 1991, by $105 million in 1991-92, by $26.3 million in 1992-93 and by $45 million in 1993-94. ANL has been trading badly for a long time. The reason for this big announcement yesterday was not that it was suddenly discovered that ANL was in difficulty—everybody knew it—it was that ANL had become an embarrassment to the Labor government in the lead-up to the forthcoming conference of the ALP to be held next month. Those are some of the reasons why we saw this take place yesterday.

I have to ask: is there not a little favouritism here, a bit of looking after our mates in all of this? What business do Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull engage in? We found out in question time today that Malcolm Turnbull and Neville Wran run a merchant banking business. Malcolm Turnbull happened to be a handsomely employed consultant to ANL before the decision was made to make him a director yesterday. What is going on here? Could there be a little pecuniary interest in all of this? The minister assured us in question time today that that is not going to be so. Let us see whether the minister will give us an absolute ironclad assurance that Malcolm Turnbull and Neville Wran will not derive any financial gain from the sale of ANL through their merchant banking activities in the future. I think that would satisfy a lot of people.

The other question that should be asked of the minister is: how much remuneration are Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull getting for their role on the board? Will Malcolm Turnbull continue to be employed as a consultant as well as receiving his director's fees? These are all questions which have arisen in the last 24 hours since we discovered the make-up of the new board. It is also important for us to understand that, in the statement the minister made yesterday, he indicated that he felt it was possible to bring—as he has said today in question time—ANL back into trading in the black, to restructure it and to get it going well.

That is an interesting claim, because in the process of making his comments yesterday it was suggested that, in order to achieve that, much of the overseas operations of ANL would have to be axed. If that is the case, then ANL is going to be pared back to basically a domestic shipping operator plus an operator across the trans-Tasman between Australia and New Zealand. If that is the future ANL holds, then its future is totally dependent upon the maintenance of cabotage, which is the banning of foreign competition around the Australian coastal line. It is also dependent on the trans-Tasman accord—the illegal union to union trans-Tasman accord—that bans foreign competition between Australia and New Zealand in the shipping industry.

If ANL is to have any value in the future, it depends upon government largess to protect it from competition. These are questions which we can rightly put to the government and which the minister can answer in a few moments. If ANL's survival depends on those things, it is going to be at a very heavy cost to the Australian people. As the Business Council of Australia estimated some years ago, the existence of the illegal trans-Tasman accord, arranged between the unions in Australia and New Zealand, cost this country around $110 million a year. So there will be a further heavy price for the maintenance of ANL's operations. As the Salomon Brothers, Price Waterhouse report said yesterday, the likelihood of the $160.5 million being the last of the capital contributions this government will put into ANL is very low. The report pointed out that it may take a further $200 million to get ANL successfully operating in the black.

The minister now has an opportunity to point out to us what he is going to do to try to fix up the problems of ANL and to answer the questions that have been rightly put to him today. I look forward to the answers from him. If he cannot provide those answers, then I come back to where we started in this debate and say that we cannot trust Labor with other people's money. The problems of ANL, under the administration of this minister, his predecessors and his government, highlight to us how incompetent Labor is in running government business enterprises and protecting the interests of Australians, whether they be ANL employees or taxpayers around this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing that one cannot help but be struck by in the matter of public importance brought on this afternoon by the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), is its absolute and utter superficiality. This is the shadow minister and this is the party which have put out press release after press release for the last 18 months about ANL. They must have had something in their diary where every month a date bobbed up and they whacked out another press release about ANL.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what the press releases say. They say only one thing and they have only ever said one thing: privatise ANL, sell 100 per cent of it. That was the case at the start of last year, at the end of last year and at the end of last week. The federal honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) said that ANL should have a similar place in shipping to the position that Qantas has as an international air carrier. Just imagine that as an argument for its 100 per cent privatisation, knowing what we know now about its finances. Later on it was said, `Only 100 per cent privatisation will see ANL shake itself free of government and union control,' and, `One hundred per cent privatisation will solve all the problems.' Again with the honourable member for Hume in February of last year it was the same old story:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has said all along that only a 100 per cent sale of ANL makes sense. That is what the coalition will do and what the Keating government should commit itself to doing.

In the following month again we were told to sell 100 per cent of ANL, and again the following month, every month. Month in and month out we have been told to sell 100 per cent of ANL. It is like a revolving door. But there has never been any analysis of the real state of ANL. There has never been any insight from the opposition into exactly what state ANL is in and what should be done about that state other than this blind allegiance to the idea of selling off 100 per cent of it. It has been the same this year right throughout the due diligence process.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Hume has come to this chamber this afternoon and spoken to us again about 100 per cent privatisation and what a dreadful state ANL is in. He has quoted a couple of examples to back up his case. He has quoted the union movement and Patrick Crumlin, who is a terrific union official and a great believer in both the Labor Party and ANL. But for the honourable member for Hume to be relying upon Paddy Crumlin to make out his case is pretty thin, just as it is thin to be relying upon no greater journal than the Daily Commercial News. At yesterday's press conference the only paper that was not represented in Australia was the Daily Commercial News. They missed the day. The honourable member should not come here quoting the Daily Commercial News of today as any authority for any proposition because they were the one lot who were not there yesterday to find out what was going on.

Similarly, the honourable member quoted the board. He spoke of the letter leaked to the Australian Financial Review of 30 May 1994, saying that the value of ANL's goodwill was going downhill. Nothing has been helping the value of ANL's goodwill but no-one can claim that there has been any real deterioration in the last six months while the government did what had to be done, and that was conduct the due diligence so we had outside expert advice as to the affairs of ANL. It is a matter of fact that after the Potter Warburg report of last year there was a great deal of contesting of the figures which it provided to the government and which have subsequently been made public. Those figures saw the company valued at a range of values from a positive value to a negative value. ANL itself said it was in really good shape. It liked the positive scenario. The opposition take the positive scenario then and the most negative scenario now, take the difference between them and say that $290 million has been lost. That is a fanciful notion that would not stack up in anybody's sets of accounts.

The reality is that the board of ANL continuously advised the government that it was in pretty good shape. Indeed, the Chairman of ANL, in his press release as late as December 1993, spoke of the fact that there had been a real financial turnaround in the company in its latest figures, despite depressed world trading conditions. He said that ANL's results contrasted sharply with other international shipping lines which have reported poor and disastrous performances during the period. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: ANL's turnaround underlines the strength of the management strategy and the innate soundness of the business that constitute the newly reconstructed ANL.
He completed his press release on 16 December last by saying:

ANL's sound financial position is reflected in its strengthened balance sheet characterised by the enhanced prudential ratios such as gearing which moved from 130 per cent in 1991-92 to 107 per cent in 1993.

That was at the end of December. It was backed up by the management of the company, who on 10 February said that they had a very good bottom line and that we could expect solid profits in the years to come. They hoped that ANL could obtain a profit of $10 million in the next financial year and targeted tripling that within the succeeding three years. That was what the company was telling us.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the auditor was auditing the accounts of the GBE; they are matters of record in this parliament. But ANL's real position is only reflected in the results of the due diligence. Within 11 days of the company giving that optimistic forecast I had recommended to the cabinet that due diligence precede any decision on the sale because I wanted the expert advice of independent consultants to give me a real picture of ANL. I got that advice last Saturday. It is no good the honourable member coming into the chamber today saying that the only reason we are doing any of this is that we realised that we did not have the numbers for ALP conferences. I made no bones about it—you could not privatise ANL at the moment; you could not give it away. It has a net negative worth, on the best advice that is available. This is not a matter of numbers, it is not a matter of ALP conferences; it is a matter of making sound decisions about the future of this company.

That consultants report, Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers, indicated that the prudential balances are not as the company had indicated and the gearing at 160 per cent is unacceptable. We have to do something about it. We are doing something about it. But we also have to accept that we are doing something about it understanding the state of ANL and where it sits in the greater scheme of things. It is going to be extraordinarily difficult in the ultra-competitive international trade area for ANL to be truly profitable, but I believe there is an opportunity with niche marketing to do that. However it will depend upon the ability of the union movement and the ability of the management of ANL and the support of ANL's customers in redefining the role of that company and adapting itself to its new and changed circumstances.

There is no point in having ANL compete head to head with either the Russian companies or the Chinese companies in this marketplace. They have more ships, they have more tonnage, and they are a country mile ahead. But there is an opportunity with niche marketing, as I said yesterday, if we regard ourselves as a spoke rather than a hub in our own right, to have a viable business. I sincerely hope so. It is for that reason that we have appointed this new board. The honourable member for Hume would have us believe that this is the old mates act. I put it to him that we are very fortunate to have people who can make a contribution in these circumstances, and who can give independent expert advice. I believe this is a very good group of people to be tendering that advice in the circumstances of the next six months.

I have already said today that I do not anticipate that their appointment will last for more than that. They will be renumerated for six months. He has asked me about that and I am pleased to be able to indicate that the Remuneration Tribunal has independently determined—that is the same Remuneration Tribunal that determines our salaries—a rate of $42,000 per annum plus $130,000 in respect of the chairman and rates of $25,000 per annum plus $108,000 in respect of the other two members. There is provision in the event of further duties, that is, on subsidiary companies, for an additional fee of up to $30,000 for one of those appointments. Those commercial fees have been set not by the government but by the Remuneration Tribunal. Quite frankly, if these people on that money having a huge input over the next six months can save this business it will be a terrific result.

The honourable member suggested that Turnbull and Partners may in some way be associated with the sale of ANL. I am not proceeding with any proposition that would see ANL sold at this stage. We have to repair ANL and make it a profitable operation. We have to redefine its activities. Only then can we think about exactly where it should fit into the scheme of things. I would see there being a number of years of ANL repairing its balance sheet and getting back into a position of real profitability and paying off its debt.

I will conclude by making a couple of points. The support of the trade union movement is going to be terribly important in the restructure of ANL. I am pleased to advise the House that the ACTU has conveyed to me the terms of its attitude towards ANL in the following advice which I have received in the last 24 hours. The advice states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in consultation with the maritime unions strongly believes:
1. ANL should be maintained and re-established as a viable economic enterprise operating under the Australian National Flag with full Australian crews under national maritime award conditions.
2. The ALP policy should not be an impediment to achieving that objective, provided there is consultation and agreement between the Government, ACTU and maritime unions.
3. The Government should consider a number of changes that will give the industry the opportunity to operate viably in a competitive world environment.
4. The Shipping Industry Reform Authority should continue as the main industry forum.

I think that resolution of the ACTU indicates the goodwill of the trade union movement towards the rescue package that the government is launching. We will certainly need that goodwill if we are to get the right result at the end of the day. I believe it is a task worth tackling. I believe that this is a fundamentally important responsibility for government.

PARA.TAB: I have spent the last seven months setting in place the due diligence, getting the results of the due diligence and proposing a rescue package. Whether this rescue plan can succeed or not will depend upon the cooperation of all parties. Only if ANL can be made viable has it got a future. That is a fundamental issue that everyone has to understand. I believe that if we work constructively over the course of the next six months we can rescue this business, we can transform it, we can build it around those elements that are viable or can be made viable and we can deal with those chronic loss leaders that have caused the company so much grief in the course of the last several years.

No-one will be able to say that this government does not accept full and absolute responsibility for pursuing the interests of the taxpayers and the interests of ANL and a presence in Australian shipping in the process we have embarked upon. It is a very different process to that advocated ad nauseam by the opposition over the last couple of years. The opposition has not analysed the future of ANL in any way, shape or form and it has demonstrated no depth in its dealings with ANL. It has simply repeated again and again, parrot fashion, month in and month out, that we should sell 100 per cent of the company, whilst all the time there was growing evidence that ANL was not a saleable proposition at all considering the state of the world economic recession and the shipping industry depression. I am proud of the fact that I am part of a government that did the due diligence, established the facts and is now absolutely committed to the future of ANL and sorting out its difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a rather remarkable speech by the Minister for Tourism (Mr Brereton), who was trying to defend the indefensible. I have never before heard a minister in this House get up and say that he takes full responsibility for what has happened when in normal circumstances he would resign. That is the minister's responsibility. The minister cannot stand up in here and say that the taxpayers have done $290 million and he accepts responsibility—
—You would know all about resignations.

—I had more honesty than you did. The master of Sydney connections tried to be the man who succeeded Wran but they blackballed him so he came down here and he is now Keating's master of connections. He is the man with all the connections; he knows where to find them all. I am surprised the minister is in transport. He ought to be in communications because that is where the lurks are.

PARA.TAB: Who appointed the board of ANL? The Labor government—every one of them. According to the minister this afternoon, this board turned around and lied to the government. The consequence of the letter the minister quoted from is that ANL lied to the government about its position. Who was the consultant to the board who lied to the government? The minister admitted this afternoon that it was Turnbull.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; he was appointed only last week.

—Nevertheless, he was a consultant to the board that lied to the government. The government has now turned around and appointed the partner of Turnbull as the chairman of this new company to try to get it out of the ditch. This is a most remarkable string of events. I have never seen an attempt like this to cover up a situation in which a board lies to the government. Quite clearly the auditors who signed off the accounts of the ANL ought to be called to account and the Auditor-General ought to be invited to investigate the affairs of the ANL and report to parliament, not the government.

PARA.TAB: We need to consider what happened in relation to the report to government in December 1993. According to the minister this afternoon, within 11 days he got due diligence under way. Six months later due diligence resulted in a report that ANL was broke. I find it quite extraordinary that those events could come out, especially when, according to the minister this afternoon, the board said that it was proposing to have a profit of $10 million for this financial year and some multiple of that over the next three years. That is grossly misleading by the minister, as the proprietor of the organisation.

If that happened in public companies today the minister would sue them. They would be down the slammer. I am quite surprised that some action like this has not been taken. Instead, what has the minister done? He has said there will be no blame. He said he will take the blame.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one is responsible.

—No-one is responsible. A member sitting on the government backbench who could not run a sandwich shop got the chop. The minister cannot run a $290 million business and nothing is done about it. It is an absolute scandal of double standards.

PARA.TAB: This situation prompts me to look around Australia and see what is going on. We all know about the typical way Labor mismanages financial affairs. We see it everywhere we go. Victoria is still paying extra taxes. We should start with Cain because he started these wonderful things. The Queensland Premier said when he first became Premier that he wanted to do for Queensland what Cain had done for Victoria. He is on the road.

Honourable members should remember what happened in South Australia when another state bank went down. The Premier of the day was in exactly the same position as the minister. He said that he did not know what was going on. All the dogs in Adelaide were telling him that the bank was broke the same way as all the dogs were telling this minister that the board of ANL was lying and that it was completely opposed to the government's policies. It said so in its last annual report.

We can then go to Western Australia where there is another stark example of Labor Party mismanagement. Even a former Premier of that state is in gaol and another bank is down the drain. This is sheer incompetence.

I turn to the situation in New South Wales. We remember the circumstances in which Wran left the premiership. We were aware of the nasty smells around then, and this is the beginning of the smells in Canberra. As a consequence of that, we should be concerned about the whole micro-economic reform package that this government is attempting to undertake.

Earlier in the year, the OECD in its report made some very scathing comments about the way in which economic reform has been carried out in this nation. Productivity levels in the public sector are about 30 per cent below achievable international best practice. There is also criticism of the way state government organisations perform in relation to the production of electricity, water and the like.

The OECD report also criticises the labour market. In Australia, no real attempt has been made to challenge the monopoly practices that occur in the labour market. The report also refers to communications. It notes that, in this country which vitally depends on communications, communications will be kept in a monopolistic stance in a total sense until 1997. All of these factors show a total lack of ability of the Labor government to take on the issues.

Last weekend, the state premiers were together in Darwin. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could not make up his mind whether or not he would open up the building and, at the last minute, he passed the job off to the Governor-General. However, he dropped in right at the death knock to make a big fella of himself. At this meeting, he wanted to have his way. In the end, no agreement was reached between the states in relation to this matter. If we are to get agreement with the states on any matter of major concern—and the Hilmer proposals which were under discussion are vital to Australia—it must be approached in a cooperative and reasonable way. Labor cannot do this. It is confrontationist and arrogant. It believes that it is right and everyone else is wrong. I am afraid that this process will continue until we get a change in the federal government. We must have Hilmer reforms from the Trade Practices Commission right through to the labour markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get the Liberal premiers to support them?

—Because even the honourable member's mate is not too keen on it. I do not suppose that the honourable member would really understand. I am concerned that, if the nation does not change the government in the near future, more instances of what has happened to the ANL will come about. A large number of public corporations have not cut the mustard in recent history. Millions of dollars have been spent on Qantas, but there is a still a question mark as to how it will perform.

PARA.TAB: The government very belatedly undertook a privatisation process. We produced a detailed program on privatisation in 1988. We were told that it was outrageous and could not be done. In two years, this government had undertaken much of that program and had put it into the budget to buy today's lunch. Our program always said that the money must be spent on retiring debt or investing in national infrastructure. It is in these ways that this government is flaunting the future of Australia.

The privatisation process undertaken by this government has almost ground to a halt because of the way in which it has handled the Commonwealth Bank. In the first instance, the price was remarkably under-pitched. But it was taken up enthusiastically by the public. At the second tranche, the government went on a book building exercise which nobody could understand. The general public has no idea of the concept of putting in a price, bidding for it and, if an amount is not reached, reducing the price. As a consequence, the government killed the Commonwealth Bank share market.

What happened to the TAB float in Victoria was not so much as a consequence of its political aspirations. People got the wrong view about privatisation. The government cannot privatise public assets without giving the people a go. They must know what they are buying and at what price. If the government had set a fixed price rather than pursuing the open market tender operation, I believe that that float would have got away quite easily. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate demonstrates a fundamental difference between the government and the opposition. It demonstrates a lack of substance on the opposite side of the House. It also demonstrates a lack of any alternative plan or policy position on ANL or anything else. For the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) to come into this House and talk about management expertise is laughable.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Ryan was recently elevated to the frontbench, along with Senator Parer. They replaced Senator MacGibbon and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). That was sold in the press as a massive increase in Queensland representation in the cabinet. What we have heard today is proof that more means less.

The opposition has a complete lack of substance and a complete lack of policy alternative. For the honourable member for Ryan to talk about the lack of achievement of this government in restructuring this country and this economy is the height of hypocrisy. This country is 30 per cent more competitive than it was a decade ago. It is experiencing record rates of economic growth, a low inflation rate and a low inflationary culture. It is also experiencing record job growth. All of those things have occurred as a result of the fundamental capacity of the Labor Party to take the hard decisions, to take the long-term view and to change the economy into a more open, export orientated economy which is competitive in the world, which exports more and imports less.

From listening to the analysis today from the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), who is rarely seen in this House, and the honourable member for Ryan, one can see that there is no policy alternative at all. They have demonstrated in this House today the problem which goes to the very core of the Liberal Party: it is suffering a profound policy crisis. It is a policy-free zone. It is that profound policy crisis which continues to lead to its persistent leadership crisis. The Liberal Party does not have any social or economic vision for this country and it does not have any hard policies to back up that vision. Regardless of whether it is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) or the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), it is the same old flat tyre. The Liberal Party is just putting different spokes into the holes.

The honourable member for Ryan, a recycled Fraser Government minister, has come back and we are getting all of the platitudes from the 1970s. We get advice that wage rates in this country are far too high. There is no recognition of the sacrifice that the work force has undertaken to make this country 30 per cent more internationally competitive in the last decade.

We have received a call for dramatic cuts to public expenditure. The opposition thinks that we should flog off every government asset; that we should sell them all. This economic fundamentalism from the Liberal Party adds up to this: the solution to every problem in this country is to slash public expenditure, to sell all public enterprises and to bring in an unfair system of taxation, as it proposed with the GST.

The fact of the matter is that the Liberal Party does not have a policy alternative, given that it has supposedly dumped Fightback. It plays a game of conservative political rhetoric with respect to the republican debate. It says that we should not talk about the issue but, even if we do talk about it, we should not change it. So the Liberal Party is without a policy alternative.

The views of the honourable member for Wentworth are very interesting in this regard. I refer to what he had to say about the Liberal Party's policy alternative. On the Sunday Program recently, he said to Laurie Oakes:

SPEECH.PARA: There was no doubt at the last election that we stood for certain policy changes, and we had established a dominance in the area of policy debate.

That is true. The opposition did establish a dominance in the area of policy debate. It put forward a 15 per cent GST, and the electorate collectively held its nose because it could not stand the stench. That is some dominance! The opposition does not have a practical long-term alternative. The honourable member for Wentworth went on to tell Laurie Oakes:

Well, I mean, the reaction straight after the last election, on our side of politics, was almost like headless chooks: everyone was saying: oh, we've been there, we've had policy, we don't want policy any more. Let's just lie doggo and go quiet, look warm and fuzzy and try and get across the line.

The approach taken by the opposition in the House today is to look warm and fuzzy and to bemoan the fact that there are some problems with the ANL. We understand that there are problems with the ANL, but we have a commitment to an Australian flagged and crewed shipping line. This economy depends upon an effective national shipping line so that we can be internationally competitive. But what do we get from the Liberal Party? Opposition members come in here and talk about privatising 100 per cent of something which cannot be privatised and which the government has demonstrated cannot be privatised.

PARA.TAB: It does not matter whether we are talking about the republic or foreign investment. One week the Liberal Party does not want it; the next week it does. It does not matter whether we are talking about Mabo or the deficit. We get this flip-flop all over the place because the only policy of the Liberal Party is to say that it does not have a policy.

All of this was exposed in the Northern Territory a couple of weeks ago when people began to see your lack of substance. The public reacted and the Opposition Leader dropped 17 points in the polls. What was his reaction to that? He said, `Oh well, the more they see me the less they like me, so I will not come out into the public and talk about policy issues any more.' So where has the Leader of the Opposition been in this debate? A couple of weeks ago he would have been up here leading the attack, accusing the government of monumental mismanagement and all of the other cliches that he could string together. But he was absent today. What is his position? When is he going to say something about the ANL?

He is operating on the principle that the less they see him the more they like him. The Newspoll today shows that he has actually gone up in the polls after adopting the strategy of not being seen in public. But the fact of the matter is that as we run through to the next election he will not be able to hide from the public. He might run, but in the end he cannot hide.

The Leader of the Opposition and the collective policy position of those opposite have become a bit like a political cushion. They are very impressed by the last people who sat on them. If they make a comment about foreign investment and it is not well received in the business community, they backflip on that. If they go to the Northern Territory and make a statement on the Northern Territory land rights act and that is not liked by the Northern Territory government, they backflip on that. It does not matter what policy issue they are talking about, we cannot pin them down.

I think the fundamental thing that the Liberal and National parties do not understand in this House is why they lost the last election. They did not lose the last election because they had policies; they lost the last election because they had the wrong policies. The lesson for them is that if they are going to do any good at the next election they do not just need policies, they need the right policies.

I know it is very hard for the opposition to think within that framework, but that is why the government is successful. It has had the right policies in place to make this country more internationally competitive and able to restructure. Our approach to restructuring is not yours. We do not believe in the scorched earth approach of massive cuts to public expenditure, such as those advocated by various opposition spokesmen. They talk of cuts to public expenditure of somewhere between $10 billion, $20 billion or $30 billion a year when they go out and say we want Asian levels of taxation.

It does not matter whether you throw up Peacock, Howard, Hewson or Downer, the member for Mayo; it will not solve your problem. I refer to B. A. Santamaria, a well-known Australian political commentator, who said in the Australian on 21 May that the problem with the Liberal Party is that it is the party of the new rich practitioners:

SPEECH.PARA: This new class does not talk the language of the ordinary people . . . It has no community of interest or even contact with them.

It is pre-eminently the party of the new-rich practitioners of the money market, of property developers, of the rapidly growing gambling interests and of the alleged `entrepreneurs' and those who service them.
You could not have a better example of that than you have had in the House today.

PARA.TAB: This government will not shirk its responsibility to talk to the unions about how we can make ANL more internationally competitive. We have had a commitment over the last decade to work with the union movement to restructure our economy and to make ourselves more internationally competitive. That has involved a lot of pain for the work force. What angers me so much as I sit in this House and listen to so much of the supercilious comment that comes from those opposite is that they never acknowledge that the work force in this country has already made substantial sacrifices.

When I talk to representatives of the unions, people like Bob Carnegie in Brisbane and others, I say to them, `You're right to have a concern about this. You have made substantial sacrifices in recent years. But what you have to understand is that there is a changed market in international shipping and we do have problems. The government will address those problems because it will address them in the interest of ensuring that we can maintain in this country, if at all possible, an Australian crewed and flagged shipping line'—something which we have done for many years and we hope to do into the future. We will only do it by looking to the long term, taking the difficult decisions and acknowledging the role that the work force has to play, not by adopting the approach of the opposition. (Time expired)
