TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was making when the debate was interrupted was that basically one of the problems that face the parliament in this whole question of Aboriginal education is the same problem that it faces on issues like health and housing—that is, the detailed administration of much of that policy rests with state governments. The other problem, of course, is that it just happens to be a fact that since the demise of the Fraser government the opposition has had no coherent policy or philosophy in the whole area of Aboriginal affairs. That is, I think, not only a sad thing for them; it is an even sadder thing for this parliament and is unfortunate for Australia's indigenous people.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that when we come back to education, as a simple example, we find tremendous variation between states and within states and it is true to say, I believe, that there has been waste of expenditure, but that has largely been at the hands of state governments. It is not for nothing that the Aboriginal people themselves have in the area of health decided that they will try to organise their own health organisation, NAIHO, which deals with the problems that flow from dispossession.

One of the problems that face Australia as a community is that we have never been able to come to grips with the fact that Australia did not begin simply 200 years ago; it has a history of occupation, a history of culture related to our indigenous people that goes back 60,000 years and, despite differing government policies from the days of the early settlement, Australia has seriously misconstrued its own history. We have not looked at the problems of frontier settlement, the struggle of our indigenous people to survive.

There was a period which commenced in the 1930s during which the popular view was that Aboriginal people were going to disappear and be assimilated. They have survived; they have not been assimilated. They have a culture and a tradition which, despite all the things that have occurred, they are willing to share. They are willing to have non-Aboriginal Australians understand the depth, the nature and the history of that culture, and desperately want them to.

I believe it is a tragedy that the opposition finds itself caught up in a continuing conflict as to whether it will take that broad approach and formulate a national policy or whether its response will be the same as on almost every occasion when legislation has been brought into this House since the beginning of the Hawke period of government—that is, if it has to choose, it will opt for state interests against the needs of our Aboriginal people.

We saw the most interesting illustration of that when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) decided he would address the Liberal Party conference in Western Australia on the question of native title. It is a great pity that before he did that he did not seek the views of some distinguished ex-ministers for Aboriginal affairs who shared the perception that was part of the position of the Fraser government.

The Leader of the Opposition easily could have spoken to Mr Viner and other distinguished former ministers, who at least would have informed him about the views of the Northern Territory government in respect of the land rights act. They at least would have informed him of the problems that they as ministers had in maintaining the integrity of their own policy positions. That did not occur. Not only was that unfortunate for the Leader of the Opposition and for his shadow minister; more importantly, it was unfortunate for the people of Australia, who are entitled to have a far more sophisticated view on issues such as Aboriginal education than they are getting at the moment from the opposition. It is to be hoped that in the remaining term of this parliament the opposition will address these issues in a way which I believe Aboriginal people are entitled to expect.

There is one other aspect of this matter that I think we should look at very seriously. It is not just a question of educating Aboriginal children; it is also a question of educating Australian children. The inquiries that I have made in terms of secondary schools and primary schools in my own state indicate that the topic of Australian history and how it is taught is very much a matter to be decided from school to school by principals and some teachers, who in the course of dealing with that will deal with some of the problems that confront our indigenous people.

I believe it is absolutely essential that before all Australian children leave primary school, and certainly before they finish their secondary education, they should be fully and deeply informed about the history of Australia, and particularly the history of our Aboriginal indigenous people. Due to the benefits of television and the film industry, we have films such as Dances with Wolves. So the average Australian child who sees it knows something about the destruction of the Plains Indians. They see a film such as Geronimo and so they know some of the history of the Apache Indians.

We, like other nation states, have distorted our history. How many Australian adults have heard of Pemulay, who had to be one of the great guerrilla generals of modern history? With a band of Aboriginals that never numbered more than 18—it was usually about 13—and with primitive weapons, he fought the Rum Corps to a standstill, on three occasions nearly succeeded in destroying the infant colony, and forced the fringes of the settlement right back into Sydney itself. Whitehall had to send out a force of British regulars. If Whitehall sends out a force of British regulars, the Empire is at war. What contemporary or early history of Australia has dealt with that matter?

It is only in the last 10 years, thanks to the efforts of people such as Henry Reynolds, that we have been getting another perspective of Australian history. The people of my generation were given the staple diet of Clark's History of Australia, which described Aboriginal people as amongst the most unfortunate people on the face of the earth. They were described as people who were essentially nomads with no culture, no religion and no tradition. That might have been appropriate to the level of knowledge that existed at the time those sorts of books were published, but now there is another history. It is a history that I think has to be recognised and taught in our schools.

There is a new generation of people who realise that at this time in our history, if they just put out their hands, they are able to become part of a history and a culture that goes back 60,000 years. We can go up to Arnhem Land and look at Aboriginal rock paintings which are as fresh as the day they were done, when there was not a single building standing in Europe. That is our history.

Despite the things that have occurred involving Aboriginal people, their desire to make the broader Australian community understand their culture, their history and their tradition is overwhelming. I think that will forge a new meaning on the concept of reconciliation. So often when the issue of Aboriginal affairs is debated in this House, there tends to be a presumption that if only they were like us then they would not have their problems. The one thing Aboriginal people have managed to succeed in is to make it very plain that, whatever the strengths and weaknesses in our society, they have kept their own culture and traditions alive. They do not want to be just like us.

If we accept that, as we have accepted it in terms of a multicultural society, and we see the basis upon which we can build new concepts of our own society by picking up and regarding that tradition and that culture as a basis upon which to build a new Australian society, then I think we will have performed a useful and meaningful function in terms of any concept of reconciliation.

I dearly wish the new shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs all the best because, like former Liberal shadow ministers, she will have to come to terms with attempts by state governments to assert that aspects of legislation protecting Aboriginal concepts are in constant need of reform. She will have to come to terms with the fact that, although the Northern Territory government deeply opposed, as did its colleagues in this place, the handing over of Uluru, clearly the time has come, some 10 years later—it has not moved; it has not been sold; and no foreign company has taken it over—to give it its real name.

The government in the Northern Territory, on many occasions—particularly at election times—has no problem with dragging out all the old problems and reviving all the underlying attitudes towards Aboriginal people. The tourist industry in the Northern Territory is caught in this perpetual dilemma that faces many aspects of Australian society. When it advertises for tourists from the south or other parts of Australia, it uses Aboriginal motifs, wilderness aspects and Aboriginal music in order to suggest that the average person from Victoria, New South Wales or South Australia should travel to the Northern Territory to see these very important aspects of their society.

If it is good enough to advertise those things, it is good enough to use Aboriginal names. It is also good enough for this parliament, when we are allocating these funds, to indicate to the states that we are no longer going to be in a position where we will just simply hand over the money on the basis that they will determine the day-to-day practice and structure.

If we are serious about reconciliation, we have to take a far more positive attitude. We have to make it clear to the states that we want value for our dollar. We want to see real achievements on the ground. We must be determined that it is the right of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), hopefully with the cooperation of their colleagues in the opposition, to ensure that that takes place. Unless it does take place, two years from now we will still be having the same old debate. There is this perpetual argument about states rights and money being thrown away and wasted. I suggest that all humans, including our indigenous people, have rights. I have always felt that that point has superseded the continual argument about states rights.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those honourable members who have participated in this debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill. I particularly want to thank the shadow minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), for his expression of support for the bill. I note the concerns that he expressed during his remarks. He is concerned about the gaps in educational attainment that exist between Aboriginal Australians and the rest of Australia. So are we. He is also concerned that, in the future, we should focus on outcomes and results rather than on inputs. So are we. Certainly on these aspects of Aboriginal policy, if on no others, the government and the opposition are in agreement.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Braddon also indicated the information that he would be seeking about how effective government programs have been and how near we are to achieving some of our policy goals. The broad goals are to close those gaps and to ultimately arrive at a situation in which the achievements of Aboriginal Australia are exactly the same as those of Australia as a whole in both mean and range. Until we reach those goals, I do not think we can claim that our policies have been completely effective. I expect that the kind of information the honourable member for Braddon is seeking, which deals with the effectiveness of programs and progress towards goals, will be available when the AEP review is made public next month.

I suggest to the honourable member for Braddon that there is a way in which he can give some practical expression to his concerns. I was particularly taken by the remarks of the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) during his contribution. He said that one really needs the cooperation of the states to be effective in this field. I invite the honourable member for Braddon to give practical expression to his concerns by way of discussion with his colleagues in New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia. Those six non-Labor states and territories together form a majority on any ministerial council that is held in this country. We particularly need their cooperation to get the policy on Aboriginal education operating effectively.

The states will be required to provide ongoing data to measure progress. It is in their schools overwhelmingly that initiatives which we propose cooperatively will have to be implemented. It is with their support that we can have an effective national strategy on Aboriginal education.

At the ministerial council meeting in April, the Commonwealth proposed a draft strategy and a working party on the national strategy, which the states collectively decided to defer. That is not to say that work has not been proceeding in the meantime. But we await the outcome of a more limited working party that will report back to the ministerial council in November. I am very hopeful that we will have a positive result and that we will have indications of strong and enthusiastic support from the states.

Irrespective of whether we get support in November, we will certainly not give up. But how much better and easier it would be if that fine expression of support that we heard from the honourable member for Braddon today in this place were to be translated into cooperative action from his non-Labor colleagues at the ministerial council in November. I look forward to that meeting, and I look forward to a positive result. I thank all those honourable members who have made contributions to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes measures which give effect to certain announcements in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 budgets and the Working Nation white paper of 4 May 1994.

PARA.TAB: In Working Nation, the government announced a number of measures aimed at enhancing Australia's attractiveness as a regional headquarters location. These include the provision of a wholesale sales tax exemption and credit for imported, used computer related equipment, tax deductibility of certain costs of locating regional headquarters in Australia and a removal of withholding taxes on certain dividends distributed through Australia.

The initiatives in this bill will improve Australia's attractiveness as a location for the Asia-Pacific regional headquarters of large transnational corporations, including Australian companies. These complement the measures already put in place and first announced in the 1992 One Nation statement to promote Australia as a viable offshore banking centre.

The regional headquarters measures contained in this bill should provide a climate that attracts and retains multinationals without compromising the integrity of our taxation system. They will help Australia become an expanded financial centre of the region and so integrate more closely with the Asian-Pacific growth economies. The cost to revenue of the measures is likely to be around $40 million in 1994-95.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Taxation of Australian branches of foreign banks

PARA.TAB: The bill also proposes new taxation measures for the Australian branches of foreign banks. The new taxation measures were announced on 18 June 1993 in the banking policy statement issued by the former Treasurer.

The proposed new measures will recognise for taxation purposes intra-bank loans, derivative and foreign exchange transactions between the Australian branch and the foreign bank. Non-resident interest withholding tax will be applied to interest treated as being paid by an Australian branch to the foreign bank.

The proposals also treat part of a branch's funding from all sources as equity through the application of a notional equity requirement. The amendments also provide for revenue and capital loss transfer between the Australian branch of a foreign bank and its wholly owned Australian subsidiaries.

In implementing the decision to allow foreign banks to operate in Australia through branches, the government has given careful consideration to the taxation measures to apply to the Australian branches of foreign banks. This has been a complex process involving extensive consultation with the banking industry.

As part of the consultation process, the Treasurer released draft legislation and explanatory notes dealing with the proposed taxation measures. The industry comments were carefully considered and taken into account in preparing the branch banking provisions of the bill. The new measures are estimated to cost the revenue $10 million in 1994-95, $15 million in 1995-96, and $20 million in 1996-97 and 1997-98.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Home child-care allowance and dependent spouse rebate

PARA.TAB: The `with child' dependent spouse rebate for a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and dependent child or student is to be abolished and replaced with the new home child-care allowance from 29 September 1994. The amendments will remove a taxpayer's entitlement to the dependent spouse rebate where the taxpayer's spouse qualifies for the home child-care allowance. The amendments also exempt home child-care allowance payments from income tax and exclude the payments from the separate net income test for rebate purposes.

The amendments will also alter the current zone rebates, and rebates for members of the defence forces serving overseas and in the United Nations armed forces. This is necessary to ensure that these taxpayers are not disadvantaged by the abolition of the `with child' dependent spouse rebate. Amendments to the provisional tax rules are also necessary to ensure the correct rebate entitlements are used in the calculation of provisional tax for 1994-95 and later years.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to complement the introduction of the home child-care allowance

PARA.TAB: As I have just indicated, the amendments contained in the bill provide that where the spouse of a taxpayer qualifies for the home child-care allowance then the taxpayer will not be entitled to claim the `without child' dependent spouse rebate through the tax system. However, the government considers that families should be able to fall back onto the `without child' dependent spouse rebate if they qualify for that rebate. Accordingly, the government will be moving amendments to the bill in the Senate to allow taxpayers to claim the `without child' dependent spouse rebate instead of claiming for the home child-care allowance.

From 29 September 1994 the amount of jobsearch, newstart, sickness allowance or special benefit paid where the recipient has a dependent partner is to be split between the two partners. The recipient will continue to receive the allowance or benefit at half the former rate and the spouse will receive the partner allowance paid at the same rate. The amendments to the tax law are necessary to give the partner allowance the same tax treatment as other comparable social security allowances and benefits.

The impact on revenue of removing the dependent spouse rebate is a gain to revenue of $360 million in 1994-95, $870 million in 1995-96 and $1,050 million in 1996-97. These gains are offset by outlays on the home child-care allowance. The cost of introducing the partner allowance is not significant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deductions for bequests of significant cultural value made to certain institutions

PARA.TAB: The bill will allow an income tax deduction for a testamentary gift of property to specified funds, authorities and institutions under the cultural bequests program, announced last year by the government. The amendments will also exempt the gift from the application of the capital gains tax provisions. The total deductions to be approved under these provisions will be capped at a notional cost to revenue of $2 million per year, commencing in the 1994-95 income year.

The bill contains amendments designed to increase the level of compliance within certain industries. The amendments will introduce a new reportable payments system. Like the prescribed payments system, the scope of the reportable payments system will be prescribed in regulations. Initially, the proposed system will apply to certain payments within the fishing and the clothing industries where a high level of noncompliance has been identified.

Under the proposed system, a payee who is receiving a reportable payment may quote his or her tax file number to the payer. This quotation will form the basis of reports provided by the payer to the Commissioner of Taxation. The information will then enable the commissioner to match and verify the declared income of payees.

When a payee chooses not to quote his or her tax file number, the payer will be required to deduct an amount from the payment. The amount to be deducted is consistent with amounts currently deducted from investment income, prescribed payments and salary or wages, when a payee's tax file number is not quoted. Amounts deducted will be forwarded to the commissioner and credited to the payee on assessment.

The increased revenue from these measures is difficult to quantify. This is mainly due to the difficulties in estimating the precise level of tax evasion and the behavioural changes that will result from the introduction of the reportable payments system. The government estimates that increased revenue of up to $100 million per annum will be collected as a result of the introduction of the reportable payments system.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Foreign investment funds and controlled foreign companies

PARA.TAB: Australia now has a comprehensive system of taxing foreign source income. The first two parts of this system were the foreign tax credit system and the controlled foreign company measures. The foreign investment fund measures which took effect from 1 January 1993 constitute the third and final part of the system.

These measures have been kept under constant review in order to rectify any difficulties which arise in the course of their operation. The bill contains amendments necessary to finetune the foreign investment fund measures and align them properly with existing provisions, particularly the controlled foreign company measures. These measures have a minimal effect on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Eligible investment fund income of registered organisations

PARA.TAB: The bill will include in the assessable income of friendly societies and certain other registered organisations income derived from certain assets of the organisation. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that the provisions of division 8A are not circumvented by the holding of assets separate from the eligible insurance business of the organisation. The amendment is in response to the full High Court decision in Independent Order of Oddfellows of Victoria v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation.

The amendments will apply to income derived on or after 1 July 1994 by a registered organisation from eligible investment assets. It is not possible to reliably estimate the revenue impact of this measure; however, the measure has the potential to prevent a significant future loss to revenue.

The bill also includes amendments to retain the current provisional tax uplift factor of eight per cent, as announced in the 1994-95 budget. The uplift factor of eight per cent will be applied to 1993-94 incomes for the calculation of 1994-95 provisional tax. The measure defers $170 million of revenue from 1994-95 to 1995-96.

The bill will amend the provisions relating to reasonable benefit limits that apply to concessionally taxed superannuation benefits. The reasonable benefit limit provisions apply from 1 July 1994. The proposed amendments will overcome a number of technical deficiencies with the new provisions and ensure that the provisions operate as intended. The amendments will apply from 1 July 1994 and have no impact on the revenue.

In late 1993, to make child care more affordable, the government introduced amendments to provide certain exemptions from sales tax to child-care bodies. In general, to obtain funding for a child-care centre and thus access to the sales tax exemptions the centre must be outfitted and operating. This raises the issue that the goods needed to set up the centre will not be exempted from sales tax. The bill will introduce a new credit ground to allow such bodies a credit of sales tax for goods to be used in the provision of child care where the goods are purchased before a body is approved for funding. The credit will apply from 24 December 1993.

A further issue has arisen with certain child-care bodies purchasing luxury motor vehicles free of sales tax. Although there are few occasions where the usage of such a vehicle will meet the criteria for exemption, it is not the government's intention to allow bodies to gain this level of exemption at the cost of child care. It is proposed to limit the sales tax benefit in the purchase of motor vehicles to the subluxury component of the value. Thus the value above the luxury vehicle limit will be fully taxed. This restriction will apply to purchases from tomorrow. The effect of these amendments on the revenue will be negligible.

Since the introduction of the new sales tax on 1 January 1993, the Australian Taxation Office, in conjunction with business and other affected parties, has been reviewing the operation of the tax. The government has been pleased to find that the vast majority of provisions are operating very well. However, there are some that would be best handled by legislative amendment. The overall cost to the revenue of these initiatives is expected to be small.

In general, where faulty goods are replaced free of charge under warranty, a credit is allowed for the tax borne on the replacement goods. If the defective goods are later repaired and sold, a clawback of the credit, proportional to the price received, is obtained. At present no allowance is made for tax paid parts used in the repair. The law will be amended to reduce the clawback by the amount of tax borne on the parts used in the repair. The amendments will apply to sales of defective goods from today.

Australia has a burgeoning industry in repairing goods for overseas owners. It is also developing a market for used Australian goods which have been refurbished. The law will be amended to allow a credit for parts, fittings and accessories used in the repair, renovation or upgrading of goods to be exported, provided the tax is not passed on in the price of the alterations. The credit will apply to tax borne on parts used after 1 January 1993.

Quotation of a registered number or exemption declaration is the method used to obtain exemption from sales tax. In general this quotation is required in respect of each dealing, although the Commissioner of Taxation has discretion to allow a monthly quotation for all dealings in the month. To assist business to reduce the cost of administration and to provide flexibility, the law will be amended to allow a single quotation for a period up to one year for all purchases from a particular supplier. This periodic quotation will be able to be given by both registered and unregistered purchasers to both registered and unregistered suppliers. It will not require commissioner approval. The amendment will take effect from the date this bill receives royal assent.

In order to gain sales, particularly of new products, suppliers often allow businesses to trial the product before buying or leasing. This practice is described as post-trial sales or leases. The current legislation allows a credit of sales tax borne by the supplier where the person trialling and buying, or leasing for the remainder of the statutory period, is an exempt user and gains the benefit of the credit in the price. The law will be amended to allow for multiple trials by exempt users and final sale or lease to any exempt user. This will ensure that the supplier is able to be flexible in his or her method of selling, whilst ensuring that an exempt user gains the benefit of exemption. The amendment will apply to goods first trialled after this bill receives royal assent.

In respect of containers for use with takeaway food, it is the government's policy that the containers be taxed. It has been suggested that delivery containers for takeaway food may be exempted in the terms of the current legislation. An amendment will be made to ensure that the legislation is clarified to confirm that delivery containers for takeaway food are taxable. The measure will apply to dealings with goods from today.

A consequential amendment made to the legislation in 1992 to align the terminology of the sales tax legislation with the Radio Communications Act 1992 has resulted in wireless transceivers used mainly to make contact with the Royal Flying Doctor Service and other similar services being denied exemption. This particularly affects outback farmers. The law will be amended to reinstate the exemption that applied prior to the consequential amendment and will have effect on dealings occurring after 30 June 1993.

The bill also provides for a reduction in the rate of mining withholding tax from 5.8 per cent to 4 per cent. That tax applies to certain revenues derived by Aboriginal communities and groups from the use of Aboriginal land for exploration and mining. The reduction in the rate takes account of changes in the basic rate of personal tax. The measure is estimated to cost the revenue less than $1 million in 1994-95, 1995-96, 1996-97 and 1997-98.
The bill also repeals some inoperative provisions relating to short-term asset sales and the home loan interest rebate. It also makes some minor technical amendments to the gift provisions.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Assistant Treasurer, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), pointed out in his second reading speech this afternoon, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) makes a series of amendments to the taxation legislation in Australia, most of which are unremarkable and many of which are sensible and therefore have the support of the opposition. Those matters relating to regional headquarters, the taxation of Australian branches of foreign banks, reportable payment systems and so forth are not matters which I therefore intend to comment upon. However, there are some matters in this bill which deserve considerable comment. Before coming to those, I will briefly refer to two matters.

PARA.TAB: The first matter relates to the foreign investment funds and controlled foreign companies provisions of this bill. These provisions include measures to provide for the taxation of investments held by Australian residents in non-controlled foreign companies, interests held by Australian beneficiaries in non-controlled foreign trusts, and investments in foreign life policies by Australian policyholders. The short statement in relation to these matters is that this system is one which is becoming unmanageable and largely unworkable, and therefore amendments which are in this bill which provide some freeing up of that system are those which are to be supported. However, we would commend to the Assistant Treasurer and to the government a wholesale review of the foreign investment funds and controlled foreign companies provisions so that they become much more workable if they are to remain in somewhat similar form to that which exists at present.

There are also some provisions in this legislation relating to provisional tax. The legislation provides that the uplift factor for calculation of 1994-95 provisional tax which currently stands at 10 per cent will be amended to a lower uplift factor of eight per cent for 1994-95 and 10 per cent for later years. Given the rate of inflation which we hear the Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), harking back to from time to time in this place, it seems somewhat unrealistic to try to justify a rate of eight per cent and 10 per cent in future years if anything in the government forecast about the future of the economy is to stand true. This is simply a measure which accelerates the revenue collection methods of the government and it is one which again imposes a burden on business in this country. It ought to be amended and certainly not held at those percentages of eight and 10 per cent in relation to activities in this country.

However, the measures to which I want to address most of my remarks relate to two matters: firstly, the parenting allowance which the Assistant Treasurer referred to in his remarks and, secondly, the home child-care allowance. In this the International Year of the Family, one sees from time to time in the newspapers and hears in the media reports which relate to families and the condition of families in this country. If one came into this place, one would hardly know that it was the year of the family because there has been no debate, no ministerial statement, no indication of any sense that the year of the family means something to the legislature, to the House of Representatives and to the people of Australia. From looking at this legislation we know why the government is so reluctant to talk about the matter.

We are not simply dealing with a government that could be said to have a benign neglect of families in this country. This bill contains measures which actually seriously worsen the situation for thousands of Australian families. I shall set out in some detail the criticisms that are made of these measures. In this year's budget, the Treasurer, in speaking about the new home child-care allowance to be paid in September, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It will provide payments of up to $30 per week and will replace the dependent spouse rebate for couples with children . . . 840,000 Australian families will benefit. This is a substantial and progressive change to Australia's income support system.

It is those last words, `This is a substantial and progressive change to Australia's income support system' which, over the next few minutes, I will demonstrate hardly could be highlighted or recorded in Hansard for their accuracy.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the parenting allowance, which the Assistant Treasurer dealt with in the first place. In the white paper, the government announced that it would provide a parenting allowance of up to $132.65 per week for families in which only one parent is employed. While the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made great claims about supporting families and the role of this parenting allowance in supporting families, the reality is that the measure at most will apply to about 118,000 Australian families—a tiny proportion of the total number of families in Australia—most of whom will receive less than the $133 a week.

In addition, currently under jobstart or newstart allowances, an unemployed married couple receives a maximum of $265.30 per week. Under these new proposals all that will happen is that the allowance will be split in half. Couples will receive $132.65 per week each or a total of what is presently paid of $265.30. So there we have it: a great announcement from this government suggesting that it will do great things for Australian families. In reality all it is doing is splitting the current benefit in half and paying it to two people rather than one person. I suppose an additional administrative cost would be involved into the bargain.

The home child-care allowance is the measure which takes the cake so far as deception on the part of this government is concerned in what it has promised to Australian families. This Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is full of what might be regarded by the general public of Australia as arcane provisions which relate to the complexities of sales tax, foreign investment and other things which most people would not understand even if they read the bill. Hidden away in these 90 pages of taxation laws dealing with other matters is the reality of what the government is trying to do with the home child-care allowance system.

Let us go back to what the government is doing and what it purports to do in relation to child-care benefits. First of all, families with two children in institutional child care are subsidised by up to $61.50 per week. This rebate of $61.50 is not means tested at all. It does not matter whether people earn $20,000 a year, $120,000 or $220,000; they still receive this non-means tested rebate. Yet when we turn to parents who have a child and one of the spouses is caring for that child in the home the government was most generous. It said, `We'll provide $30.' What it did not say very loudly or clearly, and what it still is not saying very loudly or clearly, in relation to these provisions is that it will trade in the dependent spouse rebate and give people $30. What is the dependent spouse rebate worth? It is worth about $27 or $28. So what the government is really giving parents where one spouse stays at home and looks after children is $2.88. This is a great, generous gesture to Australian families! On the latest estimates or costs, that would probably buy a Big Mac.

Not only has the government simply traded in one measure which assisted families for another at a slight increase in value; when we look at the way in which it is doing that we can also see a whole series of problems for Australian families. The national director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, Peter McDonald, has said that up to 200,000 families will be potentially worse off under these new arrangements. This is calculated on taxpayers who at present do not claim the full dependent spouse rebate. He says that, if only half the dependent spouses do part-time work or have a notional income from managed investments, this would represent 100,000 Australian families who will not be better off by this measure which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) trumpets around the country but worse off.

Part of the reason for this is that the rules for the home child-care allowance are very different from those which apply to the dependent spouse rebate. The Tax Commissioner and tax accountants have been giving advice regarding separate net income. This is not correct according to the social security rules applied to the home child-care allowance. So the tests which apply to the way in which income is regarded under the tax system that currently applies to the dependent spouse rebate are different from those that apply under the social security system applying to the new home child-care allowance. The effect of that tightening up of the income rules, of drawing a more narrow parameter around what is regarded as income and what is exempted from income, means that according to the Taxpayers Association somewhere between 100,000 and 200,000 Australian families will be worse off. Yet we are being told by this government that it is doing something for Australian families.

In addition, we have the public perception that people will receive the home child-care allowance in addition to the dependent spouse rebate. An advertisement which will appear in this week's Women's Weekly and New Idea says, `If you stay at home for your children, this simple quiz could get you $60 a fortnight.' There is a clear implication in this advertisement, which will appear in the Women's Weekly and New Idea. The advertisement asks: `Do you have a partner? Do you have a child who is under 16 years of age or a child in secondary school? Are you and your child living in Australia? Is your income less than $250.85 a fortnight?' If people can answer all the quizzes, if people answer yes to all those questions, they will receive an extra $60 a fortnight.

The reality is that the extra $60 a fortnight has partly been traded in on a benefit that is already provided. When looking through this advertisement, it is hard to find any indication—there is none on my reading of it—that this is a benefit given after the government pulls back another benefit in the first place. Here we have a government standing up and saying to the Australian people, `We are doing great things for Australian families. Look at us. Vote for us. We will make your life as Australian families better.' The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) may smile, but I ask him, if he gets a chance to speak on this particular legislation, whether he can justify what is going on in relation to it.

The reality is that the government is taking back one benefit with one hand and giving something with the other hand. It is doing it in a way in which the rules have been changed so the chances of qualifying for this new measure are less than those of qualifying at the present time. The impression given by this advertisement to hundreds and thousands of Australian families is misleading. If the trade practices legislation, which we heard one of the ministers talk about in question time today, applied to this advertisement and to the government's program, this would clearly be in breach of such legislation.

I want to talk about the effect this measure will have on spouses who do part-time work. They will have to take into account the gross effect of their income. Under the rules that operate at the present time, they could take into account all work-related expenses. For example, if a spouse worked one day a week and travelled 10 kilometres each way to her job, she could claim up to $500 a year for travel expenses under the rules for the dependent spouse rebate. Yet, under these new provisions in the home child-care allowance, none of this is allowable at all.

The Taxpayers Association provided an example of a spouse who has a dependent child and a part-time job, and who earns a salary of $150 a week and also gets a weekly travelling allowance of $120, which is fully expended for work purposes. She also incurs net child minding costs per week of $75. Under these circumstances, separate net income for income tax purposes is her employment income, which is $7,800, and her travelling allowance, which is $6,240. That makes a total of $14,040. From that, she can deduct her travelling costs of $6,240 and her child minding expenses of $3,900. This means that her separate net income, after taking away those deductions, is just $3,900. Therefore, using this example, under the current system, the dependent spouse rebate would be allowed at a figure of $521. That is under the current system, and remember that this is a government which is doing something for Australian families. Let us take this example and see what it is doing.

If we take the social security rules, that family is financially worse off. The income of the dependent spouse or child carer's income is deemed to be not $3,900, as it would be under the dependent spouse rebate, but $14,040—and with no reduction for expenses. Therefore, the home child-care allowance payable to this woman working in a part-time job in this example is nil. That is an example of a family which is worse off as a consequence of these changes.

There are other problems with these changes. If, for example, for some reason the breadwinners fail to notify their employer that they are no longer getting the dependent spouse rebate, they will find themselves lumbered with an unexpected tax bill at the end of the financial year. There is very little publicity about the fact that the tax instalments of the breadwinner must rise where the rebate is turned into the home child-care allowance and paid direct to the carer spouse.

A pamphlet is available from the Department of Social Security. If we read through all the fine print in some detail, we will eventually find on page 3 an indication that, if we or our partner get a credit against the tax we would normally pay at the end of the financial year, this will also no longer apply. One would think that when a change like this is made, which could not only end up providing less assistance to families but also, if they are not aware of the details of the provisions, lead them to a situation where they are lumbered with an unexpected tax bill at the end of the financial year, given the recessionary conditions that Australia has been in, the government might state that in bold writing so that people can quite clearly understand what is being said.

There is nothing in the advertisement at all. There was nothing in the statement which was made by the Treasurer. People have to get hold of the pamphlet from the Department of Social Security, read the fine print, get down to page three and then, if they understand what it means, they might understand that they run this risk if they do not make the suitable notification.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost deliberate deception.

—As my learned colleague says, it is almost deliberate deception. Over the last two years this government has deceived the Australian people in relation to a whole raft of promises that it made to them. There would hardly be a person in Australia who would place any credence in what is being said by the Prime Minister and members of the government at present. If honourable members want one more example of that, they simply have to look at these provisions and they will find it.

PARA.TAB: We can also see that as the home child-care allowance is calculated on a fortnightly basis, the worst case scenario would be when part-time work fluctuated wildly, which it does for some people in Australia at present. In those circumstances a person might have to make as many as 26 applications a year in order to obtain the benefit. That is simply bureaucracy gone mad and something which this government ought to be able to do something about.

Nor is there anything in the bill to prevent spouses who are the beneficiaries of unit and discretionary trusts claiming the home child-care allowance for the entire year, apart from the one fortnight in which they received trust income at 30 June each year. What I mean by that is: if they receive income from a trust on 30 June for a particular financial year, and therefore they have income which makes them ineligible for the home child-care allowance, there is nothing, it seems to me on a reading of this bill, which would prevent them from, in effect, claiming the allowance for the other fortnights of the year even though they received income from a trust which may put them beyond the limit which is provided for in the legislation.

The bill opens up an administrative minefield. The government's claim that it would cost $230 million more to give this allowance is probably due to the extra administrative costs, as it is substituting a very simple arrangement for a very complex one. There is a whole range of unanswered questions. I thought I heard the Assistant Treasurer say something about some amendments which may be moved in the Senate. Perhaps he ought to be addressing some of these issues. This legislation is so unfair in its application from a government that practices the rhetoric of equity yet, when it comes to legislation like this, does anything but provide equitably for people.

There are some other unanswered questions as well. For example, in the case of mortgage offset accounts as held by couples, will the dependent spouse be deemed to have received income? Is a person able to choose between the dependent spouse rebate and the home child-care allowance? And where there are cash gifts to children that often go into a trust account with the mother as trustee, is this held to be income of the spouse—that is, if the mother is acting as trustee for money which is paid, in effect, to the children, will this be regarded as income and therefore have an effect on whether or not the home child-care allowance can be paid?

In addition to that, we now have a new form and new Big Brother government inquiring into the activities of ordinary Australians in a way which was not inquired into prior to these changes. For example, on the form to be filled in there are questions about accounts held in the names of, the balance of accounts, the interest rates which are prevailing at present in relation to term deposits, joint accounts and accounts held under any other names. Provision of pay slips is called for, and a person needs to supply documents to prove how much he or she gets, for example investment certificates, statements, letters, et cetera.

If we go back to the family payment system, those details and that invasion of one's privacy as an individual and as a family are not required. All that is required is a simple statement of income, whereas under this legislation the payment of the home child-care allowance is within the clutches of the Department of Social Security and all the invasive questioning that goes on from that department is provided for, simply because this government, out of its generosity, will now make a payment to ordinary families in Australia. Whose money in the first place is this payment that is to be made? There is a whole range of these provisions in the legislation. People without children can still get the dependent spouse rebate and there are questions about whether they are aware of those provisions. If we look at some of the questions raised by the measures contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) of 1994, measures which are hidden away in 90 pages of arcane provisions relating to the taxation laws of Australia generally, we can rightfully come to the conclusion that anything the government says in relation to families is in fact deceptive.

The government paints the picture that it is doing something about Australian families. It tells the Australian people that it cares for Australian families, that it will do something for them. It promises them a parenting allowance, but it will not tell them the detail, that all it will do is split one allowance in half so that half of it goes to one spouse and half of it to the other. It promises them a new payment of $60 but forgets to tell them that all it will do is trade in one payment, which it will take off them, and give them another.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sleight of hand.

—As my learned colleague says, it is a huge sleight of hand. It suggests to the Australian people that it cares for families in a way which will give them something extra. It puts advertisements in women's magazines right around the country which say, `Here's an extra $60 going for the asking,' but it does not tell them the fine detail, that that $60 will be very difficult to get and, in fact, many Australian families, perhaps 100,000 to 200,000 of them, will get less at the end of the day than they get at present.

PARA.TAB: This is the quality of the equity; this is the quality of the interest in Australian families that we are getting from the present government. The government is simply creating an illusion that it is doing a good job; that it really cares for Australians. It does not come in here and debate these matters. It simply puts forward, in the midst of legislation like this, some provisions relating to home child-care allowances which hide the real detail.

It is then up to members of the opposition to expose what this government is not doing for ordinary Australian families; otherwise people would be under the illusion that this is simply a government which is making their lives better off. The opposition has done this in a whole range of other areas relating to the national economy and families in Australia generally. This is yet another example of a government which has lost its way. It is so aloof, so arrogant and so imperious to the needs of ordinary Australians that it thinks it can sell this as a change to policy in such a way that people will believe that they are getting something better when in fact a lot of them will be a whole lot worse off.

There are other members of the opposition who will be speaking about these matters. My colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) reminds me that he has some amendments which he wishes to move in relation to provisions relating to the treatment of re-manufactured goods. My colleague the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) also has some amendments relating to the matter which I have been speaking about this afternoon, the home child-care allowance. These are amendments which we in the opposition feel strongly about. We believe that what the government is doing here, at the very best—if we put the best gloss we can on what the government is doing—is telling the Australian people just one small part of the story of what it is actually doing and hiding the other provisions in this legislation.

We regard this as a deceptive campaign, a deceptive measure, which is once again trying to foist upon Australian families measures which overall are not for the benefit of many of these families. This is coming from a government whose reputation for doublespeak is added to by the context of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) this evening. Taxation is not always an exciting subject, but the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) likes to get into the theatre of it and make it as exciting as possible. Whenever we speak in this place on taxation and how it affects families it is always appropriate to remind those opposite about their performance many years ago. It is a good thing for Australia that it has been many years since they were in government. The only growth industry under the previous government was the tax avoidance industry. It is timely to remind those opposite today—because they still have not learned from those bad old days—of how they did not believe in a fair and equitable tax system. That is what this government has worked on over the many years we have been in office.

PARA.TAB: Australia's tax system is fairer today than it ever was under the Liberal-National Party regime. Those opposite still have not learnt. One day they might wake up to the fact that what people want is a fair tax system. Through the reforms this government has put in place over many years we have been able to provide a much more equitable tax system without going down the track the opposition wanted to go at the last election. The way the opposition was going to reform the tax system was to impose a goods and services tax on every man, woman and child in this country. I believe that some of those opposite still support that form of taxation, which was soundly rejected by the Australian people at the last election, and rightly so.

Given that this is our first opportunity after the break to speak about these issues again, it is timely to remind people about those sorts of things. It is fair to say that, although this legislation may not appear to be all that exciting, it is comprehensive. Like many of the government's amendment bills on taxation which are necessary from time to time, this bill covers a range of areas. It will be very hard for honourable members to do justice to all aspects of this bill this evening. I would like to concentrate on a few of the key areas in the proposed legislation.

As I alluded to previously, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is an omnibus bill which seeks to make various amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Income Tax (Mining Withholding Tax) Act 1979 and the sales tax laws. Its purpose is to introduce a reportable payment system to assist greater compliance in tax collection. I am sure that is welcomed by all concerned members of this place. It prevents double taxation in relation to foreign sourced income, it removes the dependent spouse rebate where the new home child-care allowance applies and it provides for income for the purposes of provisional tax to increase by eight per cent in 1994-95.

The home child-care allowance has been an innovative move by the government that will assist many families directly on a fortnightly basis rather than their having to wait for their annual tax deductions through, generally speaking, the breadwinner's income tax. That is often forgotten by people in their tax assessment; they just put in their dependent spouse rebate. It is not received on a regular basis into the household budget. This measure will help families a great deal.

Other aspects of this legislation are that it will ensure the consistent treatment of certain commutated eligible termination payments. This government has been at the forefront in the superannuation area. The legislation provides income and sales tax concessions for regional headquarters established in Australia, an innovative area which I wish to turn to later as well. The bill will deem branches of foreign banks as separate legal entities for most tax purposes and allow sales tax credit in respect of sales tax paid in relation to the alteration of goods for export.

As honourable members can tell from that summary, there are plenty of different areas to talk about in relation to this bill. I would like to start by making a few comments on the important benefits it will bring to Australia by providing proposed tax concessions for regional headquarters of corporations in Australia. These changes were foreshadowed in the government's revolutionary Working Nation white paper, a document that has been well received right around Australia.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has been implementing many of those initiatives over the weeks that we have been in recess. That paper was aimed at making Australia an even more attractive place for multinational companies to invest and establish their regional headquarters to service the booming Asia-Pacific region. You would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, of the activities of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in promoting Australia in the Asia-Pacific region, quite evident over recent weeks.

The very strong economic growth and development in the Asia-Pacific region has led many multinationals to establish bases from which to provide support services for their new and expanding operations in this part of the world. The term regional headquarters, or RHQ, broadly refers to an entity that provides support services to its associated companies located in other countries in the region and acts as an intermediary between the associated companies and the parent company located elsewhere: for example, Europe or North America. Of course, in the Australian context an RHQ is an Australian company which is established to provide these services for associated companies located in our region.

In attracting RHQs to Australia, the government was not prepared to just let the natural attractions of a 4 1/2 per cent growth rate, low company tax rates, inflation of around two per cent, record profitability and productivity rises and, as we saw less than a fortnight ago, record employment growth, play a role in bringing business into Australia. True to its record in recent years, the government has set out on a path to truly integrate Australia into the Asia-Pacific region. Indeed, we have seen a number of successes in this field recently, with the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, announcing a series of multinational regional headquarters being established in Australia, not least of which was the announcement by IBM that it would build an Asia-Pacific service centre here in Australia.

The importance of regional headquarters was illustrated by the report by the Allen Consulting Group entitled `The benefits of regional headquarters and the factors influencing their location in Australia' which, for the sake of brevity, I will henceforth refer to as the Allen report. When Senator Cook launched the report, he noted that the regional headquarters of the 65 multinationals which have established operations here generate about 1,100 jobs and economic activity in excess of $350 million every year. Besides these direct benefits, the report noted that many indirect benefits are created by the RHQs, including the introduction of know-how in the areas of business intelligence, leading edge technology, management and strategic links to our region. In addition, RHQs are very good customers for Australian produced goods and services, which augurs well for the need to create jobs in our area.

A key part of the Allen report was a survey of companies operating RHQs in Australia. This section confirmed that decisions to locate an RHQ are driven by three broad sets of factors: geographical proximity to key markets and growth prospects, quality of existing support infrastructure, quality of life for staff—always a strong factor in Australia—the availability of skilled labour, costs of services, political stability, which this government has certainly provided, and, most importantly, government incentives in the tax system.

The report found that Australia was a clear winner as far as the first two factors were concerned. The changes this legislation will introduce will enhance this attractiveness by addressing the third set of factors—government incentives and the tax system. This bill proposes to allow deductions for certain business relocation expenses associated with the set-up of an RHQ company in Australia. This provision is in clause 109. The bill will also exempt non-residents from liability to dividend withholding tax on dividends paid out of certain foreign sourced dividend income of companies resident in Australia. This provision is in clause 44 of the bill.

Although this exception on dividend withholding tax was introduced as part of the RHQ initiatives in Working Nation, it is important to realise that the exemption will not be limited to shareholders of companies performing RHQ functions in Australia. It will also be available to non-resident shareholders of all Australian resident companies which derive foreign source dividend income. These measures will not only attract foreign RHQs but also provide an incentive for Australian companies to aggressively seek new markets, new shareholders and sources of funds in our region and in so doing will improve the linkages between Australian industry and that of the Asia-Pacific region.

Clause 82CB of the bill contains a number of definitions including management related services, financial and treasury, business planning, marketing, accounting and research and development services. The RHQ set-up costs are defined as expenditure incurred in setting up a regional headquarters that the Treasurer has approved and starting 12 months before the body derives income in Australia from the regional headquarters and continuing for 12 months after this date or expenditure incurred in reimbursing a non-resident associate for expenditure that would have qualified under the other criteria. Set-up costs do not include costs associated with feasibility studies, moving costs between places in Australia or the cost of plant, equipment, land, buildings or similar items. The bill provides for regional headquarters support—that is, the company will be taken to provide such support if it provides to an associated company that operates outside of Australia management related services, data services or software support services.

The bill will also amend the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 to provide an exemption for certain computer equipment used in the regional headquarters. The exemption will apply where computer related goods were owned or leased by the regional headquarters for at least nine months prior to their local entry and were entered within two years of the first exempt goods under this provision. In other words, the exemption will last for only two years.

The RHQ initiatives are indeed welcome proposals, as the international economy shows tentative signs of following Australia's strong growth pattern over the last 18 months. The signs from the United States are that we are gradually experiencing strengthening growth. As the world enters this period of sustained steady growth, the competition for new markets outside the traditional areas of interest will intensify. Of course, the area everybody wants to enter is the Asia-Pacific region. Some countries in that region are experiencing annual growth in excess of seven per cent. By making it more attractive for RHQs to be set up in Australia, we will effectively be giving this country a head start in terms of establishing the vital industry and technological linkages necessary to realise the full potential of our involvement in the Asia-Pacific region.

The measures will also have the added side effect of improving competition and therefore quality in the domestic economy. That measure needs the strength of commitment from all levels of government in Australia. This issue has been canvassed in recent days, particularly at COAG. Multinational RHQs are discerning customers that will demand only the best in the services and products supplied by local industry and will provide an incentive for Australian industries to improve quality and productivity. Many opportunities will be opened up for existing Australian industries and this will create jobs that we so badly need in Australia.

In short, the initiatives in this bill will improve Australia's attractiveness as a location for Asia-Pacific regional headquarters of large multinationals including Australian companies. These complement the measures already announced in the 1992 One Nation statement to promote Australia as a viable offshore banking centre. The RHQ measures in this bill should provide a climate that attracts and retains multinationals without compromising the important integrity of our taxation system.

The banking system is a very important part of ensuring that industry develops in this nation. We need to encourage our banking system to take up some of the advantages, such as equity capital, that this government has put in place. The banking industry needs to be more aggressive in the business sector instead of concentrating on the very easy housing market. This issue has also been canvassed over recent days in the interest rate debate.

Australian banks really need to be much more aggressive in assisting Australian business, otherwise their international competitors will certainly take advantage of them. If this is the way we have to go, it will be at the expense of those Australian banks that are not prepared to get out in the market and aggressively support industries in this country.

These initiatives will help Australia become an expanded financial centre of the region and integrate more closely with the economies of the Asia-Pacific region. The banking sector needs to play a very important part in expanding Australia's interest in the Asia-Pacific region. We have the opportunities and we must grasp them.

The amendments in the bill with respect to the taxation of Australian branches of foreign banks will have a similar effect. These measures were announced last year by the former Treasurer in the banking policy statement. I believe the issue of equity capital funding was mentioned in that policy statement. The proposed new measures will recognise for taxation purposes intra-bank loans and derivative and foreign exchange transactions between the Australian branch and the foreign bank. For withholding tax purposes, the branch of the foreign bank is to be treated as a separate legal entity.

The major effects of the amendments are: income derived from the branch is to be taken as derived in Australia; foreign tax paid by the bank on income derived in Australia is deductible; if the bank makes funds available to the branch, the branch will be taken to have borrowed those funds; the branch is taken to have paid interest on the funds borrowed from the bank; a deduction will be allowable on the interest; and if withholding tax is payable on the interest deemed aid to the bank the withholding tax is to be based on a reduced amount. This bill is not just about dry taxation measures. There are many important initiatives in this taxation amendment bill which the government has put forward.

On the proposed changes to legislation related to social security payments, the bill will remove a taxpayer's entitlement to the dependent spouse rebate where the taxpayer's spouse qualifies for the new home child-care allowance which is set to begin on 29 September. That will assist a lot of families with their fortnightly budgets. This allowance will be paid directly to the person who cares for the child at home, usually the mother, as opposed to other payments which formerly went to the taxpayer in the couple. The allowance was often lost when the tax assessment was done.

It has been estimated that this benefit will assist some 840,000 families and will put more than $1 billion directly into the hands of the parents at home. It is yet another indication of how seriously this government views its obligations to the women of Australia—they are the ones who will be most directly affected by this—not only those who work but also those who make the decision to either stay at home with the children or leave the work force to care for them. Like the recently started Commonwealth child-care cash rebate, it will allow women a greater choice in their lives.

The amendments in the bill will exempt home child-care allowance payments from income tax; remove a taxpayer's entitlement to the dependent spouse rebate where the taxpayer's spouse qualifies for the home child-care allowance; and exclude the home child-care allowance from separate net income and alter the separate net income test for partial rebate entitlements. It will make necessary consequential amendments to the current zone rebates and rebates for members of the defence forces serving overseas and United Nations armed forces. Those will be very welcome. These amendments are necessary to ensure that these taxpayers are not disadvantaged by the abolition of the dependent spouse rebate. It will also make amendments to the provisional tax provisions, making the provisional tax uplift factor used to assess a person's income for the tax year eight per cent in 1994-95 and 10 per cent in later years.

I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to comment on some of the important aspects of this legislation before us tonight. I would like to congratulate the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) who is responsible for the carriage of this particular bill. Many people may not realise that, during the recess, the government responded to a large number of recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which inquired into the Taxation Office. I think a lot of those initiatives will be of great help to many Australian taxpayers. I welcome the Assistant Treasurer's positive response to that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 is yet another omnibus bill. As has already been pointed out, this bill proposes to amend four separate acts. Overall, it has 20 separate amendments. I intend to examine only several of those amendments, as the time allocated for this debate does not allow the canvassing of all those amendments.

PARA.TAB: Division 7 involves a change in the provisional tax uplift factor, reducing the rate from the present 10 per cent to eight per cent for the 1994-95 financial year. This proposal was foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the budget statements of this year. Before I go further, I point out that, at either 10 per cent or eight per cent, the historical reason for having an uplift factor, which is for the purpose of assessing provisional tax obligation, has been overlooked and disregarded. It has been consigned to history.

An uplift factor to provisional tax assessments allowed the Taxation Office to keep pace with inflation. In other words, inflationary expectations were to be reflected in the uplift factor so that the tax office would not get too far behind the main game and so that it would get what it saw as its first share. Several years ago, Labor managed to get our economy into a state where we were experiencing double digit inflation. We passed legislation in this House to give it the discretion to increase the uplift factor to 12 per cent. At eight per cent or at any figure in excess of the forecast rate of inflation this year, this amounts to nothing more than an unreasonable tax grab. The history of, and the reason for, an uplift factor has been totally ignored. It simply becomes another way of wringing a little more out of our taxpayers in the private business sector and, in particular, the proprietors of small businesses.

Income subject to provisional tax for a year of income is also subject to the provisional tax uplift factor. In other words, taxable income for the previous year is arbitrarily increased by the uplift factor for the purpose of calculating the current year's obligations. Provisional tax is calculated by applying the tax rates and the Medicare levy to the notionally increased income and by allowing for rebate and credit entitlements which are expected to be claimed or allowed in the provisional year of income.

While I support the government's move to reduce the uplift factor for this financial year, the coalition believes that it should be no more than the forecast rate of inflation. Of course, Labor insists that the uplift factor is highly desirable at this level because it accelerates revenue collection and improves the government's cash flow. Even though the government's cash flow has improved, the cash flow of affected businesses is made worse by an equal amount plus the compliance costs. This comes at a time when the government should be encouraging new investment to reduce the exceedingly high rate of unemployment by permitting reinvestment of cash surpluses in a way which would add to the strength of businesses, particularly that of smaller businesses.

The uplift factor is a hindrance that the business community can do without. At the very least, the factor should be linked to the forecast rise in average weekly earnings, which in 1994-95 is expected to be some 3.5 per cent. If linked to average weekly earnings or even CPI, the uplift factor would not be so arbitrary and it might, on the face of it, display some semblance of fairness. At present it does not.

Division 10 allows bequests of significant cultural value made to certain institutions to be tax deductible and exempt from the application of the capital gains tax provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. To be eligible for the deduction and capital gains exemption, a taxpayer needs to be issued with a certificate from the minister for arts which certifies the value of the bequests and gives the minister's approval for the tax concessions. The approvals are capped at $2 million per year.

The scheme is a worthwhile encouragement because we should be doing all that is reasonable to foster donations by bequests of items that have cultural or artistic value to galleries, libraries and museums. The only reservation that I have is the capping of approvals to a notional $2 million per annum. Consideration by the minister should be given to increase the capped amount if there is on offer in excess of $2 million worth of items of cultural or artistic value competing for ministerial certificates. If the $2 million cap is maintained where there is excessive demand for certificates, the attractiveness of the scheme will be severely limited.

Division 14 aims to encourage foreign companies to set up regional headquarters in Australia by offering tax concessions. These concessions were announced on 4 May 1994 in the white paper on employment and growth. That announcement was one part of the government's strategy to promote international investment and business linkages. The white paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: Regional headquarters (RHQs) provide a number of direct and indirect economic benefits to the Australian economy, generally stemming from the high skill and high wage jobs they generate.
The direct benefits come from expenditure on locally produced goods and services and the taxation revenue paid by the RHQs and their employees.
RHQs tend to have a strong demand for specialist professional services, telecommunications, international travel and data processing.
Indirect benefits come from management skills and know-how, the flow of business intelligence about markets in the region, and the ability to influence the parent company.

With Australia's comparatively well-trained work force, modern national infrastructure and other advantages, it is not surprising that foreign companies would consider placing their regional headquarters in Australia. I believe that this is an aim which the vast majority of Australians would support, and I have no doubt that that would be true of members on both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of potential regional headquarters in Australia is not all positive. Although these tax concessions are welcome, they will not in themselves create an environment which will see overseas companies flock to Australia to set up their regional headquarters. Other considerations intrude on decisions to be made by potential overseas companies with regional headquarter aspirations.

Our tax structure is still a major disincentive compared with those of Asian centres, particularly Singapore. The overall rates of taxation are a disincentive, and compliance costs compound that disincentive. Our rates of capital gains tax and the breadth of their application are also very unattractive. We could say the same about fringe benefits tax.

Naturally enough, a First World economy, such as that of Australia, does have higher levels of taxation than other nations that compete with us for regional headquarters. Our Asian competitors do not offer the same levels of social services as we do. We certainly do not advocate a reduction in our present levels of social welfare or our quality of life to those of our Australian competitors merely to facilitate competition for the location of RHQs in Australia.

Building upon our strengths, though, we can develop an environment more conducive to the setting up of regional headquarters in Australia. The government needs to do a lot more in terms of tax reform and tax simplification, and as well it needs to re-examine its expenditures with the aim of reducing the overall tax burden.

The frequency with which tax amendment bills come before this place only adds to the level of uncertainty as to what is Australia's tax law. Every time another tax bill comes before this place it causes increased problems for tax professionals, accountants and those who are expected to comply with the provisions of the various taxation acts. It is tax professionals, accountants and lawyers who have to scan the multitude of tax laws and try to make sense of them. They in turn advise those who might want to set up regional headquarters in Australia.

However, the real victim of our national tax debacle is small business.
