Proprietors of small firms would much prefer to be able to tend to their own bookkeeping, leaving accountants to examine the books only at certain times of the year and specifically after the end of the financial year. Unfortunately, because of the constant changing of the tax laws, small business proprietors need to constantly consult with tax experts. This is an added cost which is part of the compliance cost that I have referred to time and again that small business can well do without.

Further, as I have stated on other occasions, compliance costs are higher for the small business sector. With Australia probably having the highest compliance costs in the world on all businesses, costs to small businesses within that overall high range are even higher than the average within it. For example, small firms with a turnover of under $500,000 spend on average three per cent of their turnover complying with taxation rules compared with 0.02 per cent for companies with a turnover in excess of $50 million.

Compliance costs generated by the current tax system clearly discriminate against small business. The government is driving businesses into the arms of tax professionals because small business proprietors no longer have any confidence in and cannot possibly comprehend the tax system. This is not too difficult to understand, as I am sure you will agree, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Uncertainty about the current tax system is endemic. Nothing but a complete overhaul of the tax system will suffice to instil in small business proprietors a new and renewed confidence in the tax system. The problems of the system have been mentioned in this place too many times to recall, yet Labor's approach to tax reform is more ad hoc now than at any other period since it has been on the treasury bench. The government has no strategy to tackle the problems in the tax system.

The uncertainty in tax law and many of the resultant problems are due to frequent legislative changes, the severity of compliance costs and the sheer volume of current tax laws in their complex entirety. At this stage, of course, it is not possible to go into great depth on these matters. I have already canvassed the issues on several occasions this year alone.

However, I cannot let the opportunity go by without congratulating the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) for publicly letting it be known that the tax system is a disaster. The honourable member's recent actions are an implicit acknowledgment that the government's talk of simplifying the tax system has been and remains a sham. For those members of the House not familiar with the honourable member's contribution I shall inform them of it.

The honourable member in a letter to the taxpayers in his electorate dated 9 August 1994 announced that he has set aside part of his electorate office for the use of a tax office trained consultant to `assist people with preparing fairly straightforward non-business returns'. He opened the letter with the statement, `The many rules regulating our taxation system can appear confusing.' You can say that again. Yes, Australia's tax system is obviously so confusing that the constituents of the electorate of Brisbane cannot fill out what should be, but is not, a simple tax return.

We should ask the obvious question: what has the member for Brisbane or any of his colleagues who agree with him, if there are any, done to rectify the problems with our tax system? The member for Brisbane has been sitting in this place since 1990 and is currently a parliamentary secretary, yet to date he has shown no inclination to attempt to rectify the government's shoddy approach to taxation policy and legislation. It is sheer hypocrisy for any government member to attempt to capitalise on the poor performance of his or her own government. The great positive is that he recognises that there is a problem, which is more than can be said for the rest of his colleagues, including ministers.

The recent government announcement that it intends to establish a taxpayers' charter of rights, a taxation ombudsman and a small taxation claims tribunal is a welcome development, but it will not go to the cause of our tax malaise. These measures only tackle the symptoms of an overcomplex tax system. The government's announcement of these measures is a response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

The committee also recommended the ATO be given a board of commissioners that would run a renamed Australian tax commission. It was recommended the board should comprise the tax commissioner as well as business figures, accountants and tax lawyers who would serve as part-time commissioners. I do not support the concept of a board of commissioners—believing it to be window-dressing—though I do support the maintenance of taxpayer advisory groups to provide avenues for the Australian Taxation Office to consult widely on tax issues.

As to the proposed taxpayers' charter of rights, I can only hope it will be a meaningful exercise and not just a public relations stunt. If so, it will have my wholehearted support as, to the best of my knowledge, I was probably the first member in this House and probably in this parliament to have advocated several years ago the adoption of a charter of rights. In the last few years there has been increasing support for the concept of a taxpayers' bill of rights which would seek to give legislative codification of the rights of taxpayers and the duties and obligations of the Australian Taxation Office.

The United States enacted a taxpayers' bill of rights in 1988. That bill requires the US Internal Revenue Service to inform taxpayers of their rights and obligations particularly prior to audit interviews; regulate the conduct of audit interviews; waive penalties that arise from IRS errors; obtain the views of small business administration on its tax regulations and increase the liability of the IRS to prosecution for a range of errors.
In April 1993 the Taxation Institute of Australia prepared a taxpayers' bill of rights. In the foreward to the bill John Tucker, president of the TIA, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is essential that taxpayers as citizens be assured that their rights under the tax system are inalienable under our system of government.
He went on to say:

The intention of the taxpayers' bill of rights is to make taxpayers aware of their existing rights under the tax system and also to set minimum standards in respect of those matters that are not presently reflected in our tax system.

It is proposed that the taxpayers' bill of rights should have the force of law, and existing taxation legislation should be read as subject to it, so that where an inconsistency occurs, the taxpayers' bill of rights will take precedence.

The TIA also recommended 11 rights to which taxpayers should be entitled. Those 11 rights include the right to reasonable certainty under the tax law in respect of their liability for tax—that certainly does not apply now; equal treatment under the law and by the tax office as well as fair and courteous treatment by the tax office; privacy in respect of their taxation affairs; and a tax ombudsman who shall have access to the necessary resources to enable the investigation and resolution of all matters taxpayers may bring before his office.

PARA.TAB: The first of those rights from the TIA is crucial. As the laws now stand, very few taxpayers are certain, or can be certain, of their tax liabilities under the law. This is simply because the tax laws are far too complex and it is only tax specialists who are able to interpret them. Where there is uncertainty under the law, the benefit of the doubt should be given to taxpayers. I am looking forward to the public unveiling of the proposed taxpayers' charter of rights. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is an omnibus bill which has covered a very wide range of issues in the taxation area. In this debate I would like to draw the attention of the House to one of the areas which has been ignored in the bill rather than contained in it. I would like to start by referring to the observations made by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his second reading speech. He said:

PARA.TAB: Since the introduction of the new sales tax on 1 January 1993, the Australian Taxation Office, in conjunction with business and other affected parties, has been reviewing the operation of the tax. The government has been pleased to find that the vast majority of provisions are operating very well. However, there are some that would be best handled by legislative amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is one of the purposes of this legislation. One of the points he raised which was very valid and totally appropriate was the growing industry in Australia for repairing goods for overseas owners. He also made the point that it is developing a market for used Australian goods which have been refurbished. He said:

The law will be amended to allow a credit for parts, fittings and accessories used in the repair, renovation or upgrading of goods to be exported, provided the tax is not passed on in the price of the alterations. The credit will apply to tax borne on parts used after 1 January 1993.

The matter at issue, however, is the question of sales taxation in regard to the remanufacture of products in Australia which are subsequently sold to government agencies or other non-government agencies which in the past have received tax deduction arrangements. This act has totally ignored that area.

PARA.TAB: It is the contention of a growing market and a growing industrial sector in Australia that the system as currently applied is inconsistent. As I have just pointed out, where goods are repaired and sold overseas, no sales tax is applied. However, where the same goods are repaired and sold in Australia to organisations which previously were tax exempt, that is no longer the case. The interesting thing is that under the old tax credit arrangements that would not have been so. Those companies, or in this case federal, state and local governments, or non-government agencies such as welfare organisations, which received or purchased repaired goods would have received a tax deduction up to the quantity of tax paid on those components which were part of the remanufacture process.

When this matter first came before the government, the general view seemed to be somewhat mixed, to say the least. There was a view, which has been put to me by officers of the Taxation Office, that the whole thing was just a mistake. They told me, `Of course this should be in this act. Of course this was just missed.' They said there was no reason why it should not be there and, of course, if we, the opposition, wished to proceed with amendments to this matter to reintroduce it into this act, it would have their blessing.

Unfortunately, following further discussions I had today with the minister's office, that is not the case. I have been told by the government and by the minister's office that they will not be supporting these proposals. Unfortunately, they did not give me any decent reason why that is so. Suffice it to say that their major concern seems to be a loss of revenue. The interesting thing is that, as we are told in the explanatory memorandum and throughout this entire bill before the House—under virtually every single clause—there will be a minimum effect on revenue. We are even told that in the context of repairing for overseas owners goods which are for export there is a minimum effect on taxation.

I think it would be reasonable, therefore, having reached a conclusion, to ask the following question: if all these other clauses in the bill are minimal in terms of their effect on tax, how is it that a proposal to reapply in the act a condition which is virtually identical to what was previously in the act is somehow or other going to involve a massive loss of revenue because of the build-up in Australia of a more efficient industry involved in remanufacture? Clearly the logic of this case as presented by the government simply does not stand up.

What we are trying to achieve is a sales tax credit in respect of parts used in the remanufacture of goods which are then sold or leased to government departments, exempt government agencies and other exempt non-profit organisations. They include schools, libraries, hospitals and other charitable organisations. That is only consistent with what has always been the case with the removal of sales tax arrangements in Australia on the purchase of new equipment or on the purchase of remanufactured equipment, which by definition contains some components which are new.

The position is even more complex when we consider that this act and the act which preceded it identified quite clearly a whole range of industries, especially mining and agriculture—of which, you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be well aware—where all purchasers in those industries, including purchases of spare parts for farm or mining equipment, do carry with them the right not to have to pay sales tax. I put the view to the House that where a purchaser chooses to purchase new equipment—often imported, with all the effect that that has on Australia's balance of payments—as distinct from remanufactured equipment, clearly there is no balance. The fact that it is ignored in this legislation guarantees that we have anything except a level playing field, which we were told by the government on many occasions was meant to be one of the bases of its economic policy.

To realise the benefits of remanufacturing in the Australian economy, let me put them on record. Firstly, the local and overseas remanufacturing industry, while it is still small in Australia, is growing and is capable of growth, provided it is given a taxation regime which is consistent. The whole purpose of my amendment is to try to reintroduce that degree of consistency which has been deliberately—as I now discover—left out by the government for no good reason. We are all aware, as pointed out by the minister in his second reading speech, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia has a burgeoning industry in repairing goods for overseas owners. It is also developing a market for used Australian goods which have been refurbished. The law will be amended to allow a credit for parts, fittings and accessories used in the repair, renovation or upgrading of goods to be exported, provided the tax is not passed on in the price of the alterations.

That is splendid, and the opposition totally supports that approach and policy, but the question we put before the House is: why stop at exports? If the government is serious about creating a viable domestic industry which has the capacity to develop a wide export sales arrangement, surely it also needs the capacity to negotiate sales on a level playing field basis within the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand we know there is a growing overseas demand for remanufactured goods. We also know there is a growing potential demand for remanufactured goods in Australia. One of the real advantages is that in most cases those remanufactured goods in Australia are substituted for imported goods or remanufactured goods. Therefore, there is a deliberate saving to Australia's balance of payments in that context.

In addition to that, remanufactured goods produced in Australia are labour intensive. They create employment opportunities. At question time today we heard the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) making the point that the government is not satisfied with the level of unemployment in Australia—and certainly it should not be! Surely on those grounds alone every effort must be made to achieve the level playing field of which I speak so that remanufactured products in Australia have the same capacity to be traded and, therefore, to be able to save us our balance of payments problems and at the same time create jobs in Australia.

Would somebody in the government please tell me the benefit to this country of companies such as IBM or Xerox creating jobs overseas. How many jobs will be created in our industries if we deliberately put into law arrangements which do not make it economically viable to develop new industries, such as remanufacturing, in our country?

Another point which is well worth noting is that, by definition, remanufacturing involves the recycling of goods, which in turn means savings in energy and materials. It certainly reduces waste disposal and, therefore, has significant environmental effects. We are again told by the government that it is interested in all these issues. If it is interested, surely we should be taking every opportunity in every aspect of industrial endeavour to reuse second-hand goods, to replace the parts which need to be replaced and to then put those products back on the market. Alternatively, they will go to the rubbish heap.

Those living in a city like Sydney know only too well that the largest component of rubbish in our society does not come from the domestic user; it comes from industry. Much of that industry produces precisely the unused, second-hand or third-hand goods which cannot be utilised because remanufacturing has not been given the opportunities that it should. My point is clearly this: to realise those benefits to the Australian economy and to enable us to have a stronger manufacturing industry, we must be able to provide the springboard to exploit import substitution to the full and to develop our export opportunities.

As I said, we support the provisions in the bill in relation to export opportunities. There must be no internal inhibitions to being able to optimise local demand. At the same time, we need to be able to see the opportunities to build up this new remanufacturing sector within Australia so that it can reduce our demand on imports and, at the same time, play a larger role in export substitution and be able to build up overseas markets.

Ultimately, we are talking about the need for best practice and an internationally competitive policy, which, by definition, means that we have to remove taxation distortions and not place them in the system, as we are seeing in this case. Above all, we have to remove those disincentives from the remanufacturing industry if we expect it to achieve government policy objectives, as stated in the minister's second reading speech here today, in return for the repairing of goods for overseas owners. We want to do that, but we also want to be able to repair and remanufacture goods for Australian producers as well, and that is where the government has completely missed the boat.

The issue is really wider than that. If we are going to have a consistent policy for sales tax law, surely we should have a series of exemptions in place which provide for the same group of people over a long time and about which, therefore, people in the marketplace would be aware. Unfortunately, nothing in this material that is associated with the introduction of the streamlined sales tax law suggests that parts for goods sold or leased should be removed from exemption. Yet, as I said, I was told that it was just a mistake, that it should be there and that there would be support if it were put there. However, that assertion will stand until we actually get around to implementing it. The Treasury and others will then come up with all these interesting arguments about why it should not be so.

The bottom line is simply this: among the largest users of remanufactured office equipment are the three levels of government in Australia. If we do not remove these components from the need to pay sales tax, it simply follows that the end price will be that much higher. What is the benefit of that? I suppose that the Department of Finance or the Treasurer (Mr Willis) will argue that we are robbing Peter to pay Paul. It is really not as simple as that. Firstly, the company selling the goods has to increase its price; secondly, the department, in its annual appropriations, has to ask parliament for more money; and, thirdly, at the end of the day, I seriously question whether the revenue base has really made any difference. As I pointed out, we are told that in every other case in this bill the effects on revenue are minuscule. So perhaps there has been, to say the least, a misplacement of priorities in this matter.

The sales tax treatment of parts used in remanufactured goods which are subsequently sold or leased has always previously been available to a specified range of consumers. Sales tax is payable on parts used to repair goods that are subsequently sold. However, where the same goods are sold as business inputs to the mining, primary production and manufacturing industries, a credit for the sales tax is provided under credit ground 22 of schedule 1 to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992. Similarly, an exemption from sales tax is also available where goods which are remanufactured or repaired overseas are imported into Australia and sold to always exempt users.

We have the most extraordinary situation. One can import goods, sell them to exempt users and apparently get the sales tax provision, but remanufactured Australian goods that are sold to the same person do not get the sales tax provision applied. The logic of that completely escapes me.

A sales tax credit is proposed by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which we are debating, for parts used in repairing goods that are subsequently exported. All I am trying to get the House to accept—I doubt I will succeed with the government, but one can only try; logic is one's strongest weapon in these cases—is that, if we are repairing goods which are subsequently exported, a position which we totally support, how can the government seriously and logically argue that no tax should be applied in that case but that such goods should be taxed if they are used in Australia and are therefore not exported? I make this point especially because, prior to the reformation of the sales tax regime, similar goods sold domestically to a range of exempt persons or organisations would not have attracted the tax. So changes took place and nobody was told about them. All we were told was that a terrible mistake had been made and that somebody should rectify it. We tried to rectify it, but we were told that people do not want to hear about it.

I will clarify what we are talking about in terms of remanufacturing. Remanufacturing refers to the industrial process whereby worn-out products are restored to a like-new condition through reconditioning or refurbishment. Accordingly, what we are seeking in relation to this amendment is that parts used in remanufacturing or for repairing goods that are subsequently sold should remain tax exempt for exempt users. As I said, prior to the introduction of the streamlined sales tax regime, which commenced on 1 January 1993, spare parts used in repairs were treated as exempt from sales tax when the prepared goods were sold or leased in exempt circumstances, including sales to and leases by exempt users. The whole issue is: why should the new provisions ignore those people who have been previously covered?

In December 1993, amendments were made by the Senate to introduce section 15C and credit ground 22 into the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992. That allowed the recovery, retrospective to the commencement of the new sales tax law, of the sales tax paid on parts used in the repair of goods where the goods were subsequently sold into the mining, agriculture or manufacturing industries for use as an exempt business input. The recent proposal to introduce credit ground 23 to apply effectively from 1 January gives a similar credit with respect to spare parts used in goods that are remanufactured or repaired and subsequently exported. But, as I said, no additional provision has been made for goods sold domestically.

The sales tax treatment of parts used in remanufactured goods in Australia, as opposed to overseas, is clearly acting as a disincentive for the remanufacturing industry in this country. Above all, this industry has to be looking for economies of scale. Those economies of scale cannot depend entirely on export capacity. That capacity will grow, but only in line with the capacity of that industry to build up a similar level of industrial output for utilisation in the Australian market. We are talking about a world market and a holistic approach from the point of view of the manufacturers. They will not do something because of some export potential. They have to develop a product range which can be sold in both Australia and overseas.
I conclude by foreshadowing the following amendments circulated in my name, which I will discuss further in the consideration in detail stage:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to one aspect of Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 3) Bill. I am glad the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) is with us tonight since I will be proposing some amendments that relate to one particular area of amendments covered by this bill. Those are the amendments referred to in chapter 4 of the explanatory memorandum under `Social Security payments' dealing with the home child-care allowance and dependent spouse rebate.

PARA.TAB: I note that tonight the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who addressed this bill, raised for the first time some additional matters, largely by ambush in a sense because neither the shadow minister who is responsible for this bill nor I were aware that the government intended to propose certain changes. But those changes obviously indicate that the government is becoming increasingly aware of the very considerable disquiet surrounding the way in which it has implemented these changes and the sleight of hand that was involved.

The minister who addressed the matter indicated that the government would be proposing some amendments to the bill to provide that where a spouse of a taxpayer qualifies for the home child-care allowance the taxpayer will not be entitled to claim the without child dependent rebate through the tax system but that the government considers that families should be able to fall back on the without child dependent spouse rebate if they qualify. The government indicated that it will be moving amendments to the bill in the Senate to allow taxpayers to claim the without child dependent spouse rebate instead of claiming the home child-care allowance.

The import of that is that there will be savings, I suppose, in the way this matter is dealt with, because the without child dependent spouse rebate—as revealed in the explanatory memorandum and is known, I think, to most members—is paid at a lower rate than the amount paid if the claimant had a child. The two amounts for the dependent spouse rebate are $1,188 if you do not have a child and $1,425 if you do. In effect, if a person is left claiming the dependent spouse rebate on the without child rate, the amount will be substantially lower than the home child-care allowance if it were claimed.

That brings us to the very question that was raised when the home child-care allowance bill was before the parliament—the identification of those sorts of people who were unlikely to benefit from this new allowance or who would receive a substantially lower benefit from this allowance than they presently receive for the dependent spouse rebate. The dependent spouse rebate is paid under rules relating to the determination of income and income testing under the taxation law of Australia and the new home child-care allowance is paid through the Social Security Act in which income is assessed in a very different way, particularly in relation to the income of the spouse who is largely dependent.

When I spoke on this matter before, I identified a number of classes of families who would be worse off. The government did not see fit to identify those, but some of them included families who are overseas for longer than 13 weeks. I mentioned in particular that that could include aid workers, missionaries, academics, exchange students—a number of people who go away for longer periods than 13 weeks—who continue to pay tax in Australia and who might claim the dependent spouse rebate. Those people would not be eligible for the home child-care allowance and would no longer be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate at the rate payable for those who have children. I think I identified that they would be $372 a year worse off.

There are also families with children who are dependent full-time students aged 18 to 25 years whose income is less than $1,785 a year. Families might receive prescribed student payments and be disqualified from the home child-care allowance as a result of the more onerous social security income definitions. One of the income definitions of other family payments that people had not readily appreciated applies in the social security area, will apply to the home child-care allowance but does not apply at the moment, as I understand it, is the government's unrealised capital gains test which is applied by way of deeming any such gains as income for the purposes of the application of the income test used by the Department of Social Security.

These unrealised capital gains or managed investments and shares might be owned by a dependent spouse. They will get notional income from it which is still deemed to be income and can reduce their eligibility for the home child-care allowance. If the person were still receiving a dependent spouse rebate where the normal arrangements for assessing capital gains occur under the tax act, that gain that perhaps can occur would be taken into account at the time when somebody actually realised their assets and they would be considered in the normal way that capital gains are treated under the tax act.

Others are going to be adversely affected by this approach that the government has taken. Those clients on jobsearch allowance in particular worry me greatly. Their partners will now receive a partner allowance but will not be eligible, as I understand it, for the home child-care allowance because the partner allowance will put them over the income limit, despite the fact that both partners are in fact unemployed.

We have a situation where the very form of payment that ought to be available to supplement the income for carers at home will not be available in a situation where there are two people in the household who are unable to obtain employment. People have reported that they have previously relied upon the dependent spouse rebate so that they would not receive a tax bill. That was significant in reducing their tax liabilities because the dependent spouse rebate was claimable. In future, because an allowance is now payable, it will alter the very basis upon which their personal circumstances are assessed for tax purposes and will lead to a tax obligation.

There are some people who receive very irregular incomes who have preferred the dependent spouse rebate because it made it very much easier for them to reconcile their financial affairs at the end of a year. When they are making their claims on their tax return they are finally able to assess what their income is, even though it may have been fluctuating during the year.

In relation to the home child-care allowance, people are required to estimate their income over four 13-week periods. There is a difficulty that, with fluctuations in income, the amount that they receive will vary. If they have had a particularly high quarter they may get very little in the way of an allowance but, at other times, when their income has fallen away they would get the full allowance, but it does not make up for the allowance lost in the period in which their income was fluctuating. Under the dependent spouse rebate those fluctuations would have been evened out.

It may be argued that the alternative will now be available to them. They can go back and rely upon the dependent spouse rebate under the amendment foreshadowed by the government tonight, but they would then not be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate that most closely relates to the home child-care allowance. They would be eligible for an amount that is paid at a considerably lower rate and the difference, as I identified before, was $372 in a year.

Cases of those who have been affected by these changes have been brought to my notice. There is a case involving a person on a carer's part pension which is means tested against her husband's income. She has been looking after her mother who has dementia. She has two children. She will now not be able to receive the home child-care allowance because the carer's part pension is taken as income for assessing her eligibility. The difference in that case is that she would receive only $27.10 per fortnight instead of the $60 that she now receives.

Other families that have relatively low income levels spread between two partners are in the same situation. Those families will be ineligible to receive a home child-care allowance. It may be that the two partners are involved in some part-time work but have relatively modest incomes. Their situation has to be contrasted with that of a person who might have a very high income and whose partner is not in the work force at all and where the dependent spouse rebate and the home child-care allowance would be available.

A number of people will be in a comparatively worse off situation as a result of the introduction of this new allowance. The government should ensure that if people do not qualify for the home child-care allowance they should be eligible to receive the dependent spouse rebate at the higher level at which they presently receive it, and that ought to be largely in the alternative. In reading the bill, one would think that that was what the government might have had in mind.

The purpose clause in the explanatory memorandum which refers to the objectives of this legislation says that it is intended to apply in situations where those who are going to be removed from the eligibility for this benefit qualify for the home child-care allowance payment. That suggests that if people notionally are disqualified for some particular reason—income testing or the like—they will still be eligible to receive the home child-care allowance. It may be that the purpose of the government's further amendment is to reflect that. But it does not put those people in the same position that they would have been in if the government had left a genuine alternative available to them. When we reach the committee stage I will be proposing an amendment—I think it has been circulated; if it has not been, it will be—to clause 56 of the bill. Clause 56(b) of the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: by omitting from column 2 in the table in subsection (2), in relation to class 1 in column 1, "Spouse" and substituting "Non-HCAA spouse".

I am not sure whether the term `non-HCAA' is correct in the bill. It is probably meant to be `non-HCCA'. That is a correction which those who look at these matters may care to note is required. Our approach to that would be to include as an alternative a clause (b) that states:
a spouse who received home child care allowance within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1991 in respect of the year of income or part of the year of income;
In relation to the definition that appears in clause 56(h), we would seek by way of amendment to substitute the following definition:

" ` "non-HCCA spouse" means a spouse who does not receive the home child care allowance within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1991 in respect of a year of income or part of a year of income;'.".

That definition would mean that if the person did not receive an allowance within that year he would be still eligible to receive the dependent spouse rebate at the higher level. At least that is the purpose of the amendment as I have drafted it. If we have failed in relation to that we will have a fresh look at it in the Senate. It is indicative of the sort of change that we believe would be appropriate. It is in the spirit of the amendments that we proposed when this matter was discussed in relation to the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill that we considered last year.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my remarks in relation to this matter by noting that these are the sorts of difficulties that arise when we try to be too smart by half. The government originally sought to obtain political capital out of introducing changes that were intended to suggest that the government was mindful of helping families in which the mother was at home. That was what it was seeking to demonstrate in the way in which it undertook, through its own promises, to change the system and to introduce a new home child-care allowance. The government's policy document for the 1993 election said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, a Keating government will increase the dependent spouse rebate and pay it directly to the spouse at home caring for children. The new Home Child Care Allowance will be $30 a week and will provide some source of independent income for women at home caring full-time for children.

No mention was made in that paragraph that any families currently receiving the dependent spouse rebate would be excluded from payments by that change. It was a sleight of hand. It was always a sleight of hand. The government was in effect taking a benefit—one which was largely available to most women who were staying at home looking after children—out of a concessional arrangement where the family benefited from it and cashing it out as an allowance in the social security system.

PARA.TAB: A number of families were going to be considerably worse off as a result of the way in which the government undertook that change. They were not identified and they still will not be dealt with adequately unless the government is prepared to adopt alternative amendments of the form that the opposition is proposing. I encourage the government, in the time it has left between when this bill is no doubt passed here and considered in the Senate, to entertain the sort of suggestions that the opposition is making as a more appropriate way of ensuring that the bill is equitable in the way it operates.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Coal and Iron Ore Exports: Related Services

TALK.START.PARA: —(7.35 p.m.)—I want to speak tonight about the failure of Australian coal and iron ore exporters to take up the opportunities to sell Australian services that go along with exports—services like freight forwarding, insurance dispute settlement, transport to the port and all related services. What we are seeing in this country is Australian exporters who are being consistently outwitted by Japanese steel mill customers.

PARA.TAB: The very contrast I want to make this evening is this: while Japanese steel mills insist on free market forces determining the purchase price of Australian coal on the eastern side of our continent, the same mills reserve the marine insurance market for Japanese insurance companies when transporting Australian iron ore to Japan. On the one hand they are saying, `open market for coal prices,' while on the other hand, where there are competitive Australian firms available who want to compete on cargo insurance on the west coast, that market is denied to Australian marine insurers.

The transport of coal to ship, sea freight, insurance and freight forwarding are all value adding services to the production and sale of coal. They are legitimate upstream and downstream extensions of coal production. It is amazing that Australian coal exporters in effect seek the minimum return on coal exports to Japan by selling f.o.b.—free on board—and not seeking CIF—or cost, insurance and freight-sales. We see in the Bevis report on government purchasing that even Australian government agencies are not following government guidelines on seeking opportunities to buy f.o.b. from abroad and to sell CIF out of Australia.

When we see that Australian coal exporters are in effect seeking the minimum return on coal exports to Japan by selling f.o.b., that contrasts starkly with Japan's vertical integration of the coal industry in the region that I come from—the Hunter. In the Hunter Japanese buyers of coal have invested in coal production. It gives them the guts of the industry—the cost structures. They know precisely what costs and margins there are in coal. They have also invested in coal loading; tug operations to move around the ships that are loading the coal; coal shipping to Japan; marine insurance; and, through associates, they are trying to transport coal by rail to port in the Hunter.

Clearly, the Japanese are outwitting the coal exporters. The coal exporters, with cap in hand, take the lowest possible return. The Japanese buyers, who are far more sophisticated in financial terms and in commercial operations, are there at every level of operation, value adding for themselves and denying Australia the opportunity. It is time that barriers to competitive Australian firms, competitive Australian marine insurers and service providers not having access to the coverage or carriage of our exports were abolished. It makes a mockery of competition when Japanese steel mills buy iron ore and demand, `Insurance of our iron ore is reserved to Japanese insurance companies, but the coal that we need to put with the iron ore has to be sold on an open market and open market forces should operate.' There is a direct contradiction, solely to the benefit of the Japanese and to the detriment of Australia.

There is a great need for Australian exporters to look beyond the minimum return on exports and work with other Australian firms and service providers to sell those services along with the products so that we are value adding to the basic product. It is the ineffectiveness of coal and iron ore exporters, particularly coal exporters, thus far in this respect that gives more substance to the campaign by mining unions for a fairer return on our coal exports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: In the Report of its inquiry into the charges of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) did the Prices Surveillance Authority recommend that it would be appropriate for the Industry Commission to consider issues relating to the organisation of Australia's airports with specific reference to a number of issues concerning the FAC; if so, will he refer the matter to the Industry Commission and if so, when.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The PSA in its inquiry into the aeronautical and non-aeronautical charges of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) recommended, inter alia, that:
"It would be appropriate for the Industry Commission to consider structural issues relating to the organisation of Australia's airports including:
the composition of airports owned and operated by the FAC, particularly in relation to divestiture of some airports;
the relationship between the Government and the FAC, including the use of formal directives and composition of the FAC Board;
identification of the natural monopoly elements of the FAC's operations;
whether or not the FAC should be competing in the provision of terminals, given its monopoly position in the operation of runways; and
the scope of the FAC's non-aeronautical functions, with particular attention to activities not centrally related to aviation responsibilities."

As the Prime Minister announced in the `Working Nation' statement of 4 May 1994, the Government is proposing to sell all FAC airports over the period 1995-96 to 1997-98, subject to the outcome of a Scoping Study and to the necessary amendments to the Labour Party Platform.
There will be no commitment to the sale of particular airports before the Government's consideration of the Scoping Study.

The Government will also develop an ownership-neutral regulatory regime for airports. This will ensure that the purchasers of the airports are not able to abuse any market power arising from the monopoly characteristics of airport services.
It will also set appropriate limitations on ownership and will ensure proper protection of the environment, security and safety.
In addition, the `Working Nation' statement announced that the Government would introduce reforms to improve the FAC's investment and pricing decisions.

The Working Nation announcement took into consideration the recommendations of the PSA, as well as a review of the FAC's capital structure which covered a number of the issues that the PSA had envisaged being examined by the Industry Commission.

In both cases the WST would have made Sydney less competitive than Singapore and the other competing locations for the centre. The Government's decision was taken in the light of the perceived national benefits of Cathay Pacific's and Data General's investments.

The concession is restricted to sales tax on used equipment to be relocated to Australia and which has been owned for not less than nine months. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Bureau of Statistics: Data Series

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has the Australian Bureau of Statistics discontinued its data series on the cost of living in capital cities; if so, (a) when did it discontinue the series, (b) why did it do so, (c) what data does the Government now use to measure the cost of living in Australia's cities and regions and (d) what proposals are there to reintroduce the series.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a),(b),(c) and (d) The ABS has never produced a data series purporting to measure the cost of living in capital cities although the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and related statistics are frequently referred to in this vein. The CPI, which measures the change over time in prices paid by household consumers for the goods and services they buy, is constructed separately for each of the eight capital cities and a "national" index is derived as the weighted average of the eight capital city indexes. There are no plans to change this situation.

In addition to the CPI, the ABS also produced Indexes of Relative Retail Prices of Food, Australian Cities and Towns up to and including 1990. These indexes, which were compiled in respect of approximately 130 cities and towns (including the eight capital cities), provided measures of differences in prices between localities at a particular date, in contrast to the CPI which measures differences in prices over time in a particular locality. However, their coverage was limited to items of food (accounting for approximately 20 per cent of total household expenditures).

In the context of a forward work program review, corporate funding for this collection was withdrawn after the completion of the 1988 survey. However, the survey was conducted for a further two years (1989 and 1990) as a user funded survey. The principal users, which were the Department of Industrial Relations, Telecom and Australia Post, withdrew their support following the completion of the 1990 survey.

When considering questions pertaining to the cost of living, the data used by the Government very much depends on the task at hand. The most widely used indicator is the CPI although, as noted above, this is not strictly speaking a measure of the cost of living. The components of the CPI can also be used where appropriate. For example, an analysis of the increasing costs of health care would use relevant data from the CPI.
There are several other sets of statistics produced by the ABS which can be used to assess some particular aspects of the cost of living.

Average prices (rather than price indexes) for a range of items included in the CPI are published quarterly for each of the eight capital cities in Average Retail Prices of Selected Items; Eight Capital Cities (ABS catalogue number 6403.0).

Details of rents paid by households throughout Australia are provided by the five-yearly population census. An advantage of obtaining information from this source is that it can be provided for very small areas, thereby supplementing the broader State and capital city data available from other sources.

Household expenditure surveys are currently conducted about every five years (the most recent survey relates to 1993-94 financial year and results are expected in early 1995). They provide detailed information on the spending patterns of households; these data can be cross classified with other variables such as income and family size to provide cost of living details for different household groups. Small area data are synthesised by using household expenditure survey data in conjunction with population census data.

In addition to data provided by the Australian Statistician, the Government has other sources of information available to it. The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) regularly monitors the prices of many goods and services (such as petrol and postage rates) on a regional basis and individual Departments also monitor changes in certain sectors. For example, the Department of Human Services and Health monitors changes in private health insurance contributions. Where it is deemed appropriate, the Government can commission special enquires to collect data on the cost of the provision of certain goods and services. For example, the PSA has recently conducted an enquiry into the provision of health services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has her attention been drawn to claims by (a) the Australian Private Hospitals Association, (b) Mr John Deeble and (c) Access Economics that private health insurance reforms proposed by her predecessor would increase private health insurance premiums by 13 per cent, 15 per cent and 23 per cent, respectively.

(2) Has her attention also been drawn to an estimate by private hospitals in the electoral Division of Adelaide that their administrative costs would increase under the proposals by 15 to 30 per cent.
(3) Are the proposals designed to destroy the existing system.
(4) Does the Government intend that all medical and hospital payments within the public and private sectors be financed by a single national insurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)-(c) I am aware of claims by the Australian Private Hospitals Association (APHA), Dr John Deeble and Access Economics that private health insurance premiums would increase under the reforms proposed by my predecessor. I do not believe that these claims are correct. For the most part, such claims are based on misinterpretations of the proposed reforms.

The APHA, for example, has overstated the number of coders who will be needed throughout the hospital system under the proposed reforms. Many private hospitals (68%) are already compiling and coding information, which leads to a much lower requirement for new coders than claimed by the APHA. In addition, the APHA has overstated the information technology requirements of the proposed reforms. Many of the larger hospitals already have adequate information technology systems in place; for insurance funds, processing capacity would not need to be increased. The claim that an average private hospital would need a further two staff to perform tasks such as auditing and peer review is incorrect. Additional staff would only be required if a hospital's current quality assurance practices are inadequate, because changes are only proposed to the form of the information required, not the amount.

Dr Deeble's estimates relating to the impact of the proposed reforms on private insurance premiums have not, to my knowledge, been presented with any detail as to the method of calculation. I understand that he has extrapolated from current insurance levels at less than top cover, and calculated the increase in premiums which would be required to provide top cover. This does not take into account the full range of the proposed reforms and the scope for considerable efficiencies in operations, driven particularly by more effective market forces.

Access Economics have claimed that increasing the dollar value of public hospital bills would require an increase in administration costs of $150 million to $200 million, although the actual number of claims would not increase. The Access Economics claims (at the behest of the AMA) are based on the incorrect assumption of the introduction of US-style managed care.

My Department has modelled the reforms proposed by my predecessor, and has found that for those with an average level of private health insurance, there should be no increase in the level of premiums for private health insurance under the proposed reforms. I therefore disagree with the claims of the APHA, Dr John Deeble and Access Economics.

(2) I am aware of claims that administrative costs would increase under the proposed reforms; however as stated above, I believe that for the most part, these claims are based on misinterpretations of the reforms. I find claims that costs will rise in the Adelaide region particularly interesting, given that the APHA has claimed that South Australian private hospitals currently have contracts with most payers (that is, the private health insurance funds).

(3) No. The ultimate objective of the reforms is to provide an improved product for consumers who choose to retain private health insurance. This will be achieved by providing the framework for a more efficient industry.
(4) The question of a single national insurer is not being considered.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Health Risks: Insecticide Spraying of Aircraft

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern expressed by the US Transportation Secretary, Mr Pena, regarding the requirement that passenger compartments of aircraft entering Australia be sprayed with insecticides before landing.
(2) What sprays are used and for what purpose is the spraying undertaken.
(3) Are there any health risks associated with the spraying; if so, what are they.
(4) Will he consider permitting spraying to be carried out when passengers and crew are not aboard the aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, I am aware of the concern expressed by Mr Pena about spraying of aircraft entering Australia with insecticides. Mr Pena has written to my colleague the Minister for Transport on the matter and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Department of Transport have contributed to a reply which has been sent to Mr Pena from the Minister.

(2) The sprays used for disinsection of aircraft cabin and hold spaces are the synthetic pyrethroids permethrin and d'phenothrin which are administered by either manual spraying or applied as a residual spray. Manual spraying is carried out by cabin crew using permethrin prior to each flight and d'phenothrin during flight. The alternative is to apply a solution of permethrin and distilled water to cabin and hold surfaces every eight weeks. Both of these products are recommended for this purpose by the World Health Organisation.

The sprays are used to prevent the entry of hard and soft bodied insects which may present potentially serious threats to human, agricultural or environmental health or may carry potentially serious disease-causing organisms.
(3) Published data indicates that these products have extremely low toxicity for humans and there are no known health risks associated with their use in aircraft if they are administered correctly.

(4) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has convened a group of relevant agencies and experts to examine Australia's disinsection requirements and procedures. Amongst other matters, that group is examining all aspects relating to allowing spraying to be undertaken only when passengers and crew are not aboard the aircraft. Residual spraying can only be done in an empty aircraft as all surfaces are covered.

(vii) what charges were imposed on users of the services;

(ix) what sum did the Department make available for shipping and handling services to (A) Christmas Island and (B) Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the period;

(xi) was there any official or unofficial policy that the services be operated on a partial or full cost-recovery basis, if so, what are the details; and

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Prior to February 1988 the (now) Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories was not involved with the actual provision of shipping services to Christmas Island or the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Before that date Christmas Island shipping services were operated by the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island (PMCI) and Cocos Islands shipping services were operated through the then Transport and Storage Group (TSG) of the now Department of Administrative Services (DAS).

During 1987 the Commonwealth called tenders (invitation 16 October, closing 19 November) for the operation of shipping services to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands for the 12-month period commencing 1 February 1988 to 31 January 1989. This tender was won by Stateships, the WA Coastal Shipping Commission.
With the closure of the phosphate mine from 1 January 1988, the Stateships service was extended to include Christmas Island, but this arrangement was separate from the Commonwealth's Cocos contract.

DEST then conducted a further tender process during 1988 for a total freight management system, including a combined shipping service to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. In February 1989, this resulted in the establishment of the Joint Islands Supply Service (JISS), with the operational aspects consolidated into an integrated service, and sea carriage component delivered by Stateships.
This contract continued to ensure shipping services to both islands from February 1989 to September 1993, when Stateships began a commercial shipping service to the islands.
(i) Sea carriage—fully containerised service.
(ii) the services were provided on:
(a)15/02/88 Christmas Island and Cocos
(b)21/07/88 Christmas Island and Cocos
(d)08/07/89 Cocos and Christmas
(iii) Sea carriage: Stateships
(iv) (a) and (b) Cocos—Sea carriage by Commonwealth contract.
Christmas—Sea carriage by arrangement between Wesfarmers and Stateships.
(iv) (c) and (d) Sea carriage to Cocos and Christmas under Commonwealth contract.
(v) (a) and (b) Cocos—Sea carriage: guaranteed $930,000 for a 6 weekly service between February 1988 and January 1989.
Christmas—Sea carriage; guaranteed $775,000 for a 6 weekly service between February 1988 and January 1989.
(c) and (d) Commercially based per container rates were determined by Stateships
(vi) Consignors of freight bore their own costs.

(vii) Commercially based cost recovery charges were imposed on the users of the services. The exact details sought by the honourable member are not readily available and would require considerable resources to extract and collate. I am therefore not prepared to direct that this work be undertaken.
(viii) (a) and (b) Yes.
TSG collected revenue from users for payment to Stateships in accordance with the contract to service the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
Wesfarmers Transport Group collected revenue from users for payment to Stateships in accordance with their arrangement to service Christmas Island.
(viii) (c) and (d) Yes.

Total West, the Commonwealth appointed Principal Cargo Agency collected revenue from users for payments to Stateships in accordance with their contract to service the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island.
(ix) The Department paid as a user of the service.
(x) Each sum was a fee for service.

(xi) Administratively the policy was to set charges at a level which would ensure that all costs associated with operating the services were fully recovered—rates would be reviewed and adjusted as required to reflect cost increases or other adjustments in the nature of the services provided.
(xii) Not applicable.

However, the JISS arrangements were internally audited on two occasions. Currently commercial auditors (Stanton and Partners) are auditing the total 4-1/2 years of JISS operations as part of the winding up of the system now that a commercial/liner terms shipping operation is in place.

Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements, including the role and functions of relevant agencies and ways of maximising cooperative effort
IDC review including DoF, AUSTRAC, PM&C, National Crime Authority, Attorney-General's Department and Australian Federal Police.
To identify the Commonwealth's objectives and options in relation to its involvement in law enforcement activities.
To ensure there is no overlap or confusion in relation to law enforcement agencies activities.

The creation of the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board which will provide strategic advice to the Government on law enforcement and facilitate links between government and law enforcement agencies. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Government withholding a sum of approximately $650,000,000 in unclaimed superannuation; if so, (a) what will the Government do with the sum if the owners cannot be found and (b) does the sum consist of funds belonging to persons working under false names.
(2) Does the Australian Taxation Office cross-reference tax file numbers with superannuation remittances; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Unclaimed benefits in superannuation schemes for Commonwealth employees (the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, Public Sector Superannuation scheme, Military Superannuation and Benefits scheme, and Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits scheme) total no more than $6 million. Private sector superannuation funds also hold unclaimed moneys in respect of `lost' members, although the dollar value of these benefits is not presently known. There is no basis known to the Government for a figure of $650 million in respect of `lost' superannuation entitlements.

(a) The Government is putting in place measures to enable lost members to trace and claim their benefits. The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (SIS) Act 1993 currently provides for the establishment of eligible rollover funds (ERFs). These concessionally taxed vehicles, approved by the ISC, will receive and manage `lost' member benefits and be required to capital guarantee their value. Trustees will be permitted to rollover a member's benefit to an ERF if a period of 90 days has elapsed since the benefit became payable. Trustees will be required under current SIS provisions to rollover a member's benefit where it is immediately payable and the trustees are satisfied that a member has not received fund reports for two consecutive years.

The SIS legislation currently also contemplates that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) will maintain a register of `lost' members whose benefits have been transferred to ERFs. People wishing to trace their `lost' superannuation benefits would be able to contact the ISC and have the register searched using their tax file number. They would then be able to arrange to have their moneys transferred to a fund of their choice, subject to application of the preservation rules as appropriate.

When `lost' members reach eligibility age for the age pension, the benefit would be paid to the Commonwealth as unclaimed moneys. Such members would continue to be able to reclaim their entitlements through the ISC register.

In my Superannuation Policy Statement of 28 June 1994, I announced measures which will expand the role of ERFs. For example, where funds do not wish to apply the member protection rules to account balances of less than $1,000 from 1 July 1995, they will be required to transfer these accounts to an ERF (or, with the member's consent, to another complying superannuation fund). In addition, funds which do agree to member protection will have the option of retaining `lost' amounts. In light of these changes, the ERF and unclaimed moneys processes set out in the SIS legislation are currently under review, but the Government expects arrangements to deal with the problem of `lost' moneys to be operational by end January 1995.

(b) Given that the `lost' member arrangements described above are not yet fully operational, the Government is not in a position to form a view on whether any portion of the sum of `lost' member moneys held in the private sector belongs to persons working under false names. However, the use of tax file numbers for tracing purposes, should assist in uncovering fraudulent activity of that kind.
(2) Yes, the Australian Taxation Office does cross-reference tax file numbers with superannuation remittances where the tax file number has been provided by the employer to the ATO.

Under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992, an employer who has not provided the minimum level of superannuation support must pay the Superannuation Guarantee Charge. In addition, the employer must lodge a Superannuation Guarantee Statement setting out certain details including, where known to the employer, the tax file number of the employee for whom the employer has an individual superannuation guarantee shortfall.

The tax file number provided by the employer is cross-referenced to ATO records to verify the identification of the employee before Superannuation Guarantee voucher is issued to the employee concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is sales tax exemption available for the purchase of four-wheel drive vehicles by professional kangaroo shooters for carrying out their business in the agricultural industry; if not, why not.
(2) What legislative changes are required to ensure the sales tax exemption referred to in part (1).
(3) Will he initiate the legislative changes referred to in part (2); if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 provides two types of sales tax exemptions for motor vehicles. First, there is a restricted exemption for certain types of four wheel drive vehicles used mainly in carrying out activities in the agricultural industry. Secondly, there is a sales tax exemption available to registered goods producers for general-purpose road vehicles (including two wheel drives) used exclusively within the production premises or used between adjacent production premises, or both.
Both types of exemptions are available to subcontractors in specific circumstances.

The exemption covering four wheel drive vehicles used in the agricultural industry is restricted to persons carrying out activities that are agricultural in nature such as cultivation of the soil and harvesting, but not to activities of a general purpose nature, such as fencing, bore sinking, earth moving or kangaroo shooting. This exemption is unique to the agricultural industry and represents an acceptance of the special needs of agriculturalists.

The exemption for general purpose passenger motor vehicles for subcontractors to goods producers, including for primary producers, applies to a wider range of vehicles than the exemption covering four wheel drive vehicles used in the agricultural industry. However, it is restricted to vehicles used exclusively within the production premises or in going between adjacent premises of the goods producer to whom they are subcontracting. To qualify for this exemption the vehicle must be used mainly in carrying out goods production activities on behalf of one or more goods producers.

The Government receives many representations for sales tax exemption. To grant all exemptions sought would be inconsistent with the Government's fiscal target. In addition, exemptions for certain persons or organisations impose administrative costs on wholesalers and retailers, are cumbersome to administer for the Australian Taxation Office, and open scope for abuse of the taxation system.
(2) Amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 would be required to extend the existing exemptions for motor vehicles.
(3) No, for the reasons outlined in the answer to (1).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 8 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that (a) 3000 Australians are waiting for organ transplants and (b) 20 per cent of those waiting for heart or liver transplants die before a donor can be found.

(2) Did the Government (a) agree to the national organ donation awareness campaign in 1993 through the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council and (b) undertake to provide $250 000 to the campaign.
(3) Is it a fact that a kidney transplant reduces the need for patient dialysis which costs on average between $30 000 and $40 000 per year.
(4) Has the Government now decided not to fund the $250 000 to the campaign; if so, why.
(5) Is 10 June 1994 National Organ Donation Awareness Day.
(6) Will the Government contribute the $250 000 to ensure the campaign succeeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) About 3000 people are on waiting lists for organ and tissue transplantation.
(b) Yes.

(2)(a) In 1993, the Commonwealth health officials on the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council accepted in principle a management plan submitted by the Australian Co-ordinating Committee on Organ Registries and Donation (ACCORD). That plan included an objective to increase public awareness of the benefits of organ donation and included a publicity campaign as one of the strategies for increasing the rate of organ donation.
The details of that publicity strategy were not detailed in the management plan. They were developed later by ACCORD.

(b) At no stage did Departmental officials or the Government undertake to provide funding for the campaign. When approached for funding, ACCORD was advised that funding would be a matter for the Government to consider in its 1994-95 Budget context.

(3) Kidney transplantation reduces demand for renal dialysis and is generally accepted as being cost effective compared to renal dialysis techniques. The cost of renal dialysis depends on the specific treatment modality and at what stage the costs are measured. A range of $20 000 to $40 000 would cover the on-going costs in the majority of cases.

(4) At no stage did the Government or the Department agree to fund the campaign. As part of its 1994-95 Budget considerations, the Government considered two requests for funding in relation to organ and tissue donation—the ACCORD publicity campaign and the provision of financial assistance to Australians who have to search overseas for a compatible bone marrow donor because none can be found in Australia. The Government accorded the latter the higher funding priority.

The Government was also concerned about the impact on the campaign of a debate in the community about the extent to which the family of a potential donor can ultimately decide whether organs are to be donated, even where a record of consent may exist. The legal, medical and emotional issues are complex and while they remain unresolved there is a risk that a major publicity campaign would fuel that debate and create confusion in the mind of the general public.
(5) Yes.
(6) The Government will not fund the campaign in 1994-95 but will reconsider the funding request for 1995-96, provided the issues referred to in (4) above have been clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he able to say whether Probus clubs perform a service to the retired community.
(2) Have Probus clubs lost income tax exemption through a ruling under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) In answering this question I have assumed that in referring to a "service", the honourable member has in mind the issue of whether Probus clubs are exempt from income tax under subparagraph 23(g)(v) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (the Act). That provision allows an exemption, inter alia, for non-profit organisations conducted for "community service purposes".

Probus clubs however are established to do no more than provide a social outlet for their members, who are drawn from retired and semi-retired business people, senior public servants and the like. The activities of the clubs are not of an altruistic character and so do not amount to "community service purposes" under subparagraph 23(g)(v) of the Act.

(b) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that some individual Probus clubs were granted exemption from income tax under subparagraph 23(g)(v) of the Act in 1991. These decisions were subsequently reviewed and, in 1992, the Commissioner ruled that this exemption did not apply to Probus clubs. As explained in part (a), Probus clubs have no special features to distinguish them from the activities of other clubs designed to provide mutual social benefits to members and are therefore not exempt from income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the anticipated increase in standard aggregated module funding (SAM) payable to nursing homes effective from 1 July 1994.
(2) What cost factors have been taken into account in the conclusion of SAM for 1994-95, including all relevant wage increases.
(3) What consultation with care providers and their associations was conducted in considering the 1994-95 adjustments to SAM.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The increase in SAM effective from 1 July 1994 was 49 cents per occupied bed day, as a result of indexation.

(2) SAM is indexed using a weighted average of the expected movements in the CPI and Average Award Weekly Rates (AAWR) indices. The indexation also takes into account the difference between the expected movements in these indices which were used to set SAM for the previous year, and the actual movements in the indices. This is the method of indexation established when SAM was introduced in 1987.
The indexation also takes into account:
the occupancy adjustment; and
the dependency adjustment based on measured movements in the Resident Classification Index, and in particular the responses to questions on incontinence management.
These adjustments were recommended by the SAM Review Report of September 1991 at the request of the industry, and accepted by the Government.
Actual wage changes are therefore not taken into account in indexing SAM.

(3) The method of calculation of the annual adjustment to SAM was established in consultation with the industry when SAM was introduced in 1987, and it was further refined in consultation with the industry in 1991.
When considering the annual variation to SAM, consultations are not conducted as the calculation is the application of an established method.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is sales tax exemption available for the purchase of four-wheel drive vehicles by (a) fencers, (b) bore sinkers and (c) earthmovers for carrying out their business in the agricultural industry; if not, why not.
(2) What legislative changes are required to ensure the sales tax exemptions referred to in part (1).
(3) Will he initiate the legislative changes referred to in part (2); if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 provides two types of sales tax exemptions for motor vehicles. First, there is a restricted exemption for certain types of four wheel drive vehicles used mainly in carrying out activities in the agricultural industry. Secondly, there is a sales tax exemption available to registered goods producers for general-purpose road vehicles (including two wheel drives) used exclusively within the production premises or used between adjacent production premises, or both.
Both types of exemptions are available to subcontractors in specific circumstances.

The exemption covering four wheel drive vehicles used in the agricultural industry is restricted to persons carrying out activities that are agricultural in nature such as cultivation of the soil and harvesting, but not to activities of a general purpose nature, such as fencing, bore sinking, earth moving or kangaroo shooting. This exemption is unique to the agricultural industry and represents an acceptance of the special needs of agriculturalists.

The exemption for general purpose passenger motor vehicles for subcontractors to goods producers, including for primary producers, applies to a wider range of vehicles than the exemption covering four wheel drive vehicles used in the agricultural industry. However, it is restricted to vehicles used exclusively within the production premises or in going between adjacent premises of the goods producer to whom they are subcontracting. To qualify for this exemption the vehicle must be used mainly in carrying out goods production activities on behalf of one or more goods producers.

The Government receives many representations for sales tax exemption. To grant all exemptions sought would be inconsistent with the Government's fiscal target. In addition, exemptions for certain persons or organisations impose administrative costs on wholesalers and retailers, are cumbersome to administer for the Australian Taxation Office, and open scope for abuse of the taxation system.
(2) Amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 would be required to extend the existing exemptions for motor vehicles.
(3) No, for the reasons outlined in the answer to (1).
