TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did recent cases involving canned tuna, gas metal arc welding wire and canned tomato dumping or subsidisation expose a weakness in Australian Customs Service (Customs) procedures whereby uncooperative foreign exporters are frustrating applications by Australian industries.
(2) Did the action of the foreign exporters equate to a veto over ACS procedures.

(3) Will the Government adopt the US statutory provision which requires the US Department of Commerce to use the best information available, including information provided by the affected US industry, when the foreign exporter refuses to provide a complete, timely and accurate response to the investigator's request for detailed information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There has been no weakness exposed in Australian Customs Service procedures by the cases cited in this question. Customs arrived at its findings in each of the cases by employing methods set out in the Customs legislation. Information was provided by exporters in each case and when considered sufficient for the purposes of the legislation, normal values were determined based on this information.
Part XVB of the Customs Act 1901 contains special provisions relating to anti-dumping duties and was enacted to implement those Articles of the GATT Code which deal with anti-dumping action.

The legislation provides a hierarchy of alternative methods for determining normal values in the country of export. These methods involve the use of domestic selling prices, selling prices to third countries and the cost to make and sell the goods in the country of export. The selling prices or costs arrived at by any of those methods are adjusted to ensure a proper comparison with the export price of the goods.

When sufficient reliable information has not been supplied by exporters or is not available to determine normal values using any other method, the normal value is determined using the best information available.

It must be pointed out that there is currently a case before the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act disputing the Anti-Dumping Authority's assessment of the normal value of canned tuna in Thailand. Accordingly, no specific references to Customs' assessment of Thai normal values can be made.

When the information was considered insufficient, Customs determined normal values based on the best information available, as it is empowered to do under the legislation and in accordance with the GATT Anti-Dumping Code.

(2) The actions of the foreign exporters did not equate to a veto in the cases mentioned. As stated above, the special provisions of the Customs Act in relation to anti-dumping duties enabled Customs to determine normal values using the alternative methods.

Customs has no `power' over foreign exporters and those exporters accordingly are not compelled to provide Customs with any information. Nor, as previously advised, is Customs reliant on information from exporters.

The legislation empowers Customs to ascertain normal values based on the information provided by the exporter, the importer or the applicant, depending on the circumstances and what is considered to be the best information available.
(3) Australian legislation already includes a provision, consistent with the GATT Anti-Dumping Code, which allows for the use of best information available.

Where foreign exporters do not provide sufficient information, either by refusal or non-availability, a decision is made on the best information available to Customs. A judgement is made on which information is the most reliable and relevant. Values based upon the best information available may include elements relating to the particular exporter, or other exporters, other information gathered in the country of export or any other relevant information, including information provided by the Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did an Italian exporter of canned tomatoes successfully exploit a limit of 120 days on the collection of interim securities against dumped or subsidised imports which allowed subsidised imports from Italy to rise from 590 tonnes in July 1993 to 2000 tonnes in November 1993; if so, (a) does the 120 day provision provide a loophole which effectively destroys Australia's fair trade and dumping countervailing procedures and (b) will the Minister close the loophole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: In the period referred to by the Honourable Member, July to November 1993, imports of canned tomatoes from Italy did rise. However, the rise was not due to any `exploitation' of, or `loophole' in, Australia's anti-dumping or countervailing procedures. At the time the anti-dumping and countervailing duties which had been imposed on canned tomatoes during 1992 were suspended due to legal proceedings.

Dumping and countervailing duties were imposed on canned tomatoes exported from Italy when the then Minister signed notices on 21 April 1992 after considering and accepting recommendations from the Anti-Dumping Authority.

La Doria, an Italian exporter of canned tomatoes, then applied to the Federal Court for Orders setting aside the Authority's recommendations and the Minister's decisions claiming that several errors of law had been made. When the matter was heard by the Court the Authority acknowledged that an error had occurred which influenced the recommendations it had made in regard to the level of duties and consequently the `duty' notices. When Justice Lee handed down his decision on 11 June 1993 he ordered, inter alia, that both the `duty' notices and the notices relating to `cause' be set aside. Accordingly, collection of duties ceased with effect from that date.

Customs, on 23 June 1993, imposed securities on imports of tomatoes pending consideration by the Authority of matters arising from the Court's decision. Securities taken in respect of anti-dumping or countervailing duties that may become

ANSWER.PARA: payable are valid for a period of four months. The four month limit is a legal requirement which is in accord with Australia's GATT obligations.

PARA.TAB: On 21 July 1993 Customs, being aware that an appeal had been lodged decided that it would be inappropriate to continue the requirement for securities as it was most unlikely that the proceedings of the Court would be finalised quickly thereby allowing the Authority to further advise the Minister.

The Full Federal Court subsequently handed down its majority decision on the 10 February 1994 upholding the appeal. The Authority then advised the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction as to the amount of the measures that should be imposed resulting in duties again being applied to exports of canned tomatoes from Italy with effect from 10 February 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many instances of tourists attempting to use illegally obtained Australia tertiary courses for points test requirements for permanent residence did the Minister's Department discover between 1990 and 1994.
(2) To what degree is the Minister's Department monitoring the matter referred to in part (1).
(3) In respect of how many applicants were qualifications vetoed under the points test requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2) and (3) I am advised that there is no points test requirement for the grant of permanent residence in Australia.
